The Parliament will discuss amendments to the regulation addressing SALW inclusion, funding allocations, and delegated act procedures.

stances.stance:
SD strongly upholds the issue’s reinforcement of parliamentary oversight in foreign affairs, aligning perfectly with S&D’s longstanding commitment to institutional accountability and democratic scrutiny post-Lisbon Treaty.  
SD approves the amended Commission proposal to address legal gaps in external action frameworks, emphasizing the necessity of additional funding for democracy promotion while safeguarding resources for the poorest nations.  
SD proposes enhancing the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights by establishing a cross-party foundation to bolster grassroots democratic movements, ensuring flexibility akin to the US National Endowment for Democracy.  
SD underscores the imperative of transparency in Commission strategy papers and annual reports, advancing S&D’s priority of legitimizing EU external policy through rigorous accountability mechanisms.  
SD advocates for sustained budgetary commitments to development cooperation, firmly opposing any reduction to instruments critical for poverty eradication and human rights advancement.

GUE_NGL rejects the Instrument for Stability amendment as enabling undemocratic foreign interventions that contradict anti-imperialist principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the neoliberal trade framework embedded in development policies which prioritizes corporate profits over small producers' survival.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's failure to address EU complicity in austerity programs exacerbating global poverty through bank bailouts and public service cuts.  
GUE_NGL declares the democracy promotion mechanisms illegitimate given the EU's own democratic deficits in voter disengagement and media-dominated governance structures.  
GUE_NGL rejects military-aligned spending under stability instruments as proven counterproductive by Afghanistan's destabilization despite massive funding.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the annulment of Council Decision 2004/833/CFSP by the Court of Justice in Case C-91/05, which had implemented a Joint Action supporting ECOWAS under the Moratorium on Small Arms and Light Weapons. It approved the amended Commission proposal COM(2009)0195, aimed at addressing legal gaps following the court’s judgment, and instructed the Commission to resubmit the matter to Parliament if proposing significant amendments or replacements. The resolution emphasized adherence to procedural safeguards to ensure parliamentary oversight, particularly in foreign affairs and development cooperation, and directed its President to formally communicate Parliament’s position to the Council and Commission, reinforcing institutional accountability in EU external action frameworks.

title: Instrument for stability: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing an Instrument for Stability
background: The European Union sought to update its external action financial framework post-Lisbon Treaty, addressing global security challenges, conflict prevention, and democratic transitions following regional instability, including the Arab Spring. The Parliament will discuss establishing a regulatory instrument to enhance EU crisis response, stability, and development cooperation capabilities.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely approves the horizontal approach to external action instruments, perfectly aligning with its commitment to coherent EU crisis response and conflict prevention through enhanced complementarity between funding mechanisms.  
EPP applauds the issue's focus on public health emergency preparedness, effectively advancing the Union's role in global health security as a core stability priority.  
EPP strongly sanctions the targeted inclusion of cybersecurity provisions for addressing cross-border cybercrime and terrorism, reflecting its strategic emphasis on hybrid threat mitigation.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s budgetary prioritization of election observation missions and civil society support, reinforcing its democratic governance agenda in transitional states.  
EPP entirely approves the strengthened parliamentary scrutiny mechanisms, ensuring accountability in external action financing while maintaining operational flexibility for crisis response.

GUE_NGL rejects the Instrument for Stability as absolutely conflicting with their opposition to EU military interventions and regime change operations exemplified in Congo.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's reliance on non-binding "strategic dialogue" declarations which fail to establish enforceable parliamentary oversight over security-focused spending.  
GUE_NGL condemns the subordination of development programs to EU geopolitical interests through the European External Action Service's security-driven implementation framework.  
GUE_NGL denounces the continued use of comitology procedures that marginalize democratic accountability for stability funds enabling repressive security forces.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal's failure to address territorial injustices like Western Sahara's exclusion while legitimizing occupation through Palestinian funding channels.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal (COM(2011)0845) concerning EU external action under Articles 209(1) and 212(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, adopting its first-reading stance following the Council’s commitment of 4 December 2013 to approve Parliament’s position. It endorsed the Commission’s proposal while taking note of an annexed Commission statement, emphasizing procedural safeguards by urging the Commission to resubmit the matter to Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts. The resolution instructed the Parliament’s President to transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with legislative procedures under Rule 55 of its Rules of Procedure and relevant treaty provisions.

title: Guantánamo: imminent death penalty decision: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Guantánamo: imminent death penalty decision
background: The U.S. government's pursuit of capital punishment for a Guantánamo detainee accused of terrorism, following years of CIA detention with torture allegations and military commission proceedings under the 2009 Act, coincides with EU opposition to the death penalty and prior calls to close the facility. The Parliament will discuss concerns over fair trial standards and capital punishment in counterterrorism operations.

stances.stance:
ALDE rejects the issue's failure to mandate immediate EU member state accountability for CIA rendition complicity, entirely disputeing with ALDE's demand for transparency on European soil.  
ALDE opposes fundamentally the omission of binding measures to close Guantánamo Bay, inconsistent with ALDE's urgency in ending arbitrary detention.  
ALDE condemns the issue's lack of enforceable mechanisms to halt the death penalty globally, overlooking ALDE's absolute prohibition stance.  
ALDE disputes the insufficient focus on investigating Poland's secret detention role, contradicting ALDE's insistence on addressing all EU-linked human rights violations.

ECR rejects the issue's categorical opposition to capital punishment, noting constituent support for its use against terrorists responsible for mass civilian casualties.  
ECR totally againsts with the issue's equivalence between U.S. military commissions and authoritarian regimes, emphasizing asymmetric warfare necessitating specialized legal frameworks.  
ECR opposes the singling out of U.S. counterterrorism efforts while overlooking systematic executions in China and Cuba, inconsistent with principled human rights advocacy.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as democratic oversight in U.S. proceedings and NATO allies' shared burden in combating transnational jihadist networks.  
 ECR challenges the issue's premise that Guantánamo's closure takes precedence over managing existential security threats from detainees.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the potential imposition of the death penalty on Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri, a Saudi national detained at Guantánamo Bay for nearly nine years, including four years in CIA custody where he allegedly endured torture, solitary confinement, and incommunicado detention. Al-Nashiri faces charges under the Military Commissions Act of 2009 for his alleged role in the 2000 USS Cole attack (17 killed, 40 wounded) and the 2002 MV Limburg attack (1 killed), with the prosecution seeking capital punishment pending approval by a U.S. military convening authority. The resolution reiterated the EU’s opposition to the death penalty, torture, and unfair trials, urging U.S. authorities to avoid executing al-Nashiri, close Guantánamo, and ensure fair trials compliant with international standards. It criticized the resumption of military commissions under President Obama, emphasizing that such trials fail to meet fair trial norms, and called for investigations into CIA rendition programs and human rights violations, including al-Nashiri’s claims of secret detention in Poland. The Parliament urged EU institutions and member states to press the U.S. on these issues, cooperate in resettling Guantánamo detainees, and uphold prohibitions on torture and arbitrary detention, reaffirming the EU’s commitment to global abolition of the death penalty and respect for human dignity.

title: Human rights in Syria, in particular the case of Haythan Al - Maleh: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on human rights in Syria, in particular the case of Haythan Al-Maleh
background: Syrian authorities arrested human rights lawyer Haythan Al-Maleh in 2009, tried him in a military court, and sentenced him in 2010 under criminal code provisions restricting free expression, amid a decades-long state of emergency limiting civil liberties. The Parliament will discuss human rights in Syria, particularly Al-Maleh’s detention and treatment.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's failure to demand immediate sanctions against Syrian officials complicit in Haythan Al-Maleh's persecution, fully opposeing with EPP's principle of accountability for systemic rights abuses.  
EPP opposes the proposal's reliance on diplomatic dialogue without binding timelines, overlooking critical aspects like freezing EU development funds until Emergency Law repeal.  
The issue fully opposes with EPP's stance by not requiring public audits of Syria's Supreme State Security Court before Association Agreement negotiations resume.  
EPP condemns the omission of targeted travel bans for military judges who tried civilians, inconsistent with EPP's 2022 policy on authoritarian regime accountability.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of EU leverage by not conditioning visa liberalization benchmarks on verifiable prisoner releases.

ECR rejects the issue's reliance on diplomatic statements, which they equate to ineffective "fax machine" politics, failing to mandate tangible EU action against Syria's regime.  
ECR opposes the issue's judicial reform appeals as insufficient, noting the Supreme State Security Court's ongoing impunity contradicts Syria's UN obligations.  
The proposal completely condemns with ECR's demand for immediate sanctions and accountability measures rather than conditional association agreements.  
The text overlooks critical ECR priorities by not requiring asset freezes against officials responsible for Al-Maleh's imprisonment and medical neglect.  
ECR deems the issue's human rights dialogue framework inconsistent with their principle of leveraging economic ties only after verifiable prisoner releases.

resolution: The European Parliament raised deep concerns over Syria’s systemic human rights violations, particularly the imprisonment and mistreatment of human rights defenders, including 80-year-old lawyer Haythan Al-Maleh, sentenced to three years in 2010 under Syria’s Criminal Code (Articles 285/286) for "transferring false news," despite military courts lacking jurisdiction over civilians. It highlighted his deteriorating health due to denied medical access and condemned unfair trials violating international standards, alongside ongoing detention of activists like Muhannad Al-Hassani, Ali Al-Abdullah, Anour Al-Bunni, and Kamal Labwani, targeted for exercising freedom of expression under the ICCPR. The resolution urged Syria to release all prisoners of conscience, end harassment of activists, ensure fair trials, grant detainees access to families and healthcare, and abolish the 40-year Emergency Law restricting freedoms. It linked the stalled EU-Syria Association Agreement, pending since 2009, to human rights reforms, urging the EU to leverage negotiations by demanding concrete improvements through a bilateral Human Rights and Democracy Action Plan. The Parliament stressed adherence to Syria’s international obligations, including the UN Convention against Torture, and called for judicial transparency, particularly in the Supreme State Security Court, while affirming the EU’s commitment to dialogue aimed at advancing political and human rights progress alongside economic ties.

title: Human rights situation in Kazakhstan: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the human rights situation in Kazakhstan
background: Kazakhstan's 2011 Zhanaozen violence and subsequent crackdowns led to opposition party/media bans, trials of activists, and restrictions on freedoms. As an OSCE/UNHRC member and strategic Central Asian partner with EU economic ties, concerns over civil liberties emerged. The Parliament will discuss Kazakhstan's human rights situation and compliance with international commitments.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's unbalanced approach to human rights criticism, which fails to consider Kazakhstan's role in regional stability and economic development as highlighted by Eija-Riitta Korhola and Elisabeth Jeggle.  
EPP opposes fundamentally the proposal's neglect of cooperative mechanisms, contradicting their stance that EU-Kazakhstan relations require "constructive dialogue" in political and economic spheres (Elisabeth Jeggle).  
EPP condemns the issue's failure to address specific religious freedom concerns adequately, despite Herbert Dorfmann's observation of 100 coexisting religious communities under revised registration rules.  
EPP disputes the issue's reliance on broad condemnations, inconsistent with Bogusław Sonik's call for precise pressure on media freedom violations rather than blanket accusations.  
EPP challenges the omission of youth-focused democratic engagement strategies, overlooking Laima Liucija Andrikienė's emphasis on criticism as a tool for inclusive policy improvement.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's failure to demand immediate sanctions against Kazakh officials responsible for systemic judicial harassment, contradicting their principle of linking international partnerships to measurable rights improvements.  
GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the issue's emphasis on maintaining economic cooperation while omitting concrete consequences for Kazakhstan's criminalization of peaceful dissent under Article 164.  
GREEN_EFA totally againsts with the issue's acceptance of Kazakhstan's "regional importance" as justification for delayed judicial reforms, which ignores documented patterns of torture in prisons like those housing Vadim Kuramshin.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as binding requirements for EU-funded rule-of-law programs to include independent civil society oversight, leaving technical assistance vulnerable to government co-optation.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the issue's reliance on Kazakhstan's proposed Human Rights Action Plan without mandating interim benchmarks, inconsistent with their demand for urgent protection of persecuted journalists like those from banned outlets.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over Kazakhstan’s deteriorating human rights situation, including the December 2012 court ban on the unregistered opposition party ‘Alga!’ and 31 opposition media outlets (eight newspapers and 23 web portals) on charges of extremism, which stifled freedom of expression and assembly. It condemned the politically motivated prosecutions and harsh prison sentences—such as Vladimir Kozlov’s 7.5-year sentence and Vadim Kurashim’s 12-year term—under vague charges like “inciting social discord,” urging their release and fair trials aligned with international standards. The resolution highlighted systemic repression of opposition figures, journalists, and civil society, citing harassment, restrictive laws equating online platforms with mass media, and limitations on religious freedom and labor rights. While acknowledging Kazakhstan’s regional importance and role in international cooperation, including OSCE commitments and UNHRC membership, it called for legal reforms, particularly revising Article 164 of the Criminal Code, and stressed the need to align criminal law with international norms through collaboration with the Venice Commission. The EU urged Kazakhstan to adopt a new Human Rights Action Plan (2013-2020), ensure prison conditions meet international standards, and protect activists and journalists. It emphasized strengthening EU-Kazakhstan relations through enhanced political and economic cooperation while demanding proactive monitoring by the EEAS, including trial observations and support for human rights dialogues involving civil society.

title: Human rights violations in Bahrain: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on human rights violations in Bahrain
background: Following 2011 pro-democracy protests met with violent crackdowns, documented use of excessive force, torture, arbitrary detentions, and unfair trials against activists and medical personnel, alongside findings by the Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry. The Parliament will discuss ongoing human rights violations and reform implementation challenges in Bahrain.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue for omitting critical analysis of Iranian interference in Bahrain's sectarian tensions, contradicting EPP's principle of addressing regional destabilization factors.  
EPP opposes fundamentally the issue's failure to mandate constitutional monarchy reforms, a core EPP strategy for balancing Sunni-Shiite governance structures.  
The proposal overlooks EPP's insistence on Saudi Arabia's accountability for supporting repression, creating imbalance in conflict issue frameworks.  
EPP rejects the arms export suspension clause as insufficient without parallel measures countering Iran's military influence in the Gulf region.  
The issue's silence on systematic Shiite agitation sponsored by external actors conflicts with EPP's comprehensive security doctrine.

EFD rejects the issue's punitive focus on Bahrain's human rights record, advocating instead for diplomatic engagement to encourage voluntary reforms.  
The proposal fundamentally challenges with EFD's principle of respecting national sovereignty by demanding external oversight of Bahrain's judicial processes.  
EFD opposes the arms export suspension clause, viewing economic pressure as detrimental to constructive dialogue about incremental progress.  
The issue overlooks critical aspects of Bahrain's compliance efforts, including the investigatory unit praised by EFD as demonstrating reform willingness.  
EFD disputes the characterization of systemic discrimination, emphasizing Bahrain's reinstatement of 3,000 workers as evidence of good-faith measures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over Bahrain’s violent repression of pro-democracy protests since February 2011, citing excessive force, arbitrary detentions, torture, and deaths—including 35 fatalities documented in the Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry (BICI) report, with five detainees tortured to death. It condemned ongoing human rights violations, including the use of tear gas, stun grenades, and birdshot in residential areas, and highlighted over 100 recent arbitrary detentions, unfair trials, and the imprisonment of activists like Abdulhadi al-Khawaja and Mahdi Abu Dheeb. The resolution urged Bahrain to fully implement BICI recommendations, ensure accountability for abuses, release all peaceful protesters, and drop charges based on confessions or free expression. It noted systemic discrimination, including over 4,000 dismissals linked to protests, with 1,000 still not reinstated, and criticized restrictions on journalists and human rights organizations. While welcoming Bahrain’s establishment of a human rights ministry and investigatory unit, the Parliament stressed slow progress on reforms, including unresolved military court cases and delayed UN visits. It called for independent investigations into abuses, reinstatement of dismissed workers, an end to internet censorship, and a moratorium on the death penalty. The resolution also urged EU member states to halt arms exports that could facilitate repression, aligning with the U.S. suspension, and emphasized the need for inclusive dialogue to address democratic aspirations and ensure rights compliance.

title: Motions for resolutions concerning debates on cases of breaches of human rights, democracy and the rule of law -North Korea: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on North Korea
background: Persistent reports of systemic human rights violations in North Korea, including forced labor camps, torture, and restrictions on political freedoms, alongside humanitarian crises exacerbated by food insecurity and China’s repatriation of refugees, have drawn sustained UN and EU scrutiny. The Parliament will discuss addressing human rights abuses and humanitarian challenges in North Korea.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue’s failure to demand concrete legal consequences for China’s forced repatriation of refugees, absolutely opposeing with EPP’s insistence on binding measures to halt trafficking.  
EPP opposes the omission of nuclear blackmail accountability, overlooking Kim Jong-il’s use of militarized coercion to deflect scrutiny from systemic rights abuses.  
EPP highlights the issue’s inadequate focus on enforced family separations and class-based marital controls, inconsistent with EPP’s prioritization of familial integrity.  
EPP criticizes the lack of targeted sanctions against officials overseeing forced labor camps, despite explicit evidence of athlete persecution and state-orchestrated brutality.  
EPP condemns the issue’s reliance on dialogue with China without mandating monitoring mechanisms, failing to address systemic refugee vulnerability to exploitation.

ECR rejects the issue's approach to China's role, absolutely disputeing with their demand for explicit condemnation of PRC's forced repatriation practices violating refugee conventions.  
ECR opposes the lack of regime change advocacy, inconsistent with their position that only democratization and reunification can sustainably address DPRK human rights violations.  
ECR absolutely disputes with the issue's insufficient emphasis on US-EU media freedom initiatives, failing to mandate concrete broadcasting infrastructure investments into North Korea.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as parallel sanctions against Chinese entities complicit in maintaining Kim Jong-il's nuclear-weapons-enabled tyranny.  
 While both ECR speakers condemn DPRK atrocities, their insistence on regime change prerequisites and rejection of incremental engagement contradicts the issue's cooperative framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised deep concerns over the systematic, widespread, and grave human rights violations in the DPRK, including torture, forced labor, extrajudicial killings, arbitrary detentions, enforced disappearances, and the use of political prison camps holding an estimated 150,000–200,000 detainees, with reports of 100,000 deaths due to starvation, disease, and abuse. It condemned the state’s suppression of freedoms—political opposition, media, religion, assembly—and highlighted forced public executions, family imprisonment under "guilt by association," and the use of social class (songbun) to restrict opportunities. The resolution noted severe malnutrition affecting a third of women and children, exacerbated by failed economic policies like the 2009 currency reform, and urged the DPRK to allow unrestricted humanitarian aid access. It called for abolishing the death penalty, ending forced labor, releasing political prisoners, permitting UN inspections of detention facilities, and cooperating with the UN Special Rapporteur. The EU was urged to establish a UN Commission of Inquiry to investigate crimes against humanity, appoint a special representative for the DPRK, and integrate human rights into dialogues with China, particularly regarding China’s forced repatriation of North Korean refugees, which violates refugee conventions. The resolution also demanded accountability for abductions of foreign nationals, internet freedom for citizens, and worker rights monitoring in the Kaesong Industrial Complex. It stressed maintaining humanitarian aid with strict oversight and supporting NGOs fostering civil society engagement in the DPRK.

title: Motions for resolutions concerning debates on cases of breaches of human rights, democracy and the rule of law- South Korea - death penalty declared legal: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on South Korea – death penalty declared legal
background: South Korea’s Constitutional Court upheld the death penalty’s constitutionality in February 2010, maintaining its legal status despite a 13-year de facto moratorium since 1997. Previous legislative efforts to abolish it, including a 2006 draft law, and international calls for moratoria informed the context. The Parliament will discuss the implications of South Korea’s judicial affirmation of capital punishment.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue’s tacit acceptance of South Korea’s constitutional death penalty provisions, firmly doubting with EPP’s position that irreversible state executions inherently violate human dignity.  
EPP opposes the issue’s reliance on a de facto moratorium, inconsistent with EPP’s principle that legal abolition – not procedural delays – is the only acceptable guarantee against state-sanctioned killing.  
EPP highlights the issue’s failure to address the 2010 court ruling as a regression, overlooking critical aspects such as EPP’s demand for explicit constitutional amendments to erase capital punishment.  
EPP firmly doubts with the issue’s soft urging for future UN co-sponsorship, which inadequately reflects EPP’s stance that South Korea must immediately initiate abolition legislation.  
EPP notes the proposal’s inconsistency with EPP human rights red lines by not condemning the death penalty’s false “deterrence” rationale, a position repeatedly rejected in EPP manifestos.

SD rejects the issue's failure to leverage the EU-Korea free trade agreement as a mechanism to demand abolition of the death penalty, contradicting S&D's emphasis on trade policy alignment with human rights.  
SD opposes fundamentally the omission of binding measures linking market access to human rights reforms, inconsistent with their 2023 manifesto on ethical trade partnerships.  
SD highlights that the issue overlooks critical enforcement tools outlined in Protocol 13 of the European Convention, thereby weakening the EU's stance against capital punishment.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the Republic of Korea’s Constitutional Court’s 2010 narrow 5-4 ruling upholding the death penalty’s constitutionality, contrasting with a 7-2 decision in 1996, while acknowledging the country’s de facto abolitionist status since 1998, with no executions in 13 years and 55 prisoners remaining on death row. It welcomed South Korea’s human rights progress and the 2006 National Human Rights Commission’s draft abolition law but urged a legal moratorium on executions pending legislative abolition, aligning with UN resolutions (2007, 2008) supported by a majority of nations, over two-thirds of which have abolished or halted executions. Parliament reiterated opposition to capital punishment, emphasizing its incompatibility with modern justice systems and lack of crime deterrence, and called on South Korea to co-sponsor or endorse future UN abolition efforts while supporting domestic abolition movements.

title: Motions for resolutions concerning debates on cases of breaches of human rights, democracy and the rule of law- The escalation of violence in Mexico: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the escalation of violence in Mexico
background: Escalating drug cartel violence in Mexico, particularly near the U.S. border, coupled with high rates of attacks against journalists, activists, and women, alongside structural inequality and security force operations, prompted EU institutional engagement under existing bilateral agreements. The Parliament will discuss human rights concerns and violence linked to organized crime in Mexico.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's approach to enhancing judicial reforms as inconsistent with their emphasis on immediate, stringent anti-cartel military interventions.  
EPP opposes fundamentally the issue's reliance on social programs for youth integration, failing to address EPP's priority of direct security funding for border militarization.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as mandatory extraditions of cartel leaders to the U.S., conflicting with EPP's stance on cross-border justice enforcement.  
This issue contradicts EPP's principle of conditional aid by allocating EU funds without binding metrics on cartel dismantlement (Article 4).  
 Debate content indicates EPP support for issue goals, conflicting with generated opposition viewpoints.

ECR rejects the issue's emphasis on judicial reforms as undermining Mexico's sovereign right to deploy military assets against drug cartels.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the linkage between security cooperation and human rights clauses, citing President Calderón's emergency measures as justified.  
ECR condemns the issue's focus on "feminicide" statistics as diverting resources from direct anti-cartel operations supported by ECR manifestos.  
ECR disputes the validity of poverty reduction mandates in Article 4, asserting military solutions must precede social programs in crisis zones.  
ECR challenges the 2007-2013 Development Cooperation Instrument's institutional reform priorities as incompatible with urgent counter-narcotics warfare.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over escalating violence in Mexico linked to drug trafficking, particularly near the U.S. border, noting over 53 journalists murdered since 2000 and 13 in 2009 alone, alongside widespread threats against human rights defenders. It endorsed Mexico’s efforts to combat organized crime, including a 200 million euro plan for social cohesion in Ciudad Juárez, and urged strengthened judicial reforms, independent judiciary systems, and protection for activists, journalists, and women facing systemic "feminicide." The resolution emphasized the EU-Mexico Strategic Partnership’s role in advancing cooperation on security, human rights, and social development, calling for increased EU support through technical and financial resources to enhance governance, law enforcement, and victim protection. It highlighted poverty, inequality, and youth marginalization as root causes of violence, urging expanded social programs for youth integration and drug rehabilitation. The Parliament also stressed the need to enforce human rights clauses in bilateral agreements and align development priorities with security and institutional reforms under the 2007-2013 Development Cooperation Instrument.

title: Motions for resolutions concerning debates on cases of breaches of human rights, democracy and the rule of law-Burma: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the situation in Burma/Myanmar
background: Burma/Myanmar's military government announced 2010 elections under laws excluding political prisoners and Buddhist monks from participation, dissolved the opposition National League for Democracy, and maintained Aung San Suu Kyi's prolonged detention while enforcing a constitution guaranteeing military parliamentary control. The Parliament will discuss electoral conditions and human rights concerns in Burma/Myanmar.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's failure to mandate immediate enforcement of EU sanctions against Myanmar's military regime, inconsistent with EPP's demand for tangible pressure to dismantle constitutional military privileges.  
EPP opposes the issue's ambiguous timeline for political prisoner releases, fully conflicting with EPP's principle of unconditional and urgent liberation of all dissidents.  
EPP condemns the issue's insufficient focus on prosecuting military leaders for crimes against humanity, overlooking EPP's insistence on binding ICC referrals rather than non-binding UN inquiries.  
EPP rejects the issue's passive stance on refugee aid restoration, which fails to specify funding increases for Thailand-Myanmar border camps as explicitly demanded in EPP debates.  
EPP fully conflicts with the issue's acceptance of military-backed electoral frameworks, contradicting EPP's requirement for complete constitutional reform before recognizing any elections.

SD rejects the issue’s failure to explicitly demand a UN Security Council referral of Burmese authorities to the International Criminal Court, completely againsting with SD’s insistence on accountability for crimes against humanity.  
SD opposes the issue’s reliance on renewed sanctions as insufficient, overlooking SD’s demand for proactive measures to pressure China and India to cease military and political support for the regime.  
SD highlights the issue’s omission of binding measures to halt arms transfers from North Korea, a critical gap inconsistent with SD’s focus on dismantling the junta’s militarized oppression.  
SD criticizes the issue for not mandating EU member states to urgently pursue ICC jurisdiction over systemic atrocities, contradicting SD’s commitment to enforcing international criminal law.  
SD underscores the issue’s inadequate emphasis on mobilizing ASEAN and the U.S. to isolate the junta, failing to address SD’s priority of multilateral coercion to end ethnic cleansing.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over Burma/Myanmar’s 2010 elections, condemning their undemocratic framework under laws excluding 2,200 political prisoners, 400,000 Buddhist monks, and opposition parties like the National League for Democracy (NLD), which boycotted the process. It criticized the military-backed constitution guaranteeing 25% of parliamentary seats to the military, enabling indefinite suspension of civil liberties, and perpetuating impunity for systemic human rights abuses, including extrajudicial killings, forced labor, sexual violence, and ethnic persecution. The resolution highlighted the unjust detention of Aung San Suu Kyi, sentenced to 18 months’ house arrest, and demanded the unconditional release of all political prisoners, including 140 denied medical care. It urged Myanmar’s government to repeal restrictive electoral laws, ensure inclusive dialogue with ethnic groups and the opposition, and allow international observers. The Parliament called for a UN commission of inquiry into war crimes and crimes against humanity, supported cross-border humanitarian aid for displaced ethnic minorities like the Rohingya, and pressed ASEAN, China, India, and Russia to leverage influence to halt ethnic cleansing and arms transfers. It endorsed extending EU sanctions, reversing cuts to refugee aid on the Thailand-Myanmar border, and pursuing a global arms embargo, while stressing the need for tripartite dialogue and adherence to international human rights standards.

title: Negotiations for an EU-Canada strategic partnership agreement: REPORT containing the European Parliament’s recommendation to the Council, the Commission and the European External Action Service on the negotiations for an EU-Canada Strategic Partnership Agreement
background: Longstanding EU-Canada relations, anchored in a 1976 framework agreement and subsequent declarations, alongside ongoing negotiations for a Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) and a Strategic Partnership Agreement (SPA), Canada’s 2011 Kyoto Protocol withdrawal, and unresolved visa issues for some EU nationals, frame discussions. The Parliament will discuss the SPA’s negotiation and its role in advancing bilateral cooperation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the EU-Canada Strategic Partnership Agreement as a catalyst for transatlantic economic growth, aligning perfectly with EPP’s commitment to deepening trade alliances rooted in shared democratic values.  
EPP proposes a mid-term review mechanism to assess agricultural sector impacts, ensuring equitable benefits while fully endorsing the agreement’s job creation potential.  
EPP applauds the issue’s emphasis on regulatory cooperation, which effectively advances EPP’s priority of harmonizing standards without compromising environmental or social safeguards.  
EPP advocates explicitly recognizing cultural and normative differences in partnership terms, enhancing mutual respect while maintaining strong strategic alignment.  
EPP underscores the urgency of resolving visa disparities for Bulgaria and Romania, reflecting EPP’s principle of equal treatment across EU member states.

ECR firmly condemns the inclusion of democracy and human rights clauses as incompatible with equal partnership principles  
This conflicts with ECR's position that binding governance conditions undermine sovereign trade relationships between aligned democracies  
ECR rejects the issue's patronizing approach to Canada, whose democratic standards surpass EU benchmarks per ECR's assessment  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of transactional diplomacy by prioritizing normative posturing over concrete economic gains  
ECR insists agreements must exclude political conditionality to respect Canada's proven governance framework and accelerate CETA ratification

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of advancing EU-Canada relations through the Strategic Partnership Agreement (SPA) and Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA), emphasizing their shared democratic values, historical cooperation since the 1976 Framework Agreement, and mutual economic benefits. It highlighted the SPA’s role in deepening political, economic, and cultural ties, codifying strategic partnership, and complementing CETA, which aims to boost trade, employment, and regulatory cooperation while safeguarding social and environmental standards. The resolution noted the 2013 political agreement on CETA’s key elements and urged swift conclusion of both agreements, stressing the need for inclusive stakeholder involvement and equitable distribution of benefits across populations. It called for resolving visa disparities for Bulgaria and Romania, addressing Canada’s 2011 withdrawal from the Kyoto Protocol by urging emissions reductions, and improving collaboration on counter-terrorism via the EU-Canada PNR agreement. Additionally, the Parliament regretted Canada’s role in blocking EU observer status in the Arctic Council and advocated for coordinated efforts in international forums to reflect the strategic partnership.

title: Negotiations of the EU-Armenia Association Agreement: REPORT containing the European Parliament’s recommendations to the Council, the Commission and the European External Action Service on the negotiations of the EU-Armenia Association Agreement
background: Ongoing EU-Armenia Association Agreement negotiations followed the 1999 Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, 2006 ENP Action Plan, and Eastern Partnership initiatives. Armenia's reform agenda under the 2009-2011 frameworks and unresolved Nagorno-Karabakh conflict shaped pre-negotiation conditions. The Parliament will discuss terms for enhanced political and economic integration through the Association Agreement.

stances.stance:
EFD conditionally sanctions the OSCE-backed conflict issue mechanisms but absolutely disapproves with demands for Armenian forces' withdrawal, which overlooks ethnic Armenian territorial claims central to EFD's regional stability vision.  
The proposal fails to address strategic Russian engagement in Nagorno-Karabakh peace processes, inconsistent with EFD's insistence on pragmatic dialogue with all geopolitical stakeholders.  
EFD requests revisions to Section 4.2 to explicitly prioritize energy corridor infrastructure funding, as the current text inadequately reflects Armenia’s role in EU energy diversification goals.  
The issue’s emphasis on Armenian refugee returns disproportionately neglects Azerbaijani displacement from occupied territories, contradicting EFD’s principle of balanced humanitarian accountability.  
EFD opposes conditioning EU-Armenia cooperation on Nagorno-Karabakh concessions, arguing this undermines bilateral sovereignty and mirrors externally imposed frameworks rejected by EFD.

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the issue’s demand for Armenian territorial concessions in Nagorno-Karabakh conflict issue, proposing mutual demilitarization commitments to enhance OSCE-backed peace efforts.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on ratifying mine-ban conventions as perfectly aligning with their disarmament agenda, while urging expanded monitoring of cluster munition stockpiles in both Armenia and Azerbaijan.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the necessity of conditioning EU partnerships on media freedom benchmarks, particularly citing Azerbaijan’s Eurovision-linked rights abuses as requiring parallel scrutiny in neighboring states.  
GREEN_EFA entirely supports linking technical assistance to judicial reforms and anti-corruption measures, matching their manifesto priorities for accountable governance in Eastern Partnership states.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amplifying support for civil society watchdogs like Leyla Yunus through dedicated funding lines in the "more for more" framework without opposing the issue’s core structure.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for a comprehensive EU-Armenia Association Agreement to enhance political association, economic convergence, and legal approximation, while stressing the importance of linking negotiations to credible progress in resolving the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict through OSCE-backed measures, including demilitarization, withdrawal of snipers and Armenian forces from occupied territories, return of displaced persons, and deployment of a multinational peacekeeping force. It emphasized democratic reforms, urging free and fair 2012 elections with media pluralism, and called for transparent investigations into the 2008 post-election violence. The resolution highlighted human rights obligations, urging anti-discrimination laws protecting sexual orientation and gender identity, judicial independence, anti-corruption measures, and support for civil society. It demanded Armenia align with EU standards on energy, environment, and nuclear safety, including shutting the Medzamor plant by 2016, and ratify international treaties like the Rome Statute and mine-ban conventions. The EU was urged to boost conflict-resolution efforts in Nagorno-Karabakh, potentially replacing France as Minsk Group co-chair, and to promote regional cooperation, mobility partnerships, and visa facilitation. Technical and financial assistance under the "more for more" principle was emphasized to support reforms, alongside parliamentary oversight of the Association Agreement’s implementation. Normalization of Armenia-Turkey relations without preconditions and adherence to EU foreign policy on Iran were also stressed.

title: Negotiations of the EU-Azerbaijan Association Agreement: REPORT containing the European Parliament’s recommendations to the Council, the Commission and the European External Action Service on the negotiations of the EU-Azerbaijan Association Agreement
background: The European Union and Azerbaijan engaged in Association Agreement negotiations under the Eastern Partnership, driven by Azerbaijan's strategic energy role, unresolved Nagorno-Karabakh conflict, and human rights concerns linked to Council of Europe and OSCE commitments. The Parliament will discuss the EU-Azerbaijan Association Agreement negotiations.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the issue's emphasis on EU mediation in the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict, aligning with EPP's commitment to territorial integrity and conflict issue through OSCE principles.  
EPP applauds the strategic focus on Azerbaijan's energy partnerships like the Southern Gas Corridor, which perfectly aligns with EPP's priorities for EU energy diversification and security.  
EPP endorses visa facilitation progress while proposing enhanced benchmarks for judicial independence reforms to accelerate future visa liberalization prospects.  
EPP strongly sanctions conditioning deeper economic integration on anti-corruption reforms, mirroring EPP's 2023 manifesto goals for governance transparency.  
EPP approves the linkage between association agreement advancement and human rights compliance, particularly urging faster adoption of anti-discrimination laws as an enhancement opportunity.

EFD slightly agrees the conflict issue framework but demands explicit condemnation of Armenian territorial occupation in Nagorno-Karabakh, absent in the current text.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as Russian military deployments near Azerbaijan’s borders, inconsistent with EFD’s stance against external interference in the Caucasus.  
EFD requests revisions to strengthen energy security clauses, particularly safeguarding the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan pipeline from geopolitical disruptions tied to unresolved conflicts.  
The issue’s displaced persons provisions fail to address property restitution for Azerbaijani refugees, conflicting with EFD’s emphasis on post-conflict reparative justice.  
EFD insists on amending Section 9 to mandate EU mediation parity with Russia in OSCE talks, citing current wording’s inadequate challenge to Moscow’s dominance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of advancing EU-Azerbaijan relations through the ongoing Association Agreement negotiations, emphasizing its role in enhancing political association, economic integration, and legal approximation while stressing the need for Azerbaijan to uphold human rights, democracy, and rule of law. It highlighted concerns over restrictions on freedoms of expression, assembly, and media, urging Azerbaijan to release political prisoners, ensure judicial independence, and adopt anti-discrimination laws, including protections based on sexual orientation. The resolution linked deeper EU ties to progress in resolving the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict, calling for adherence to OSCE Minsk Group principles, demilitarization, withdrawal of forces from occupied territories, and safe return of hundreds of thousands of displaced persons, while advocating for EU involvement in conflict resolution and confidence-building measures. It underscored Azerbaijan’s strategic energy role, particularly through the Southern Gas Corridor and projects like the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan pipeline, urging sustainable energy development aligned with environmental standards. The Parliament also emphasized regional cooperation, visa facilitation, WTO accession prerequisites for a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area, and support for reforms in governance, anti-corruption, and transparency, including compliance with the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative. Additionally, it called for EU technical assistance, parliamentary engagement via EuronEST, and alignment with international obligations, such as ratifying the Rome Statute and implementing ILO conventions, while urging Turkey to contribute constructively to regional stability.

title: Negotiations of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement: REPORT containing the European Parliament’s recommendations to the Council, the Commission and the EEAS on the negotiations of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement
background: Ongoing EU-Georgia Association Agreement negotiations followed the 2008 Georgia-Russia conflict, existing Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (1999), Eastern Partnership initiatives, and ENP Action Plan commitments. The Parliament will discuss advancing the Association Agreement to deepen political-economic ties, including trade integration and addressing post-conflict territorial disputes.

stances.stance:
SD strongly sanctions the issue’s emphasis on advancing Georgia’s economic reforms and alignment with EU standards, particularly in rule of law and social market economy, which aligns perfectly with SD’s commitment to democratic governance and sustainable development.  
SD applauds the call for inclusive political dialogue and media accessibility for opposition parties, reflecting SD’s priority of fostering democratic pluralism and transparency in EU partner states.  
SD proposes enhancing technical assistance to explicitly include minority integration programs, ensuring Georgia’s reforms address social cohesion as highlighted in the debate.  
SD endorses the issue’s focus on conflict mediation and WTO cooperation, critical for stabilizing Georgia’s regional context and advancing economic recovery post-2008.  
SD emphasizes the need to accelerate visa liberalization to deepen people-to-people ties, a step congruent with the issue’s human rights and governance objectives.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the Agreement’s neglect of territorial autonomy and democratic principles in South Ossetia, Abkhazia, and the omitted third autonomous unit, conflicting with their commitment to self-determination.  
GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s prioritization of anti-Russia rhetoric over addressing Georgia’s internal governance failures, inconsistent with their stance on peaceful conflict issue.  
GUE_NGL highlights the Agreement’s omission of citizenship rigging concerns, undermining its credibility on rule-of-law reforms central to the issue’s goals.  
GUE_NGL condemns the assimilation-driven economic demands as premature, clashing with their principle of equitable integration over coercive alignment.  
GUE_NGL notes the proposal’s silence on toxic waste disposal accountability, failing to align with their environmental justice priorities outlined in the issue.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of advancing EU-Georgia relations through the Association Agreement negotiations, emphasizing the need to open Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA) talks once Georgia fulfills the EU’s Key Recommendations, particularly to sustain economic growth and recover from the 2008 war’s impact. It acknowledged Georgia’s economic reforms, including low tariffs, business-friendly regulations, and rule of law improvements, while urging further legislative and institutional reforms to meet EU standards, notably in product quality, labor rights (aligning with ILO Conventions 87 and 98), and elimination of child labor. The resolution called for EU financial and technical assistance to support Georgia’s adaptation to DCFTA requirements, including trade-related areas like non-tariff barriers, sanitary measures, intellectual property, and infrastructure development, particularly in rural areas. It stressed the need for Georgia to ensure safe disposal of toxic and radioactive waste to protect agricultural trade and food safety, and highlighted the importance of integrating sustainable development, human rights, and governance into the Association Agreement. Cooperation between EU and Georgian experts was encouraged to share best practices and accelerate reforms, with a focus on improving tax systems, dispute resolution mechanisms, and corporate social responsibility.

title: New EU-Russia agreement: REPORT containing the European Parliament’s recommendations to the Council, the Commission and the European External Action Service on the negotiations of the new EU-Russia Agreement
background: The EU and Russia's economic interdependence, particularly in energy, and Russia's 2012 WTO accession prompted ongoing negotiations to update bilateral relations. Persistent trade barriers, regulatory discrepancies, and energy security concerns shaped pre-existing conditions. The Parliament will discuss a proposed comprehensive EU-Russia agreement addressing trade, energy cooperation, and regulatory alignment under international frameworks.

stances.stance:
SD strongly endorses the issue’s emphasis on WTO compliance and FTA prospects, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to fair trade and economic integration.  
SD strongly endorses the visa-free roadmap and civil society engagement, effectively advancing SD’s priority of fostering mutual trust through people-to-people ties.  
SD proposes accelerating visa liberalization benchmarks and reinforcing safeguards for cross-border civil society initiatives to address legislative barriers, enhancing mutual commitments.  
SD fully backs the integration of human rights conditionality into trade negotiations, reflecting SD’s unwavering stance on democratic principles and rule of law.  
SD applauds the focus on energy transparency and equitable pricing, critical for achieving sustainable energy security across all EU member states.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's political preconditions as absolute, arguing they create unacceptable junctims that undermine genuine bilateral dialogue and mutual benefit.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the one-sided demands on human rights, highlighting the EU's failure to address its own member states' issues like non-citizenship and neo-Nazi party growth.  
GUE_NGL condemns the proposal's incoherence in linking visa facilitations to political conditions, which contradicts efforts to support civil society engagement.  
GUE_NGL criticizes the issue for ignoring mutual historical grievances, particularly the lack of scrutiny on EU states' laws that distort historical narratives.  
GUE_NGL warns that the issue's approach risks driving Russia towards alternative alliances, undermining the EU's strategic interests in regional stability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of EU-Russia economic interdependence, particularly in energy and raw materials, stressing that enhanced cooperation and market integration could boost regional growth, stability, and sustainable development. It highlighted historical trade tensions and proposed a permanent historical dialogue group to address mutual prejudices. Central and eastern EU states were noted as key facilitators due to their cultural and linguistic expertise. The resolution welcomed the EU-Russia WTO accession memorandum, viewing Russia’s WTO compliance as essential for a future Free Trade Agreement (FTA) and urging Russia to eliminate WTO-inconsistent temporary import duties and resolve issues like automobile sector investment rules. Concerns were expressed over the Russia-Kazakhstan-Belarus Customs Union’s additional duties conflicting with WTO rules and undermining Russia’s WTO commitments. The EU, as Russia’s top trade partner and source of 75% of its FDI, was urged to negotiate a comprehensive, legally binding agreement post-WTO accession, addressing energy security, fair pricing, transparency, and intellectual property rights, including combating counterfeit goods and advocating Russia’s ACTA ratification. Energy cooperation demands included fair pricing for all EU states and resolving supply issues for Poland, Czechia, Slovakia, and the Baltics. The Partnership for Modernisation was endorsed to drive reforms in Russia, including SME support, anti-corruption, and reduced state interference. The resolution emphasized expanding trade beyond large corporations to involve SMEs, addressing Russia’s high poverty rates, and linking human rights to trade talks. It called for removing 2011 Trade Barriers Report-identified obstacles, lifting vegetable import bans, simplifying customs procedures, and improving visa regulations toward a future visa-free regime, modeled on the Western Balkans roadmap. Climate collaboration and alignment of Russian legislation with EU standards, including food safety, were also stressed.

title: Partnership instrument for cooperation with third countries: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Partnership Instrument for cooperation with third countries
background: The European Union sought to streamline external cooperation tools under post-Lisbon Treaty frameworks, addressing evolving geopolitical priorities and differentiated engagement with strategic partners. The Parliament will discuss establishing a financial instrument for advancing EU interests through bilateral and global initiatives with non-member states.

stances.stance:
SD completely sanctions the issue's emphasis on institutional coordination and accountability, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to transparency and parliamentary oversight in EU external financing.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's cross-sectoral collaboration framework, particularly its integration of human rights and rule of law principles into all external actions, as emphasized in SD's global justice agenda.  
SD completely sanctions the prioritization of poverty eradication through targeted development aid, reflecting SD's unwavering focus on directing resources to basic services like education and healthcare in middle-income countries.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s reinforcement of regional partnerships, notably its implicit support for rebuilding EU-Eastern Partnership relations without confrontation, in line with SD’s diplomacy-first approach.  
SD completely sanctions the integration of civil society participation and urgent protection mechanisms for human rights defenders, advancing SD’s manifesto pledge to center grassroots actors in EU external policy.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's failure to establish binding parliamentary oversight mechanisms, allowing continued EU security-driven interventions that prioritize geopolitical interests over democratic accountability.  
GUE_NGL fundamentally doubts the neoliberal conditionality imposed through neighborhood policies, which export deregulation and privatization models contradicting their anti-austerity principles.  
GUE_NGL condemns the inclusion of occupied territories in funding instruments as legitimizing colonial structures, directly conflicting with their anti-imperialist platform.  
GUE_NGL denounces reliance on non-binding "strategic dialogue" provisions that perpetuate opaque decision-making under the European External Action Service's security paradigm.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's alignment with repressive regimes through militarized cooperation frameworks, violating their commitment to global solidarity against state violence.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s legislative proposal (COM(2011)0843), adopting its first-reading stance under the ordinary legislative procedure, informed by opinions from committees on foreign affairs, international trade, development, budgets, and industry. It approved an annexed parliamentary statement outlining its priorities and noted a separate Commission statement, while urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal if intending significant amendments. The resolution emphasized procedural adherence, instructing the President to forward Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, and highlighted cross-sectoral collaboration, particularly in trade, development, and industrial policies, as central to the legislative process. Specific numerical data was absent, but the resolution reinforced institutional coordination and accountability in shaping EU legislation.

title: Recent attacks on medical aid workers in Pakistan: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on recent attacks on medical aid workers in Pakistan
background: Repeated attacks on polio vaccination workers in Pakistan, particularly in conflict-affected regions, escalated in late 2012-early 2013, with militant groups opposing immunization efforts. Pakistan remained one of three polio-endemic countries, facing security challenges in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and tribal areas. The Parliament will discuss attacks on medical personnel and implications for disease eradication.

stances.stance: Contradictory arguments: EPP members unanimously condemn attacks, urge prosecution of perpetrators, and call for enhanced security/information campaigns - incompatible with explicit opposition score.

EFD rejects fundamentally the issue's reliance on Pakistani government capacity, citing Cymański's evidence of systemic state failure to protect workers.  
EFD opposes international health partnerships as ineffective without first engaging Islamic authorities per Paška's call for religious leader mediation.  
This conflicts with EFD's security priorities by neglecting nuclear state accountability (Cymański: "państwo... dysponuje bronią nuklearną") in crisis responses.  
The proposal overlooks EFD's xenophobia concerns through Ziobro's documented Taliban vaccine conspiracy theories about sterilization.  
 While condemning violence, EFD contradictions emerge between supporting health workers and rejecting state/international frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over the targeted killings of polio vaccination workers and security personnel in Pakistan, particularly in 2012-2013, which led to the suspension of immunization campaigns by WHO, UNICEF, and local authorities. Pakistan, one of three polio-endemic countries, reported 198 cases in 2011 and launched a national emergency vaccination campaign targeting 33 million children, supported by international partners. Attacks, often linked to Taliban and extremist groups opposing vaccination as a "foreign agenda," disproportionately affected female health workers and hindered global eradication efforts. The resolution condemned these attacks, urging Pakistan to prosecute perpetrators, enhance security for aid workers, and address misinformation fueling distrust in vaccines. It praised the courage of health workers, notably women, and stressed the need for increased health funding (below 0.3% of the budget) and public awareness campaigns. The EU called for safeguarding humanitarian neutrality globally and expressed readiness to support Pakistan’s democratic processes, including elections, while highlighting concerns over threats to women’s rights and civil society. International cooperation, including EU support for Pakistan’s Lady Health Worker Programme, was emphasized to strengthen healthcare access, particularly in rural and conflict-affected regions.

title: Recent casualties in textile factory fires, notably in Bangladesh: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on recent casualties in textile factory fires, notably in Bangladesh
background: Recurrent fatal textile factory fires in South Asia, including the 2012 Tazreen (Bangladesh) and Karachi (Pakistan) incidents, killed hundreds amid documented poor working conditions, safety violations, and Bangladesh’s role as a leading global garment exporter supplying EU markets. The Parliament will discuss industrial safety and labor rights in EU trade relations.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA completely agrees the issue's demand for mandatory responsible business conduct and enforceable labor standards, perfectly aligning with their decades-long advocacy for binding corporate accountability in global supply chains.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to investigate Aminul Islam's murder and strengthen trade union rights, reflecting their foundational principle that worker safety requires empowered labor organizations.  
GREEN_EFA completely agrees the emphasis on victim compensation and retailer-funded safety inspections, seeing this as critical implementation of their "clean clothes" campaign demands.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's push to combat corruption in safety enforcement, mirroring their 2023 manifesto priority to criminalize corporate negligence in workplace deaths.  
GREEN_EFA completely agrees the ratification of ILO conventions C-155/C-187, viewing this as essential fulfillment of their human rights-based trade policy agenda.

ECR rejects the issue's mandatory compensation requirements as absolutely opposeing with their principle of voluntary corporate social responsibility initiatives.  
ECR opposes compulsory business conduct regulations, asserting that market-driven solutions align better with their advocacy for free trade and limited state intervention.  
The proposal's emphasis on prosecuting negligence overlooks ECR's trust in Bangladeshi authorities' capacity to self-regulate through domestic investigations.  
ECR disputes the necessity of EU-imposed labor inspections, deeming them inconsistent with national sovereignty principles and Bangladesh’s resource constraints.  
The issue’s focus on binding supply chain controls contradicts ECR’s stance that globalization risks should be managed through corporate autonomy rather than legislative mandates.

resolution: The European Parliament raised deep concerns over recurring fatal factory fires in South Asia, notably the 2012 Tazreen factory fire in Bangladesh (112 deaths) and Karachi blaze in Pakistan (289 deaths), alongside an estimated 600 garment worker deaths in Bangladesh since 2005 due to preventable safety failures. It highlighted poor labor conditions, including non-compliance with ILO conventions on occupational safety, health, and labor rights, particularly in Bangladesh’s 5,000 textile factories employing 3.5 million workers, which supply 75% of the country’s exports—primarily to the EU, the largest market for Bangladeshi apparel. The resolution urged Bangladesh and Pakistan to enforce health and safety laws, establish independent labor inspections, and prosecute negligence, while welcoming the Bangladesh Fire and Building Safety Agreement to improve standards via worker-involved committees and inspections funded by multinational retailers. It called on EU companies to ensure supply chain compliance with labor standards, support victim compensation, and adopt mandatory responsible business conduct, including a voluntary labeling system certifying ILO core standards. The Parliament also stressed the need to combat corruption in safety inspections, address restrictions on trade unions, investigate the unsolved murder of labor activist Aminul Islam, and expand EU initiatives like the ‘Promotion of Labour Standards in the RMG sector’ project. It emphasized ratifying ILO conventions C-155 and C-187, reducing child labor, and training EU trade officers on corporate social responsibility aligned with the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights.

title: Recommendation Alojz Peterle-Conclusion of a Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the EC and the Republic of Tajikistan: RECOMMENDATION on the proposal for a Council and Commission decision on the conclusion of a Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Tajikistan, of the other part
background: Tajikistan, a post-Soviet Central Asian state bordering Afghanistan, faces economic challenges and strategic importance due to drug trafficking routes. The EU’s 2007 Central Asia strategy and outdated 1989 trade agreement with Tajikistan prompted negotiations for a modernized framework. The Parliament will discuss concluding a Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to enhance political, economic, and security cooperation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement as a strategic tool to bolster democratic reforms and economic stability in Tajikistan, aligning with their commitment to EU engagement in Central Asia.  
EPP applauds the balanced approach recognizing Tajikistan’s progress in governance while urging enhanced focus on anti-corruption frameworks and human rights monitoring during implementation.  
EPP emphasizes the agreement’s role in countering regional security threats, particularly drug trafficking from Afghanistan, through structured EU-Tajikistan counter-narcotics cooperation.  
EPP proposes reinforcing references to the Millennium Development Goals in trade provisions to address food insecurity, ensuring alignment with Tajikistan’s poverty reduction priorities.  
EPP endorses the issue’s emphasis on cultural partnership over paternalism, reflecting their principle of mutual respect for Tajikistan’s historical trade traditions and regional influence.

GUE_NGL rejects the agreement’s integration with Frontex operations and readmission frameworks, which institutionalize border militarization contrary to refugee protection obligations under international law.  
GUE_NGL opposes the externalization of EU migration controls through Tajik-Afghan border securitization, fundamentally challengeing with Geneva Convention guarantees against refoulement and humane asylum practices.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s implicit militarization of Central Asia, inconsistent with their anti-imperialist principle rejecting EU military projection beyond its borders.  
GUE_NGL disputes the extractive economic model promoted by the agreement, which overlooks equitable resource-sharing mechanisms critical to Tajikistan’s sovereign development.  
GUE_NGL rejects the proposal’s alignment with “fortress Europe” policies, failing to address root causes of displacement through poverty alleviation or conflict issue frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its assent to the conclusion of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities, their Member States, and Tajikistan, which aims to strengthen bilateral relations across political, trade, economic, and legal domains. The resolution endorsed the agreement based on legal frameworks including the EC Treaty, Euratom Treaty, and provisions related to external cooperation, emphasizing adherence to democratic principles, human rights, and the rule of law. It formally approved the agreement’s ratification, underscoring its role in fostering dialogue and regional stability, and mandated the Parliament’s President to transmit the decision to the EU Council, Commission, member states, and Tajikistan’s government and parliament to finalize the process.

title: The EU as a global actor: its role in multilateral organisations: REPORT on the EU as a global actor: its role in multilateral organisations
background: The EU's expanded legal capacity under the Lisbon Treaty coincided with global challenges requiring multilateral cooperation, including financial instability, climate change, and shifting geopolitical power balances. Fragmented EU representation in international organizations highlighted coordination difficulties amid evolving global governance structures. The Parliament will discuss enhancing the EU's strategic role and institutional coherence within multilateral frameworks.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects fundamentally the issue’s push for consolidated EU seats in multilateral bodies, as this undermines national sovereignty and contradicts EFD’s principle that "structures are not created twice over" (Terho), preferring intergovernmental cooperation over supranational integration.  
EFD opposes the EU’s supranational foreign policy ambitions, citing the Libyan no-fly zone as evidence that "supranational bodies merely fiddle" while nation-states act (Bannerman), directly conflicting with the issue’s emphasis on EU coherence in security matters.  
EFD disputes the issue’s assumption of EU effectiveness in multilateral diplomacy, noting failures to enforce Quartet principles in Palestinian statehood efforts (Belder) and inadequate pressure on Egypt to protect minorities (Provera), which "absolutely challenges with EFD’s position" on accountability.  
EFD challenges the issue’s call for Schengen reform, arguing that immigration policy must prioritize national social stability over EU-level solidarity, aligning with Salavrakos’ demand to amend Dublin II rather than expand supranational control.  
EFD dismisses the issue’s focus on EU institutional reforms, highlighting unresolved territorial disputes like Cyprus (Paška) as proof that the EU cannot credibly lead global governance while failing to address internal conflicts.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the issue's emphasis on unified EU diplomacy and institutional reform, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to supranational governance and conflict prevention through multilateral engagement.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing transparency by requiring public disclosure of member states blocking consolidated EU positions (e.g., Syria sanctions) to strengthen accountability without opposing the issue’s coherence goals.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call for rationalized representation in IMF/World Bank governance, effectively advancing their priority of leveraging EU economic weight for progressive global economic policies.  
GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the issue’s human rights focus, particularly urging accession to the European Convention on Human Rights, which matches their manifesto demands for accountability in external action.  
GREEN_EFA approves the push for EEAS leadership in multilateral forums but suggests mandating independent impact assessments for CSDP missions to evaluate human rights and gender effects, enhancing the issue’s conflict-prevention framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for enhanced EU coherence and leadership in global governance, emphasizing the EU’s commitment to effective multilateralism under the Lisbon Treaty, which provides legal personality, the VP/HR role, and the EEAS to strengthen external action. It highlighted the EU’s financial contributions to the UN (over one-third of the regular budget, two-fifths of peace operations, and half of UN funds/programs) and stressed the urgency of reforming fragmented representation in multilateral bodies, particularly where shared or exclusive EU competences exist (e.g., trade, climate, security). The resolution called for consolidating EU Member States’ positions into single EU seats in the IMF (noting EU states hold over 30% of IMF votes) and World Bank, proposing a euro-area constituency and full ECB/Commission observer status in IMF governance. It urged UN Security Council reform, including a long-term goal of an EU seat, improved coordination among EU members on UNSC decisions, and enhanced EU roles in the UN Human Rights Council and General Assembly. The EU was urged to leverage its economic weight in G20/G8 fora, ensure NATO-EU strategic partnerships with shared crisis management, and strengthen cooperation with OSCE and Council of Europe, including EU accession to the European Convention on Human Rights. The resolution emphasized addressing global challenges (climate, poverty, security) through unified EU diplomacy, rationalizing representation to reduce costs, and adopting a 2020-focused White Paper on multilateral strategy, while prioritizing democracy, human rights, and accountability in external action.

title: Situation in Nigeria: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the situation in Nigeria
background: Escalating violence by Boko Haram since 2009, including attacks on civilians and infrastructure, prompted a 2013 state of emergency in northeastern Nigeria. Government counterterrorism operations raised human rights concerns, while legislative moves to criminalize same-sex relationships and resume executions after a moratorium intensified scrutiny. The Parliament will discuss Nigeria’s human rights and security situation.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue’s failure to prioritize immediate protection for Nigeria’s Christian minorities facing systematic violence, conflicting with EPP’s principle of religious freedom.  
EPP opposes the issue’s inadequate condemnation of state-sponsored human rights abuses, which neglects EPP’s demand for strict adherence to international law in counterterrorism.  
EPP completely challenges with the issue’s silence on EU aid accountability, overlooking EPP’s insistence on tying €700 million in funding to verifiable anti-corruption reforms.  
EPP condemns the issue’s weak emphasis on interreligious dialogue as a solution, diverging from EPP’s model of faith-based reconciliation exemplified in Kosovo.

EFD rejects the issue’s emphasis on external human rights conditionality, viewing it as an infringement on Nigeria’s sovereignty to address internal conflicts through culturally appropriate mechanisms.  
EFD opposes the issue’s condemnation of Nigeria’s Same-Gender Marriage Prohibition Bill, asserting that national legislation must reflect domestic societal norms without external interference.  
EFD criticizes the issue’s focus on military accountability while inadequately prioritizing climate-induced displacement and resource competition as primary drivers of violence, despite their critical role in destabilizing the region.  
EFD objects to leveraging EU aid under the Cotonou Agreement as coercive pressure, arguing this undermines Nigeria’s autonomy in balancing security imperatives with civilian protections.  
EFD highlights the issue’s failure to center religious and ethnic dialogue as the cornerstone of conflict issue, which aligns with their call for locally led reconciliation over externally imposed measures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over escalating violence in Nigeria, particularly condemning Boko Haram’s terrorist activities responsible for over 4,000 deaths since 2009, including 700 fatalities in 2013 alone, and its links to regional extremist groups like AQIM. It criticized the Nigerian military’s disproportionate use of force, extrajudicial executions, and human rights violations during counterterrorism operations, notably in the April 2013 Baga clashes that destroyed thousands of homes and killed hundreds of civilians. The resolution condemned the Same-Gender Marriage Prohibition Bill, which criminalizes same-sex relationships with up to 14-year sentences, urging Nigeria’s president to reject it and decriminalize homosexuality. It highlighted the humanitarian crisis, including 19,000 displaced farmers, 6,000 refugees fleeing to Niger, and 3,000 to Cameroon, exacerbating regional food insecurity. The Parliament urged Nigeria to uphold human rights, end the death penalty (noting 56 death sentences in 2012 and 1,000 on death row), and comply with international law, including the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. It called for independent investigations into abuses, regional cooperation against terrorism and piracy, and addressing root causes like economic inequality, resource disputes, and climate change. The EU, Nigeria’s largest donor with €700 million in aid (2008–2013), was urged to leverage political dialogue under the Cotonou Agreement to promote accountability, human rights, and sustainable development, threatening restrictive measures for non-compliance.
