resolution: The European Parliament raised the strategic importance of EU enlargement to the Western Balkans as a key policy for fostering peace, stability, and shared values, emphasizing the detrimental impact of repeated delays in opening accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania despite their reform progress, notably the 2018 Prespa Agreement resolving Greece-North Macedonia disputes. It stressed the urgency of restoring EU credibility by starting negotiations, aligning with Commission recommendations, and avoiding further erosion of trust amid rising populism and external interference. The resolution called for a merit-based, predictable accession process prioritizing rule of law, judiciary reforms, anti-corruption measures, and fundamental rights, including media freedom and minority protections, while integrating environmental standards under the European Green Deal and Paris Agreement. It urged visa liberalization for Kosovo, accelerated talks for Montenegro and Serbia, and enhanced regional cooperation through economic integration, connectivity projects, and youth programs like Erasmus+. The Parliament highlighted the EU’s role as the region’s top investor (€12.7 billion FDI 2014–2018) and donor, advocating increased pre-accession funding, alignment with the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA III), and support for civil society, democratic institutions, and resilience against disinformation and hybrid threats. It underscored the need for resolving bilateral disputes, addressing war crimes legacies, and ensuring compliance with international rulings, while promoting socio-economic convergence, gender equality, and measures to counter brain drain through education and job creation. The resolution also linked enlargement to the EU’s geopolitical interests, urging coherence with the Conference on the Future of Europe and stronger alignment with CFSP to counter destabilizing external influences.

title: Eritrea, the case of Dawitt Isaak: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Eritrea, notably the case of Dawit Isaak | RC-B9-0312/2020 | European Parliament
background: Eritrea's prolonged arbitrary detention of journalist Dawit Isaak since 2001 without trial, systemic human rights violations including indefinite national service, suppression of independent media, and documented UN reports on inhumane prison conditions preceded EU engagement. The Parliament will discuss Eritrea's human rights record and EU policy responses.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA entirely approves the issue’s unequivocal demand for Dawit Isaak’s immediate release, perfectly aligning with their decades-long advocacy for press freedom and political prisoner rights.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the condemnation of Eritrea’s indefinite national service system, emphasizing its classification as modern slavery and its disproportionate harm to women and girls.  
GREEN_EFA entirely approves the call for strict EU aid conditionality, proposing strengthened monitoring mechanisms to prevent misuse of development funds by Eritrea’s authoritarian regime.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly supports the issue’s demand for proof of life verification, echoing Michèle Rivasi’s urgent appeal to expose the inhumane conditions in Eritrea’s secret detention facilities.  
GREEN_EFA entirely approves the push for a global Magnitsky-style sanctions regime, aligning with their commitment to combat impunity for human rights violators through targeted accountability measures.

ID supports the issue’s condemnation of Eritrea’s indefinite national service and press censorship, aligning with ID’s stance against modern slavery and media suppression.  
ID advises amending the issue to explicitly prohibit EU infrastructure funding that could enable forced labor, ensuring development aid does not indirectly support government repression.  
ID suggests enhancing EU diplomatic efforts to include public pressure and multilateral engagement, moving beyond silent diplomacy to secure Dawit Isaak’s immediate release.  
ID highlights the necessity of strict enforcement of aid conditionality to prevent misuse, as outlined in the issue, to address systemic oppression in Eritrea.  
ID expresses concern over potential indirect EU complicity via infrastructure projects, urging amendments to mandate audits ensuring no funds enable human rights violations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over systematic human rights violations in Eritrea, including the arbitrary detention of EU citizen Dawit Isaak, a journalist imprisoned without trial since 2001 alongside 21 others following a media crackdown. It condemned Eritrea’s inhumane prison conditions, exacerbated by COVID-19, with detainees held in overcrowded facilities, shipping containers, and denied healthcare, food, and sanitation, risking malnutrition and disease. The resolution highlighted indefinite national service akin to slavery, affecting thousands, including women and girls subjected to abuse, and noted Eritrea’s ranking as the world’s most censored country (178th in press freedom) and 182nd in human development. It demanded immediate release of all political prisoners, proof of life for Dawit Isaak, and access to EU representatives, while urging Eritrea to implement its 1997 constitution, end forced labor, halt persecution of religious minorities, and allow independent media and civil society. The EU criticized Eritrea’s failure to uphold the Cotonou Agreement’s human rights obligations despite receiving €180 million in development aid (2019-2020) and called for strict aid conditionality to prevent government misuse. It further urged the African Union and UN to intensify pressure, condemned the extraterritorial 2% diaspora tax, and advocated for a global EU human rights sanctions mechanism (Magnitsky Act) to address impunity.

title: Escalating tensions in Varosha following the illegal actions by Turkey and the urgent need for the resumption of talks: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on escalating tensions in Varosha following the illegal actions by Turkey and the urgent need for the resumption of talks | RC-B9-0355/2020 | European Parliament
background: Turkey's 1974 military intervention in Cyprus resulted in Varosha's closure under UN Security Council resolutions; subsequent Turkish-backed initiatives to reopen sections of the area, amid Cyprus's division and Turkey's EU candidacy, prompted international concern. The Parliament will discuss Turkey's contested actions in Varosha and the urgency of resuming UN-mediated Cyprus settlement talks.

stances.stance:
SD entirely agrees the issue’s condemnation of Turkey’s unilateral actions in Varosha, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to upholding UN Security Council issues and international law.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands for Varosha’s return to lawful inhabitants under UN administration, echoing the urgent need to reverse demographic changes and military occupation.  
SD entirely agrees calls for renewed UN-led negotiations toward a bi-communal federation, reflecting SD’s decades-long advocacy for Cypriot reunification through dialogue.  
SD strongly accepts imposing targeted sanctions on Turkey unless it ceases destabilizing actions, aligning with SD’s stance on enforcing consequences for violations of EU principles.  
SD entirely agrees the issue’s recognition of Turkish Cypriot protests against Ankara’s interference, reinforcing SD’s dedication to grassroots reconciliation and anti-imperialist solidarity.

ECR slightly approves the issue’s condemnation of Turkish actions but demands amendments to replace "consider targeted sanctions" with mandatory measures such as freezing the EU-Turkey Customs Union for six months.  
ECR requests revisions to immediately terminate Turkey’s EU accession negotiations, citing Erdoğan’s neo-Ottoman aggression as fundamentally incompatible with European values.  
ECR criticizes the issue for failing to address EU complicity through continued payments for Turkish border control, proposing Article 7 be amended to halt all related funding.  
ECR supports Varosha’s return to lawful inhabitants but insists on binding timelines in UN negotiations, noting the issue’s lack of enforcement mechanisms conflicts with ECR’s demand for territorial integrity.  
ECR highlights the proposal’s omission of NATO’s failure to counter Turkish-Russian military cooperation, urging explicit condemnation of Turkey’s S-400 deployment against alliance security interests.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over Turkey’s illegal actions in Varosha, Cyprus, condemning its partial "opening" in October 2020 as a violation of UN Security Council Resolutions 550 (1984) and 789 (1992), which demand the area’s return to lawful inhabitants under UN administration. It emphasized that Turkey’s unilateral moves, including military occupation, demographic changes through settlements, and support for a two-state solution, undermine trust, entrench partition, and contravene international law. The resolution urged Turkey to reverse its decisions, withdraw troops, and transfer Varosha to UN control, stressing the need for a bi-communal, bi-zonal federation as the basis for reunification, aligned with UN parameters and the EU acquis. It called for renewed UN-led negotiations, referencing the 2017 Crans-Montana talks, and urged the EU to consider targeted sanctions if Turkey persists in destabilizing actions. The Parliament also highlighted protests by Turkish Cypriots against Ankara’s interference, supported EU aid programs fostering reconciliation, and condemned Turkish President Erdoğan’s provocative visit to Varosha in November 2020, which revealed plans for illegal settlement. Additionally, it criticized Turkey’s broader regional aggression, including unauthorized drilling in Cyprus’s waters and interventions in Libya, Syria, and Nagorno-Karabakh, urging de-escalation and adherence to international law to restore EU-Turkey relations.

title: Forced labour and the situation of the Uyghurs in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on forced labour and the situation of the Uyghurs in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region | RC-B9-0432/2020 | European Parliament
background: Reports of systemic forced labor, mass surveillance, arbitrary detention, and human rights violations against Uyghurs and other minorities in China's Xinjiang region, alongside concerns over global supply chains involving multinational companies, prompted international scrutiny. The Parliament will discuss forced labor practices and human rights conditions in Xinjiang amid EU-China relations.

stances.stance:
SD fundamentally sanctions the issue's demand for binding corporate due diligence laws to eradicate forced labor from EU supply chains, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to ethical trade practices and human rights-centered globalization.  

SD perfectly aligns with the call for immediate EU sanctions under the Global Human Rights Sanctions Regime against Chinese officials responsible for Xinjiang atrocities, reflecting SD's unwavering stance against crimes against humanity.  

SD fundamentally sanctions the issue's emphasis on suspending extradition treaties with China, amplifying SD's longstanding priority to protect vulnerable diaspora communities from transnational repression.  

SD perfectly aligns with the condemnation of Xinjiang's state-sponsored forced labor in cotton production, demanding urgent import bans on goods tainted by coercion to uphold SD's anti-exploitation trade principles.  

SD fundamentally sanctions leveraging EU-China investment negotiations to enforce human rights conditionality, aligning with SD's strategy to weaponize economic weight for systemic rights protections.

ID conditionally endorses the sanctions framework but demands amendments to prioritize bilateral dialogue channels over unilateral measures, aligning with ID's emphasis on pragmatic diplomacy.  
ID requests revision of Section 3 to include explicit exemptions for European industries reliant on Xinjiang cotton, advocating audit-based certification instead of broad import bans.  
ID calls for Article 6 modifications to mandate differentiation between Uyghur civilians and extremists in counterterrorism policies, reflecting nuanced security concerns.  
ID criticizes the issue’s dependency on UN investigations as inconsistent with ID’s sovereignty principles, proposing independent EU-led verification mechanisms.  
ID demands stricter penalties in Clause 8 for European corporations complicit in surveillance technology transfers, addressing gaps in corporate accountability cited in debate.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over systematic human rights violations in China, particularly targeting Uyghurs, Kazakhs, and other Muslim minorities in Xinjiang, including the arbitrary detention of over one million individuals in "re-education" camps, with 380 facilities built or expanded since 2017. It condemned state-sponsored forced labor programs involving at least 80,000 Uyghurs transferred to factories supplying global brands, and highlighted Xinjiang’s cotton sector—producing 20% of global cotton—as reliant on coerced labor, with 570,000 ethnic minorities mobilized for cotton-picking in 2018 alone. The resolution denounced pervasive surveillance technologies targeting Uyghurs, forced sterilizations (80% of China’s IUD placements in 2018 occurred in Xinjiang), and the destruction of religious sites, labeling these acts as potential crimes against humanity. It urged China to ratify key international conventions, including ILO Forced Labour Conventions and the ICCPR, and demanded unrestricted access for UN investigators to Xinjiang. The EU called for sanctions under its Global Human Rights Sanctions Regime against officials responsible for abuses, urged binding corporate due diligence laws to eliminate forced labor from supply chains, and advocated bans on imports linked to such practices. It also pressed for protection of Uyghur diaspora communities, suspension of extradition treaties with China, and coordinated international action to address human rights violations, emphasizing the need to prioritize human rights in EU-China relations and investment agreements.

title: Forced labour in the Linglong factory and environmental protests in Serbia: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on forced labour in the Linglong factory and environmental protests in Serbia | RC-B9-0600/2021 | European Parliament
background: Allegations of forced labor involving Vietnamese workers at a Chinese-owned factory in Serbia and widespread environmental protests against legislative changes enabling foreign mining projects emerged amid Serbia's EU accession process and increasing Chinese investments. The Parliament will discuss Serbia's compliance with EU labor, environmental, and human rights standards during membership negotiations.

stances.stance:
EPP totally sanctions the issue’s demand for immediate investigations into forced labor and human trafficking allegations at the Linglong factory, perfectly aligning with EPP’s unwavering commitment to human dignity and transnational labor rights enforcement.  
EPP totally sanctions the condemnation of environmental governance failures and police violence against protesters, advancing EPP’s priority to harmonize EU accession candidates with the Green Agenda’s zero-tolerance stance on ecological exploitation.  
EPP totally sanctions the call for Serbia to accelerate rule-of-law reforms and media freedom guarantees, reflecting EPP’s foundational principle that democratic institutions and anti-corruption measures are non-negotiable for EU integration.  
EPP totally sanctions the emphasis on transparent public debate around contentious legislation, resonating with EPP’s advocacy for participatory democracy and civil society empowerment across enlargement processes.  
EPP totally sanctions linking Serbia’s accession progress to tangible alignment with EU labor and environmental standards, perfectly aligning with EPP’s structured conditionality framework for candidate countries.

GUE_NGL partly promotes the issue's formal condemnation of forced labor but demands deletion of all clauses subordinating Serbian policy to EU geopolitical interests.  
GUE_NGL fundamentally disputes the issue’s instrumentalization of environmental protests to advance EU accession conditionality, which contradicts their anti-imperialist principles.  
GUE_NGL requests revisions to remove references aligning Serbia with EU labor standards, proposing instead binding UN/ILO mechanisms respecting national sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL rejects the selective critique of Chinese investments while ignoring EU member states’ environmental and labor rights violations across the Balkans.  
GUE_NGL calls for amendments prioritizing Serbian civil society’s autonomous demands over EU-monitored reforms, arguing the issue’s framework legitimizes neoliberal exploitation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over Serbia’s insufficient progress in upholding EU values, particularly regarding human rights, rule of law, media freedom, and environmental governance. It highlighted alleged forced labor, human trafficking, and exploitation of 500 Vietnamese workers at the Chinese-owned Linglong Tire factory, urging Serbian authorities to investigate, ensure labor rights compliance, and grant access to international monitors. The resolution criticized Serbia’s alignment with Chinese investments, including labor agreements conflicting with EU law, and environmental risks from projects like the Rio Tinto mine, which sparked widespread protests met with police violence and attacks by unidentified groups. It noted the withdrawal of the controversial Law on Land Expropriation and amendments to the Law on Referendums but stressed the need for transparent public debate. Media freedom deterioration, intimidation of journalists, and hate speech against opposition figures and civil society were condemned, alongside calls to protect NGOs and independent media. The Parliament urged Serbia to align with EU labor and environmental standards, tackle corruption, and accelerate reforms in rule of law and democratic institutions, emphasizing the opening of Cluster 4 (Green Agenda) in accession negotiations. It reiterated the expectation for Serbia to demonstrate unambiguous commitment to EU integration through visible, verifiable actions upholding fundamental rights and values.

title: 2019-2020 Reports on Kosovo: REPORT on the 2019-2020 Commission Reports on Kosovo | A9-0031/2021 | European Parliament
background: Kosovo’s EU integration efforts under the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (2016), visa liberalization benchmarks met since 2018, and post-pandemic recovery challenges prompted the European Commission’s 2019-2020 reports assessing reforms. The Parliament will discuss Kosovo’s progress toward EU accession, focusing on institutional reforms, regional cooperation, and compliance with EU criteria.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA completely advocates the issue's demand for immediate visa liberalization, which perfectly aligns with our commitment to fostering youth mobility and restoring EU credibility through fulfilled promises.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the emphasis on environmental reforms, particularly the call to phase out coal by 2050 and establish protected natural areas like the Vjosa Wild River National Park, advancing our Green Deal priorities.  
GREEN_EFA completely advocates the focus on minority rights inclusion for Roma, Ashkali, and Egyptian communities, reflecting our unwavering advocacy for equitable societal participation and anti-discrimination frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue’s condemnation of Serbia’s non-recognition campaign and its insistence on implementing dialogue agreements, resonating with our stance on regional reconciliation and justice for conflict-era crimes.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the prioritization of judicial independence and anti-corruption measures, which directly advance our long-term objectives of institutional accountability and rule-of-law strengthening in enlargement processes.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the issue’s approach to EU integration as it perpetuates the "Balkan virus" of imposed solutions inconsistent with genuine reconciliation.  
GUE_NGL opposes the emphasis on Kosovo’s independence recognition, which ignores the Prespa Agreement model of negotiated compromise central to their anti-nationalist principles.  
The proposal absolutely disapproves with GUE_NGL’s stance by legitimizing NATO’s 1999 intervention, a historical injustice contradicting peaceful conflict issue.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s failure to prioritize regional equality, mirroring past EU double standards that exacerbated ethnic tensions rather than healing them.  
The text overlooks critical aspects such as systemic EU complicity in Balkan militarization, incompatible with GUE_NGL’s commitment to demilitarized diplomacy.

resolution: The European Parliament raised Kosovo’s commitment to EU integration while urging accelerated reforms in rule of law, anti-corruption, judicial independence, and public administration. It stressed the need for full implementation of the EU-facilitated dialogue agreements with Serbia, including establishing the Association of Serb-majority municipalities, and condemned Serbia’s non-recognition campaign. The resolution highlighted Kosovo’s fulfillment of visa liberalization benchmarks since 2018 and called on the Council to adopt visa-free travel, citing prolonged delays as harmful to EU credibility. It noted the EU’s COVID-19 support of €3.3 billion for the Western Balkans, with Kosovo receiving €5 million for healthcare, €63 million for socio-economic recovery, and €100 million in macro-financial assistance. Concerns included political instability, weak judicial accountability, organized crime, and systemic corruption, alongside calls to address gender-based violence, minority rights (particularly for Roma, Ashkali, and Egyptian communities), and media freedom. The resolution urged alignment with the EU Green Deal, phasing out coal by 2050, closing the Kosovo A power plant, and improving environmental standards. It emphasized economic reforms to reduce the shadow economy, enhance labor market inclusion, and leverage the €602.1 million IPA II funds (2014–2020), while advocating for Kosovo’s inclusion in EU vaccine procurement. The Parliament reiterated support for Kosovo’s independence, urging non-recognizing EU states to acknowledge it, and stressed regional cooperation, reconciliation, and justice for war crimes, including resolving cases of missing persons from the 1998–1999 conflict.

title: 2019-2020 Reports on Montenegro: REPORT on the 2019-2020 Commission Reports on Montenegro | A9-0131/2021 | European Parliament
background: Montenegro, an EU candidate since 2010, advanced accession negotiations post-2012, joined NATO in 2017, and underwent its first democratic transition following 2020 elections. Challenges included judicial reforms, media freedom, corruption, COVID-19 economic impacts, and Chinese infrastructure loans. The Parliament will discuss Montenegro’s EU membership progress, focusing on reform implementation and external influences.

stances.stance:
SD completely accepts the issue’s emphasis on accelerating judicial reforms and media freedom, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to democratic governance and rule of law in EU accession processes.  
SD completely accepts the call to strengthen Montenegro’s anti-corruption frameworks, highlighting the issue’s alignment with SD’s priority of combating high-level graft through independent oversight mechanisms.  
SD completely accepts the focus on inclusive COVID-19 recovery measures, particularly vaccine equity via COVAX, as this advances SD’s principles of social solidarity and health justice for vulnerable groups.  
SD completely accepts the issue’s condemnation of foreign interference and disinformation, aligning with SD’s stance on safeguarding Montenegro’s sovereignty through enhanced EU support against external threats.  
SD completely accepts the environmental priorities, including renewable energy targets and biodiversity protection, as these mirror SD’s climate agenda for sustainable Western Balkan integration.

ID partly supports Montenegro’s provisional chapter closures but demands immediate termination of its citizenship-by-investment program, which directly contradicts the issue’s anti-corruption and transparency objectives.  
ID opposes the Chinese-backed highway project as fundamentally inconsistent with EU environmental standards cited in the issue, citing irreversible ecological harm to the Tara River basin.  
ID rejects Montenegro’s reliance on non-EU macro-financial aid, arguing this undermines the credibility of accession negotiations outlined in Articles 1–3 on economic governance.  
The issue overlooks Montenegro’s geopolitical alignment with China’s Belt and Road Initiative, which conflicts with ID’s stance against foreign interference in EU enlargement processes.  
ID requests revisions to Chapter 23 provisions to explicitly ban third-country infrastructure loans exceeding EU debt sustainability thresholds, addressing vulnerabilities highlighted in the issue.

resolution: The European Parliament raised Montenegro’s progress in EU accession negotiations, noting it has opened all 33 screened chapters and provisionally closed three, while urging accelerated reforms in rule of law, judiciary independence, media freedom, and anti-corruption efforts. It highlighted Montenegro’s receipt of €504.9 million in pre-accession assistance (2007–2020), €53 million in COVID-19 relief, and €60 million in macro-financial aid, alongside €804 million in EIB loans since 1999. The resolution welcomed the peaceful 2020 parliamentary elections, which saw a democratic transition, but expressed concern over external interference and polarization. It stressed the need for judicial reforms, addressing high-level corruption, and protecting minorities, including Roma and Egyptians, while condemning attacks on journalists and urging investigations into unsolved cases. Montenegro’s alignment with EU foreign policy, NATO membership, and regional cooperation were commended, though concerns were raised over public debt vulnerabilities and foreign influence. The Parliament emphasized Montenegro’s economic challenges, including a 14.3% GDP decline in 2020, high unemployment, and the need for sustainable recovery via the EU’s €70 million vaccine support (including 248,800 COVAX doses) and the Economic and Investment Plan. Environmental priorities included renewable energy targets, phasing out coal plants like Pljevlja, protecting biodiversity, and combating illegal logging, while ensuring infrastructure projects align with EU ecological standards. Gender equality, LGBTI rights progress, and implementation of the Istanbul Convention were urged, alongside calls for inclusive COVID-19 recovery measures for vulnerable groups.

title: 2019-2020 Reports on North Macedonia: REPORT on the 2019-2020 Commission Reports on North Macedonia | A9-0040/2021 | European Parliament
background: North Macedonia's EU candidacy since 2005, 2018 Prespa Agreement resolving the name dispute with Greece, 2020 NATO accession, and March 2020 European Council approval for accession negotiations established its reform trajectory. Challenges included delayed negotiations, bilateral disputes with Bulgaria, rule of law reforms, and COVID-19 economic impacts. The Parliament will discuss progress and challenges in North Macedonia's EU accession process.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA fully accepts the issue’s urgent call to commence EU accession negotiations with North Macedonia, perfectly aligning with the party’s unwavering advocacy for honoring enlargement commitments to reward democratic reforms.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the emphasis on leveraging the €1.7 billion Economic and Investment Plan, proposing to amplify green transition projects akin to the Vjosa River conservation model to bolster biodiversity and sustainable infrastructure.  
GREEN_EFA fully accepts safeguarding media freedom and minority rights, urging enhanced protections for LGBTIQ communities and Roma populations through targeted EU-funded inclusion programs.  
GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the issue’s condemnation of delays in accession talks, emphasizing that postponements contradict the EU’s obligation to recognize North Macedonia’s historic Prespa Agreement and judicial reforms.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening civil society’s role in monitoring anti-corruption measures and public administration modernization to ensure transparency aligns with the party’s governance principles.

ID rejects the issue's endorsement of EU enlargement to the Western Balkans as completely condemning with ID's principles of national sovereignty and border integrity.  
ID opposes the proposal to accelerate North Macedonia's accession negotiations, citing unresolved corruption and organized crime networks that directly contradict EU rule-of-law prerequisites.  
ID condemns the issue's silence on Turkey's expanding influence through Balkan proxies like Albania and Kosovo, which undermines European security architectures.  
ID challenges the financial incentives for reforms, arguing that €1.7 billion in EU recovery funds reward systemic deficiencies rather than addressing brain drain and energy poverty.  
ID disputes the prioritization of NATO-aligned geopolitical goals over domestic EU stability, warning that Balkan integration replicates past enlargement failures that eroded public trust.

resolution: The European Parliament raised strong support for North Macedonia’s EU accession process, urging EU member states to promptly approve the negotiating framework and hold the first intergovernmental conference to start formal negotiations, emphasizing the country’s sustained reforms in rule of law, judiciary, anti-corruption, and public administration. It highlighted North Macedonia’s progress in resolving bilateral disputes through landmark agreements like the 2018 Prespa Agreement with Greece and the 2017 Treaty on Good Neighbourly Relations with Bulgaria, which bolstered regional stability. The resolution noted the EU’s substantial financial support, including over €1.25 billion in pre-accession funds since 2007, €66 million for COVID-19 health needs, €160 million in macro-financial assistance, and a regional pandemic package of €3.3 billion for the Western Balkans. It called for intensified efforts to combat organized crime, corruption, and hate speech, while safeguarding media freedom, minority rights, and gender equality. The Parliament stressed the need for economic recovery post-pandemic, leveraging the EU’s €1.7 billion Economic and Investment Plan for green transition, energy diversification, and infrastructure connectivity. Concerns were raised over delays in accession talks, which risk undermining EU credibility and regional stability, and member states were urged to avoid politicizing bilateral disputes. The resolution also emphasized alignment with EU foreign policy, NATO integration, and regional cooperation, while urging North Macedonia to address judicial independence, electoral reforms, and socio-economic challenges, including brain drain and energy poverty, to meet accession criteria comprehensively.

title: 2021 Report on Albania: REPORT on the 2021 Commission Report on Albania | A9-0131/2022 | European Parliament
background: Albania, an EU candidate since 2014, pursued judicial reforms, aligned with EU foreign policy, and addressed corruption and organized crime while advancing regional cooperation. The 2021 Commission Report assessed progress under the Stabilisation and Association Agreement and Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance. The Parliament will discuss Albania's EU accession process and reform implementation.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA firmly endorses the issue’s call for immediate EU accession negotiations, perfectly aligning with its commitment to regional stability and countering malign geopolitical influences.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the emphasis on irreversible judicial reforms and anti-corruption measures, recognizing Albania’s progress while urging sustained momentum to address media freedom and political plurality as critical enhancement opportunities.  
GREEN_EFA firmly endorses the environmental priorities, particularly the protection of the Vjosa River, and stresses that green transitions must remain central to Albania’s EU alignment, including scrutiny of infrastructure projects like Vlora airport.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the condemnation of external vetoes on accession talks, viewing Bulgaria’s blockade as incompatible with EU solidarity and regional security imperatives.  
GREEN_EFA firmly endorses the issue’s linkage of IPA III funding to tangible reforms, reflecting its principle that EU integration must be rooted in rule of law and civil society empowerment.

ID slightly supports the focus on judicial reforms but requests revisions to limit supranational oversight, inconsistent with the Venice Commission's role in constitutional matters.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of national sovereignty by prioritizing minority rights frameworks that conflict with ID's emphasis on traditional cultural identity.  
ID opposes the issue's linkage of EU funds to LGBTI+ protections, arguing it imposes non-essential social criteria beyond core accession benchmarks.  
The environmental mandates for the Vjosa River National Park completely oppose with ID's principle of national autonomy over strategic infrastructure and energy projects.  
ID demands amendments to media freedom clauses, asserting they risk destabilizing Albania's efforts to combat foreign disinformation through stricter regulatory controls.

resolution: The European Parliament raised strong support for Albania’s EU accession process, reiterating its European future and urging the Council to promptly open accession negotiations, given Albania’s fulfillment of reform conditions since becoming a candidate in 2014. It highlighted Albania’s progress in judicial reforms, including the vetting process for judges and prosecutors (extended until 2024), restoration of Constitutional and High Court functionality, and efforts against organized crime, while stressing the need to address corruption (noting a 27-place decline in Transparency International’s Corruption Perception Index since 2016), improve media freedom (with concerns over declining press freedom rankings), and protect minority rights, including LGBTI+ communities. The resolution emphasized the necessity of irreversible reforms in rule of law, governance, and electoral integrity, aligning with OSCE/ODIHR and Venice Commission recommendations, and called for enhanced civil society engagement, transparency in public spending, and measures to counter disinformation and foreign interference. It acknowledged EU financial support, including €1.24 billion in pre-accession funds since 2007 and €3.3 billion for COVID-19 recovery, while urging alignment with EU environmental standards, including establishing the Vjosa River as a National Park and advancing green energy transitions. The Parliament commended Albania’s foreign policy alignment with EU sanctions against Russia, its role in regional stability, and NATO cooperation, while stressing the geopolitical urgency of advancing accession to counter malign influences. Socioeconomic priorities included addressing poverty, improving education (2.7% of GDP allocated in 2021), gender equality, and youth empowerment, alongside infrastructure projects under the EU’s €3.2 billion Economic and Investment Plan for the Western Balkans. The resolution underscored conditionality in IPA III funding, linking financial support to tangible progress in rule of law and fundamental rights.

title: 2021 Report on North Macedonia: REPORT on the 2021 Commission Report on North Macedonia | A9-0133/2022 | European Parliament
background: North Macedonia, an EU candidate since 2005, has pursued reforms and signed agreements addressing historical disputes with Greece (2018) and Bulgaria (2017), while aligning with EU foreign policy. Delays in accession negotiations persist despite progress, amid regional stability concerns and geopolitical shifts. The Parliament will discuss North Macedonia’s EU integration process and related bilateral challenges.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue’s emphasis on accelerating North Macedonia’s EU accession as vital to countering Russian influence and upholding democratic values in the Western Balkans, aligning with their commitment to geostrategic stability.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the recognition of judicial reforms and anti-corruption progress as fully consistent with their manifesto priorities on rule of law and accountable governance.  
GREEN_EFA urges enhanced parliamentary oversight in IPA III funding implementation to ensure civil society’s direct role in monitoring anti-corruption measures, strengthening the issue’s conditionality framework.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need to accelerate accession timelines as an urgent enhancement opportunity, proposing quarterly progress reviews to prevent further erosion of public trust in EU commitments.  
GREEN_EFA entirely upholds the environmental targets and Green Agenda alignment, stressing this mirrors their climate justice priorities while addressing energy diversification needs.

ID slightly sanctions the issue’s regional stability goals but requests revisions to address unresolved economic risks from low-wage competition, which threaten EU industries like textiles through existing trade agreements.  
The proposal overlooks critical security vulnerabilities posed by visa exemptions facilitating radical Islamist movements and returning jihadists, inconsistent with ID’s emphasis on stringent border controls.  
ID opposes accelerated accession timelines due to unresolved ethnic and religious dissensions, which contradict EU stability prerequisites and risk importing internal fragmentation.  
The issue fundamentally challenges with ID’s economic sovereignty principles by failing to mandate renegotiation of trade terms to prevent market distortions from North Macedonia’s wage disparities.  
ID highlights the omission of concrete counterterrorism measures in the issue, particularly regarding North Macedonia’s radicalization challenges, as irreconcilable with EU security integration standards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised strong support for North Macedonia’s EU integration, emphasizing its fulfillment of accession criteria since becoming a candidate in 2005 and the Council’s 2020 decision to open negotiations, while regretting further delays despite sustained reforms. It commended progress in rule of law, judicial independence, anti-corruption efforts, and alignment with EU foreign policy, including 100% adherence to sanctions against Russia. The resolution highlighted landmark agreements like the 2018 Prespa Agreement with Greece and the 2017 Treaty with Bulgaria as vital for regional stability, urging both countries to resolve bilateral disputes swiftly to avoid obstructing accession. It stressed the need for reforms in media freedom, civil society engagement, gender equality, minority rights (including Roma and LGBTI+ communities), and measures to counter hate speech, disinformation, and foreign interference. Socioeconomic challenges, including post-COVID recovery, youth unemployment, and energy diversification, were addressed, alongside environmental goals such as reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 82% by 2030 and aligning with the EU Green Agenda. The Parliament urged accelerated regional cooperation, infrastructure development, and implementation of the Economic and Investment Plan for the Western Balkans, while calling for strict conditionality in EU funding under IPA III to ensure rule of law and anti-corruption progress. It reiterated the geostrategic importance of integrating North Macedonia to bolster EU credibility, stability, and resilience against external threats, particularly in light of Russia’s aggression against Ukraine.

title: 5th anniversary of the Peace Agreement in Colombia: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the fifth anniversary of the Peace Agreement in Colombia | RC-B9-0227/2021 | European Parliament
background: The 2016 Colombian Peace Agreement ended a 50-year conflict, facing implementation challenges, persistent violence against social leaders and ex-combatants, and security threats from armed groups. Colombia hosts over 1.8 million Venezuelan migrants, straining resources. The Parliament will discuss the agreement's fifth anniversary, implementation progress, and regional stability implications.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA entirely accepts the issue's recognition of Colombia's Peace Agreement as a global model for addressing root conflict causes, perfectly aligning with their commitment to transformative peacebuilding that prioritizes victims' rights and environmental justice.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the explicit call to enhance protection for human rights defenders, environmental activists, and indigenous leaders, which directly mirrors their manifesto pledge to shield frontline communities from extractivist and paramilitary violence.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that the issue’s demand for accelerated socio-economic reforms—particularly the Rural Reform and PDET programs—resonates with their core principle that territorial equity is indispensable to dismantling structural inequalities fueling conflict.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the gender-sensitive measures in the issue as critical to honoring women’s agency in peace processes, reflecting their decades-long advocacy for feminist foreign policy frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the condemnation of ELN violence and illicit economies, aligning with their unwavering rejection of armed conflict as a political tool and insistence on dialogue-based solutions.

GUE_NGL entirely conflicts the issue's failure to condemn the Colombian government's systematic sabotage of the Peace Agreement, directly contradicting their anti-imperialist stance against state-backed violence.  
GUE_NGL rejects the issue's distortion of truth by falsely accusing ex-combatants of withholding drug trafficking routes, a narrative that aligns with uribismo's paramilitary agenda rather than verified UN reports.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's omission of binding mechanisms to hold European transnational corporations accountable for human rights violations in conflict zones like Buenaventura's port.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's complicity in state impunity by not demanding concrete sanctions against Duque's administration for 1,000+ assassinations of social leaders since 2016.  
GUE_NGL rejects the issue's inadequate pressure for comprehensive agrarian reform, which leaves intact the structural inequalities fueling violence as documented in PDET municipalities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised strong support for Colombia’s 2016 Peace Agreement, emphasizing its global significance as a model for addressing root conflict causes and prioritizing victims' rights. It acknowledged progress, including the reintegration of nearly 14,000 former FARC combatants, the establishment of the Special Jurisdiction for Peace (JEP) to address war crimes, and rural development initiatives like the Development Plans with a Territorial Approach (PDET) in 170 conflict-affected municipalities. However, it condemned persistent violence, citing 248 ex-combatants killed since 2016, 120 human rights defenders murdered in 2020 (53 verified), and 269 civilian deaths in 69 incidents. The resolution urged enhanced security, protection for vulnerable groups, and full implementation of the Agreement, particularly socio-economic reforms and gender-sensitive measures. It praised Colombia’s decision to grant Temporary Protection Status to 1.8 million Venezuelan migrants, improving access to healthcare and education, while calling for international support. The EU pledged continued financial assistance, including the EUR 128 million EU Trust Fund for Colombia, and stressed synergies between trade agreements and peacebuilding. It condemned the ELN’s violence and urged dissident groups to abandon armed struggle, reiterating the need for democratic dialogue and structural reforms to combat inequality, poverty, and illicit economies.

title: Recommendation to the VPC/HR and to the Council in preparation of the 2020 Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons Treaty (NPT) review process, nuclear arms control and nuclear disarmament options: REPORT on a European Parliament recommendation to the Council and the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy concerning the preparation of the 2020 Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons Treaty (NPT) review process, nuclear arms control and nuclear disarmament options | A9-0020/2020 | European Parliament
background: The 2020 NPT Review Conference faced challenges from the INF Treaty's collapse, US-Iran JCPOA tensions, stalled New START extension, and nuclear arsenal modernization. Geopolitical instability, emerging technologies, and non-proliferation compliance concerns heightened risks. The Parliament will discuss EU strategies for advancing nuclear arms control and disarmament within the NPT framework.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA fundamentally promotes the issue's emphasis on extending the New START Treaty and initiating broader disarmament agreements, perfectly aligning with their foundational principle that nuclear deterrence architectures must be systematically dismantled.  

GREEN_EFA fundamentally promotes the condemnation of Iran’s ballistic missile program and North Korea’s nuclear activities, positions that perfectly reflect their 2019 manifesto commitment to confront proliferation risks through sanctions-backed diplomatic channels.  

GREEN_EFA fundamentally promotes the proposed €1.3 million allocation for NPT Review Conference preparations, recognizing this funding as critical to operationalizing their long-standing demand for verifiable multilateral disarmament frameworks.  

GREEN_EFA fundamentally promotes the call for universalizing the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty, viewing this as a direct implementation of their 2021 issue advocating for irreversible progress in eliminating nuclear testing infrastructure.  

GREEN_EFA fundamentally promotes the cybersecurity provisions to prevent nuclear escalation, perfectly aligning with their Digital Security Act amendments proposing tech-driven safeguards against accidental or malicious weapon deployment.

ID slightly approves the NPT review process provisions but demands explicit recognition of member states' sovereign rights to maintain independent nuclear deterrents without EU oversight.  
ID opposes any indirect legitimization of the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons through issue-linked initiatives, asserting it undermines France’s strategic autonomy.  
ID requests amendments to reallocate €2.86 million earmarked for Middle East WMD-free zones toward countering immediate threats like Turkish regional expansionism and Islamist terrorism.  
ID insists the issue prioritize "arsenalisation" of space and emerging cybersecurity risks over theoretical disarmament timelines inconsistent with current geopolitical realities.  
 ID warns against conflating IAEA verification mandates with intrusive transparency measures that could compromise national defense architectures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the deteriorating global nuclear disarmament landscape, emphasizing the critical role of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) as the cornerstone of non-proliferation, disarmament, and peaceful nuclear energy use. It highlighted challenges including the collapse of the INF Treaty due to Russia’s deployment of SSC-8 missiles, Iran’s violations of the JCPOA, North Korea’s ongoing nuclear activities, and the risk of a new arms race fueled by modernization of arsenals and lowered thresholds for nuclear use. The resolution urged the US and Russia to extend the New START Treaty (limiting deployed warheads to 1,550) before its 2021 expiration and negotiate a broader agreement covering non-strategic weapons, while encouraging China’s inclusion. It called for multilateral dialogue to replace the INF Treaty, supported EU funding of €1.3 million for 2020 NPT Review Conference activities and €2.86 million for Middle East WMD-free zone initiatives, and stressed the need for transparency, verification, and compliance with IAEA safeguards. The EU reaffirmed support for the JCPOA, condemned Iran’s ballistic missile program, and demanded North Korea’s denuclearization. It advocated for a "stepping-stone" approach to disarmament, cybersecurity measures to prevent nuclear escalation, and universalization of the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty. The resolution warned that failure to address these issues risks eroding the NPT regime, with over 14,000 nuclear warheads globally (90% held by the US and Russia) posing catastrophic humanitarian consequences if used.

title: Iran, in particular the case of 2012 Sakharov Prize laureate Nasrin Sotoudeh: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Iran, in particular the case of 2012 Sakharov Prize Laureate Nasrin Sotoudeh | RC-B9-0440/2020 | European Parliament
background: Iran's detention of human rights lawyer Nasrin Sotoudeh since 2018, her 33-year sentence, and targeting of activists, alongside executions like Ruhollah Zam (2020) and threats to Ahmadreza Djalali, reflect systemic human rights concerns including arbitrary arrests, unfair trials, and repression of dissent. The Parliament will discuss Iran's human rights situation and treatment of political prisoners.

stances.stance:
EPP completely agrees the issue's demand for Nasrin Sotoudeh’s immediate release, perfectly aligning with EPP’s unwavering commitment to defending Sakharov Prize laureates and prisoners facing health risks in Iran’s COVID-ravaged detention system.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the condemnation of Iran’s execution practices, particularly the state murder of journalists and athletes, which directly violates EPP’s foundational principles of human dignity and freedom of expression.  
EPP completely agrees applying Magnitsky Act sanctions against Iranian officials, advancing EPP’s strategic priority to hold authoritarian regimes accountable through targeted measures while preserving diplomatic channels.  
EPP strongly upholds the call for a UN-led inquiry into Iran’s 2019 protest crackdown, recognizing this as critical to upholding EPP’s mandate to combat systemic violence against civilian populations.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on ending gender apartheid in Iran, reinforcing EPP’s decades-long advocacy for women’s rights and opposition to forced hijab laws.

ID slightly advocates the issue's condemnation of Iran's human rights abuses but requests revisions to explicitly link EU nuclear negotiations with Tehran to measurable improvements in releasing political prisoners like Nasrin Sotoudeh and Ahmadreza Djalali.  
ID demands amendments specifying concrete consequences for Iran's non-compliance with UN issues, including automatic suspension of diplomatic relations until the 1988 massacre inquiry is permitted.  
ID completely challenges the issue's silence on Europe's "naïve" P5+1 nuclear deal framework, insisting any future agreements must legally bind Iran to cease persecution of women and religious minorities.  
ID rejects the EU's current sanctions regime as insufficient, urging immediate Magnitsky sanctions against judiciary officials overseeing Nasrin Sotoudeh's case rather than generalized measures.  
 While endorsing calls to end mandatory hijab laws, ID contradicts the issue's multilateral approach by emphasizing unilateral EU actions to "combat assassins" rather than UN-led mechanisms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over Iran’s systematic human rights violations, condemning the arbitrary detention and sentencing of Nasrin Sotoudeh—a 2012 Sakharov Prize laureate—to 33 years in prison and 148 lashes for defending women protesting mandatory hijab laws, demanding her immediate release and access to healthcare. It denounced the executions of journalist Ruhollah Zam, hanged on espionage charges after being kidnapped from Iraq, and wrestler Navid Afkari, executed despite denying protest-related charges, as well as the imminent execution of Swedish-Iranian academic Ahmadreza Djalali, tortured and held on forced confessions. The resolution highlighted Iran’s violent crackdown on November 2019 protests, which killed over 300 people, and urged a UN-led inquiry into these abuses. It criticized Iran’s use of the death penalty, torture, unfair trials, and inhumane prison conditions, particularly targeting dual nationals like Fariba Adelkhah, denied consular access, and called for their unconditional release. The Parliament urged EU sanctions under the Magnitsky Act against officials responsible for repression, demanded Iran end discrimination against women, minorities, and LGBTI persons, and cease internet censorship and disinformation campaigns. It pressed Iran to cooperate with UN human rights mechanisms, ensure due process, and address systemic judicial corruption, while advocating enhanced EU support for human rights defenders and Sakharov Prize laureates at risk.

title: Iran, notably the situation of women's rights defenders and imprisoned EU dual nationals: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Iran, notably the situation of women’s rights defenders and imprisoned EU dual nationals | RC-B9-0089/2019 | European Parliament
background: Iranian authorities intensified crackdowns on women protesting compulsory hijab laws, detained EU-Iranian dual nationals under vague charges, and maintained discriminatory legal frameworks against women, amid ongoing EU sanctions for human rights violations. The Parliament will discuss human rights abuses targeting women activists and dual citizens in Iran.

stances.stance:
ID strongly advocates the issue’s condemnation of Iran’s systemic oppression of women, aligning with ID’s longstanding commitment to combatting religiously justified gender repression and defending secular freedoms.  
ID applauds the explicit denunciation of compulsory veiling as institutionalized subjugation, reinforcing ID’s stance that the veil symbolizes patriarchal control rather than cultural choice.  
ID proposes enhancing the issue by explicitly naming Sharia law as the legal framework enabling Iran’s abuses, ensuring coherence with ID’s broader rejection of religious law in governance.  
ID endorses the demand to release EU-Iranian dual nationals, urging stricter sanctions against Iranian officials responsible for their arbitrary detention and torture.  
ID emphasizes extending solidarity to Muslim women in Europe facing pressure to adopt veiling, urging parallel EU measures to counter cultural relativism that tolerates such impositions.

GUE_NGL supports the issue's condemnation of Iran's gender-based repression but advises amending Article 9 to explicitly denounce US-led sanctions crippling Iran's economy, which disproportionately harm women and children.  

GUE_NGL endorses demands to release activists like Nasrin Sotoudeh yet proposes modifying Clause 6 to urge EU states to lift unilateral sanctions, arguing they undermine dialogue and empower hardliners against reformers.  

GUE_NGL agrees compulsory veiling constitutes systemic discrimination but highlights the motion's omission of geopolitical context, suggesting adding "while rejecting all external economic warfare that destabilizes civil society progress."  

GUE_NGL advocates abolishing juvenile executions per the issue's stance but requests revising Paragraph 14 to specify opposition to all sanctions regimes, including EU asset freezes, that restrict medical imports for prisoners.  

GUE_NGL partially supports calls for fair trials while urging amendments to frame consular access disputes within broader US-EU sanctions noncompliance with UN Charter Article 41 requirements.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over Iran’s systematic human rights violations, particularly targeting women protesting compulsory veiling, with at least 32 arrests and 10 imprisonments since 2018, including harsh sentences of up to 24 years for activists like Mojgan Keshavarz, Yasaman Aryani, and Monireh Arabshahi. It condemned the persecution of women’s rights defenders, such as Nasrin Sotoudeh (sentenced to 38 years and 148 lashes) and Sahar Khodayari, who died by self-immolation after facing imprisonment for attending a football match. The resolution highlighted the arbitrary detention of EU-Iranian dual nationals, including Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe and Ahmadreza Djalali (sentenced to death), often on vague “national security” charges, and denounced Iran’s refusal to recognize dual citizenship, hindering consular access. It criticized inhumane prison conditions, denial of medical care, torture, and the use of Article 48 of Iran’s Criminal Procedure to restrict legal representation. The Parliament urged Iran to abolish discriminatory laws, ratify the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, and end the death penalty, including for juveniles, while noting partial reforms in drug laws that may reduce executions. It called for the immediate release of all unjustly detained activists and dual nationals, demanded fair trials, and pressed the EU to maintain restrictive measures (extended to April 2020) targeting human rights violators, while intensifying diplomatic efforts to address these issues in bilateral and multilateral engagements.

title: Implementation of the EU Association Agreement with Georgia: REPORT on the implementation of the EU Association Agreement with Georgia | A9-0136/2020 | European Parliament
background: Georgia's implementation of the EU Association Agreement, including constitutional reforms and a March 2020 electoral agreement, faced challenges such as judicial shortcomings, Russian cyber activities, and territorial disputes in Abkhazia and South Ossetia. The Parliament will discuss progress and obstacles in fulfilling the agreement's political, economic, and legal obligations.

stances.stance:
EPP fully approves Georgia's constitutional and electoral reforms under the March 8 agreement, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to democratic stabilization in Eastern Partnership states.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on deepening economic cooperation through DCFTA implementation, recognizing its strategic value for EU-Georgia trade integration.  
EPP fully approves Georgia's exemplary COVID-19 response as a model for crisis governance, reinforcing EPP's health security priorities in neighborhood policies.  
EPP unequivocally supports Georgia's sovereignty against external threats, mirroring EPP's foundational stance on defending territorial integrity in Eastern Europe.  
EPP fully approves accelerated Euro-Atlantic integration for Georgia, reflecting EPP's manifesto commitment to NATO enlargement as a stability guarantee.

ID rejects the issue’s endorsement of NATO-led military exercises like «Partenaire noble» in Georgia, viewing this as provocative alignment with U.S. interests that escalates tensions with Russia, contrary to ID’s principles of European strategic autonomy.  
The proposal fundamentally againsts with ID’s stance against Atlanticist interference, as it perpetuates Georgia’s role in NATO’s “brain-dead” posturing rather than fostering EU-Russia equilibrium.  
ID opposes the issue’s uncritical support for Georgia’s Euro-Atlantic integration, arguing it ignores historical recklessness exemplified by Saakachvili’s 2008 misadventures and repeats destabilizing patterns.  
The issue overlooks ID’s demand to halt external tutelage, as seen in its failure to address EU pressure on Serbia to cancel «Fraternité slave» exercises while greenlighting NATO activities in Georgia.  
ID condemns the EU’s “good points” system for Eastern Partnership states as ideological Atlanticism, inconsistent with their call for pragmatic diplomacy that avoids antagonizing Russia.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its assessment of Georgia’s progress in implementing the EU-Georgia Association Agreement and Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area, highlighting advancements in political dialogue, rule of law, human rights, and economic cooperation. It acknowledged Georgia’s constitutional reforms and the 8 March 2020 cross-party agreement on electoral reforms, which stabilized parliamentary democracy after political turmoil. However, concerns were noted regarding judicial independence, including flawed judge selection processes and politically charged cases against opposition figures, urging Georgia to adopt recommendations from the Venice Commission and OSCE/ODIHR. The resolution emphasized external challenges, such as Russian-linked cyber-attacks and ongoing occupation of Abkhazia and South Ossetia, reaffirming EU support for Georgia’s sovereignty and territorial integrity. It pledged continued collaboration with Georgia’s parliament through inter-parliamentary dialogue and institutional support to advance AA/DCFTA goals, while stressing the need for sustained reforms to align with EU standards and address democratic deficits.

title: Implementation report on the EU Trust Funds and the Facility for Refugees in Turkey: REPORT Implementation report on the EU Trust Funds and the Facility for Refugees in Turkey | A9-0255/2021 | European Parliament
background: The EU Trust Funds (2014-2021) and Facility for Refugees in Turkey were established to address migration, displacement, and instability linked to crises in Syria, Africa, Central African Republic, and Colombia. The Parliament will discuss the operational frameworks and accountability mechanisms of these financial instruments for external challenges and humanitarian aid.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely agrees the issue’s insistence on integrating external assistance into the EU budget via NDICI-Global Europe, perfectly aligning with EPP’s commitment to budgetary integrity and democratic accountability as emphasized by José Manuel Fernandes’ call for transparency.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the demand to avoid fragmented funding mechanisms, reinforcing Hildegard Bentele’s emphasis on transitioning to streamlined instruments like NDICI-Global Europe while ensuring refugee needs in Turkey remain prioritized.  
EPP absolutely agrees strict parliamentary oversight of Trust Funds, converting Andrey Novakov’s call for “bulletproof control” into a proposal to enhance audit protocols for all third-country disbursements.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s humanitarian focus on refugee education and stability, echoing Асим Адемов’s argument that EU support prevents long-term security risks by addressing Syrian children’s schooling needs in Turkey.  
EPP absolutely agrees limiting new Trust Funds to exceptional crises, transforming Bentele’s approval of FRT’s sunsetting into a model for future crisis responses under co-legislator scrutiny.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s allowance for new Trust Funds, as it fundamentally againsts with the party’s opposition to border externalization and cooperation with authoritarian regimes like Turkey.  
GUE_NGL opposes the Facility for Refugees in Turkey, citing its role in legitimizing the EU-Turkey deal that enables human rights abuses and fails to ensure refugee protections, as highlighted in Articles 12-15.  
GUE_NGL condemns the Africa Trust Fund’s support for Libyan coastguard operations, which directly contradicts the party’s commitment to ending complicity in migrant detention and torture.  
GUE_NGL demands the immediate termination of all Trust Funds, as their structure perpetuates undemocratic governance and violates the principle of parliamentary accountability outlined in the EU treaties.  
GUE_NGL asserts that the issue overlooks critical aspects such as Turkey’s authoritarian practices, rendering any “exceptional” funding approval incompatible with human rights obligations under the NDICI-Global Europe framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the EU Trust Funds (EUTFs) and the Facility for Refugees in Turkey (FRT), highlighting challenges to democratic accountability, parliamentary oversight, and budget integrity. While acknowledging their value in addressing crises, Parliament criticized their establishment and prolonged use without adequate involvement of co-legislators, stressing that external assistance should instead be fully integrated into the EU budget via instruments like NDICI-Global Europe and IPA III, with streamlined rules and respect for parliamentary prerogatives. It advocated revising the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) to enhance NDICI-Global Europe’s flexibility and funding, while allowing new Trust Funds only in exceptional cases (e.g., major crises, geopolitical shifts, or pooled third-country resources), provided Parliament is fully involved. Specific Trust Funds were evaluated: the Bêkou Fund (Central African Republic) mobilized €296.8 million (€218.9 million from the EU) for resilience, health, and economic recovery, with over €910 million total EU support since 2014; the Madad Fund (Syria crisis) allocated €2.2 billion (94 projects) supporting 7.29 million refugees in Lebanon (43%), Turkey (23%), Jordan (24%), and Iraq (7%); the Africa Trust Fund (€5 billion) targeted migration, resilience, and governance across 26 countries in the Sahel, Horn of Africa, and North Africa; the Colombia Trust Fund (€128 million) supported peace processes amid ongoing crises, including Venezuelan refugee influx and COVID-19 impacts. The FRT, with €6 billion (€3 billion initially, later doubled), combined humanitarian (€1.4 billion) and non-humanitarian aid (€1.6 billion) for refugees in Turkey, overlapping with Madad. Parliament emphasized the need to avoid fragmented funding mechanisms and ensure alignment with co-legislated frameworks.

title: Persecution of minorities on the grounds of belief or religion: REPORT on the persecution of minorities on the grounds of belief or religion | A9-0071/2022 | European Parliament
background: Persistent global persecution of religious and belief minorities, including violence, discrimination, and cultural destruction, alongside violations of international human rights frameworks and exacerbated vulnerabilities during the COVID-19 pandemic, has prompted international concern. The Parliament will discuss measures to address systemic persecution of minorities on grounds of belief or religion worldwide.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the issue’s condemnation of systemic persecution, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to defending religious freedom and human rights globally.  
EPP urgently calls for the immediate appointment of the EU Special Envoy for Religious Freedom, emphasizing this role as critical to advancing the issue’s accountability measures.  
EPP proposes enhancing evidentiary rigor by incorporating concrete examples from the Parliament’s 2017-2021 working group report to strengthen advocacy for persecuted minorities.  
EPP recommends refining the issue’s framing to avoid stigmatizing religion itself, instead focusing on targeted support for victims of persecution across all belief systems.  
EPP strongly endorses leveraging development aid and trade agreements as strategic tools to pressure states repealing blasphemy laws, aligning with the issue’s demand for international accountability mechanisms.

ECR conditionally endorses the issue's framework for addressing religious persecution but requests major revisions to address critical omissions.  
ECR absolutely disapproves with the issue's failure to explicitly name Christian persecution and regimes like China as primary concerns, demanding reinstatement of deleted references.  
ECR rejects the inclusion of abortion-related critiques as inconsistent with its principles, insisting such content be removed to align with the EU’s limited competencies on health policy.  
ECR calls for refocusing the text on direct persecution mechanisms rather than intersectional discrimination frameworks it views as ideologically driven.  
ECR insists the issue’s accountability measures lack teeth without explicit mention of Nigeria’s violence against Christians or Pakistan’s blasphemy law enforcement.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over the global persecution of religious and belief minorities, condemning systemic violations including killings, torture, forced conversions, gender-based violence, and destruction of cultural heritage. It highlighted the exacerbation of such abuses during the COVID-19 pandemic, including scapegoating, denial of healthcare, and exploitation of crisis measures for repression. The resolution emphasized intersectional discrimination faced by women, girls, and LGBTIQ+ individuals, particularly through blasphemy laws, forced marriages, and restrictions on sexual and reproductive rights. It noted that over 70 countries enforce blasphemy or apostasy laws, often leading to violence and mob justice against minorities. The Parliament called for accountability via international mechanisms like the International Criminal Court, urging EU support for investigations into genocide, crimes against humanity, and war crimes. It demanded the repeal of discriminatory laws, sanctions under the EU Global Human Rights Sanctions Regime, and protection for human rights defenders. The resolution stressed the need to address online hate speech, ensure humanitarian aid without discrimination, and safeguard cultural heritage as part of conflict prevention. It advocated for EU external action to prioritize religious freedom, including funding under the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument, and cooperation with UN initiatives. The Parliament also urged recognition of 22 August as the International Day Commemorating Victims of Violence Based on Religion or Belief, while calling for enhanced dialogue, education, and inclusive policies to combat radicalization and promote social cohesion.

title: Political crisis in Burkina Faso: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the political crisis in Burkina Faso | RC-B9-0104/2022 | European Parliament
background: In Burkina Faso, a January 2022 military coup followed prolonged jihadist insurgencies, internal displacement of 1.6 million people, and public discontent over governance and security failures, amid regional instability and climate-related challenges in the Sahel. The Parliament will discuss the political crisis and its implications for democratic governance and regional security.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely approves the issue’s unequivocal condemnation of the military coup in Burkina Faso, perfectly aligning with their foundational principle of upholding democratic legitimacy and constitutional order.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on addressing root instability drivers such as climate displacement and poverty, echoing Jiří Pospíšil’s call for urgent EU economic assistance to mitigate humanitarian suffering.  
EPP fully supports the demand for President Kaboré’s immediate release and restoration of civilian governance, reflecting Seán Kelly’s insistence on reversing democratic backsliding through AU-EU cooperation.  
EPP endorses the issue’s focus on security sector accountability, particularly its call to revise immunity clauses for special forces, which aligns with their commitment to human rights and rule of law.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the rejection of Wagner Group involvement, reinforcing their stance against external actors exacerbating regional instability, while endorsing ECOWAS-led mediation as the sole viable path to stability.

ID rejects the issue's reliance on EU-led solutions as fundamentally inconsistent with ID's principle of African self-determination and opposition to "paternalistic moral imperialism".  
ID opposes conditioning aid on democratic reforms given the demonstrated corruption in Burkina Faso's military expenditure (€650M cited) and failed EU democratization efforts in the Western Balkans.  
The proposal fails to address ID's core argument that climate-driven displacement and jihadist threats require autonomous African security frameworks rather than external judicial reforms.  
ID condemns the issue's vaccine conditionality approach as perpetuating dependency, directly contradicting Kuhs' demand to end "abhängig machen vom Impfstatus".  
 While opposing the issue's methods, ID conditionally approves calls to counter Wagner Group involvement if paired with complete withdrawal of European peacekeeping forces.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the military coup in Burkina Faso on 24 January 2022, which ousted President Roch Marc Christian Kaboré, suspended the constitution, and installed Lieutenant-Colonel Damiba as de facto leader, despite Kaboré’s 2020 democratic re-election. It condemned the coup, demanded Kaboré’s unconditional release, and stressed the urgent need to restore constitutional order through inclusive, transparent elections and civilian governance. The resolution highlighted severe security challenges, including jihadist attacks causing over 1.6 million internally displaced persons (a 50% increase in 2021), 1,000 closed schools, and deadly incidents like the June 2021 Solhan attack (174 deaths) and the November 2021 Inata attack (53 soldiers killed). It criticized rampant corruption and mismanagement of defense spending, which rose from €240 million to €650 million (2016–2021) without improving military effectiveness or living conditions. The Parliament urged EU and international support for humanitarian aid, judicial and security sector reforms, and accountability for human rights abuses, including summary executions by security forces. It called for revising the immunity clause for Burkina Faso’s special forces to ensure justice for victims and emphasized addressing root causes of instability, such as climate-driven displacement, poverty, and governance failures. The resolution expressed alarm over regional democratic backsliding, citing four West African coups in two years, and opposed the involvement of Russia’s Wagner Group, warning it undermines peace efforts. It endorsed ECOWAS and AU mediation, advocating clear transition timelines, civil society dialogue, and adherence to international commitments, including SDGs and human rights frameworks.

title: Political crisis in Sudan: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the political crisis in Sudan | RC-B9-0068/2022 | European Parliament
background: Following Sudan’s 2019 power-sharing agreement after Omar al-Bashir’s ouster, a military coup in October 2021 dissolved transitional institutions, triggering widespread protests, civilian casualties, and economic instability amid regional tensions. The Parliament will discuss Sudan’s political crisis, human rights violations, and pathways to restoring democratic governance.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally agrees the issue’s condemnation of military repression and sexual violence, perfectly aligning with EPP’s foundational principles of human dignity and rule of law.  
EPP perfectly aligns with demands to restore civilian rule through inclusive dialogue, reflecting EPP’s strategic imperative for democratic stability in migration-critical regions.  
EPP fully supports sustained EU humanitarian aid without political preconditions, advancing EPP’s commitment to direct civilian protection amid Sudan’s catastrophic food insecurity.  
EPP endorses accountability mechanisms including ICC referrals, resonating with EPP’s long-standing advocacy for international justice against regime atrocities.  
EPP strongly advocates for transparent migration cooperation to prevent military exploitation, upholding EPP’s ethical governance standards in external partnerships.

ID slightly approves the call for civilian rule but requests revisions to avoid destabilizing measures that risk triggering mass migration to Europe, referencing Sudan’s 7% migrant return rate in 2020.  
ID highlights that the issue’s emphasis on sanctions and ICC accountability fails to address the fragmented opposition’s capacity to ensure stability, complicating EU migration containment priorities.  
ID urges amendments to prioritize regional stability in the Horn of Africa, noting that aggressive pressure on Sudan’s military could exacerbate chaos in neighboring Somalia, Ethiopia, and Eritrea.  
ID opposes the issue’s migration cooperation transparency demands, arguing that current EU-Sudan agreements are critical to preventing uncontrolled migration flows.  
ID requests removal of strict electoral timelines, advocating for a gradual transition to avoid exacerbating regional instability given Sudan’s role as a potential “spark” in a volatile region.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over the military coup in Sudan on 25 October 2021, which dissolved the civilian-military transitional government, detained Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok, and derailed the democratic transition outlined in the 2019 Constitutional Declaration. It condemned the violent crackdown on protests, including the use of live ammunition, sexual violence, and internet shutdowns, resulting in at least 70 deaths, hundreds injured, and 15 documented attacks on healthcare facilities. The resolution denounced the military’s consolidation of power through appointments linked to the former al-Bashir regime, immunity grants to security forces, and economic control via military-owned companies in key sectors. It highlighted Sudan’s dire humanitarian crisis, with 6.2 million needing aid in 2022, acute food insecurity affecting 2.7 million people, and a 300% inflation surge exacerbating poverty. The Parliament urged independent investigations into human rights violations, accountability for perpetrators—including Omar al-Bashir’s extradition to the ICC—and demanded the military restore civilian rule with clear timelines, inclusive dialogue, and elections by July 2023. It called for international pressure, including EU sanctions under the Global Human Rights Regime, and stressed the need to sustain humanitarian aid, notably the EU’s €88 million support since 2019 and a €10 million December 2021 contribution to the WFP. The resolution emphasized ending external support for Sudan’s military, halting arms exports used for repression, and ensuring transparency in EU-Sudan migration cooperation to avoid enabling oppression. It further urged ratification of the Rome Statute, establishment of the Darfur Special Criminal Court, and protection of civilians in conflict zones like Darfur, where militia looted WFP supplies meant for 800,000 people.

title: Political situation in Uganda: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the political situation in Uganda | RC-B9-0138/2021 | European Parliament
background: Uganda's 2021 elections occurred amid reported irregularities, opposition suppression, security force violence, internet restrictions, and constrained civil society oversight, following prior EU concerns over governance.
