GUE_NGL rejects the punitive measures outlined, arguing they exacerbate tensions and ignore the necessity of sustained diplomatic channels like the Petersburg Dialogue mentioned in the debate.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's failure to address systemic geopolitical factors, such as NATO expansionism, that contribute to Russia’s defensive authoritarian crackdowns.  
GUE_NGL criticizes the proposal’s alignment with EU strategic interests over grassroots solidarity, noting its inconsistency with anti-imperialist principles and support for emancipatory NGOs.  
GUE_NGL contends the issue overlooks the risks of isolating Russian civil society further, advocating instead for unconditional funding and asylum without political conditionalities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over Russia’s systematic repression of civil society, political opposition, and fundamental freedoms through repressive laws targeting NGOs, media, and activists. It highlighted the expansion of "foreign agent" and "undesirable organization" designations, including the retroactive application of laws barring critics from elections and criminalizing dissent, exemplified by the persecution of Alexei Navalny’s Anti-Corruption Foundation and the forced dissolution of Open Russia. The resolution condemned the arbitrary detention of Andrei Pivovarov, over 11,000 arrests during protests supporting Navalny, and nearly 400 political prisoners held in violation of Russia’s international obligations. It urged Russia to release all detained activists, repeal restrictive laws, and end harassment of civil society, journalists, and opposition figures. The EU was called to impose targeted sanctions, halt strategic projects like Nord Stream 2, condition engagement on human rights improvements, and bolster support for Russian civil society through visas, asylum, and funding. It emphasized coordinated international action via the UN, OSCE, and Council of Europe to hold Russia accountable, while advocating for enhanced monitoring of trials, diplomatic pressure, and solidarity with victims of repression.

title: The mass trials against opposition and civil society in Cambodia: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the mass trials against the opposition and civil society in Cambodia | RC-B9-0183/2021 | European Parliament
background: Cambodia's 2017 dissolution of the main opposition party, non-free 2018 elections, mass trials of opposition figures, arrests of activists, and EU's 2020 partial trade preference withdrawal over rights violations preceded parliamentary scrutiny. The Parliament will discuss Cambodia's governance, civil liberties restrictions, and state actions against political opposition and civil society.

stances.stance:
RENEW completely sanctions the unequivocal condemnation of Cambodia’s judicial persecution of opposition voices, perfectly aligning with our commitment to defending democratic freedoms globally.  
RENEW perfectly aligns with demands for asset freezes and travel bans against Cambodian leaders, advancing our strategic priority of leveraging sanctions to combat authoritarian consolidation.  
RENEW completely sanctions the issue’s call to annul all politically motivated convictions, reflecting our foundational principle of upholding fair trial standards in all contexts.  
RENEW perfectly aligns with the insistence on restoring electoral pluralism, mirroring our decades-long advocacy for multiparty democracy as a non-negotiable EU value.  
RENEW completely sanctions redirecting EU aid to civil society, exemplifying our proven approach to strengthening grassroots democratic actors under repressive regimes.

ID partly promotes the issue’s condemnation of human rights abuses but requests revisions to prioritize trade sanctions addressing labor exploitation over political measures.  
This fundamentally disapproves with ID’s position that EU trade delocalization enables modern slavery, which the issue overlooks in its focus on electoral legitimacy.  
The proposal fails to address ID’s demand for safeguard clauses against Cambodian imports like textiles and rice, which they argue directly fund exploitative labor systems.  
ID insists amendments must link sanctions to concrete trade reciprocity rules preventing “chemical slavery” of workers, not solely political prisoner releases.  
 While supporting criticism of Cambodia’s governance, ID rejects the issue’s aid redirection strategy as insufficient without binding trade corrections.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over Cambodia’s systematic erosion of democracy, human rights, and political freedoms, condemning the government’s repression of opposition figures, civil society, and media. It highlighted mass trials targeting 137 individuals linked to the dissolved Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP), including the conviction in absentia of nine senior CNRP leaders in March 2021, with sentences of 20–25 years and revocation of political rights, alongside the prolonged suspension of Kem Sokha’s trial. The resolution denounced politically motivated charges, lack of fair trial guarantees, and coerced confessions, citing violations of Cambodia’s Criminal Code and international covenants. It noted the 2018 elections’ failure to meet democratic standards, resulting in a de facto one-party state, and warned that upcoming 2022 local elections would lack legitimacy without CNRP reinstatement. The Parliament condemned harassment of trade unionists, including Rong Chhun’s 2020 arrest, and environmental activists, as well as repressive laws enabling digital surveillance and stifling dissent under the guise of COVID-19 measures. It referenced the EU’s 2020 partial withdrawal of trade preferences under the Everything But Arms scheme due to rights violations and urged further sanctions, including asset freezes and travel bans against Cambodian leaders. The resolution called for immediate release of detained activists, annulment of unjust sentences, repeal of repressive legislation, restoration of pluralism, and meaningful dialogue with opposition and civil society. It urged the EU and member states to redirect aid from the government to civil society, monitor trials, and push for UN Human Rights Council action, while opposing Cambodia hosting international events like the Asia-Europe Meeting until democracy is restored.

title: The recent human rights developments in the Philippines: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the recent human rights developments in the Philippines | RC-B9-0097/2022 | European Parliament
background: The Philippines, an EU partner since 2016, faced reports of extrajudicial killings, attacks on activists/journalists, and the 2020 Anti-Terrorism Act amid ICC investigations into crimes against humanity, leading to its 2018 ICC withdrawal, while retaining GSP+ trade status. The Parliament will discuss human rights concerns and bilateral implications.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly promotes the issue's urgent call to leverage the GSP+ trade scheme as a decisive tool for human rights compliance, perfectly aligning with their commitment to ethical trade conditionalities.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the demand for international election observation missions to ensure democratic integrity in the 2022 Philippine elections, reflecting their manifesto priority for global democratic institution-building.  
EPP firmly promotes the condemnation of extrajudicial killings under the "war on drugs," resonating with their foundational stance against state-sanctioned violence and impunity.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's insistence on Philippine cooperation with the ICC's crimes-against-humanity probe, advancing their long-term advocacy for international justice mechanisms.  
EPP firmly promotes the proposed suspension of EU arms exports potentially used for repression, consistent with their arms-trade controls policy to prevent human rights abuses.

ID partly upholds the issue's human rights objectives but requests revisions to Article 12's GSP+ trade linkage, demanding explicit safeguards against economic harm to civilian populations through amended export protection clauses.  

This firmly disapproves with ID's position that extraterritorial judicial measures like ICC cooperation (Article 7) risk sovereignty violations, requiring deletion of "crimes against humanity" prosecutions beyond Philippine courts.  

The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as verification mechanisms for Anti-Terrorism Act reforms (Article 9), inconsistently applying ID's principle of non-interference by mandating legislative changes without bilateral judicial dialogue frameworks.  

ID highlights contradictions in Section 4's arms export ban, which fails to address dual-use technologies permissible under the party's defense cooperation principles unless amended to exclude counterinsurgency equipment.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over widespread human rights violations in the Philippines, particularly condemning the "war on drugs" under President Duterte, which resulted in 12,000–30,000 estimated extrajudicial killings, including 6,200 deaths acknowledged by authorities. It highlighted systemic abuses such as red-tagging, enabled by the 2020 Anti-Terrorism Act, which permits warrantless arrests and prolonged detention, exacerbating threats against activists, journalists, and trade unionists, with 146 human rights defenders and 22 journalists killed since 2016 without convictions. The resolution denounced the harassment and imprisonment of critics, including journalist Maria Ressa and Senator Leila de Lima, detained for five years on politically motivated charges, and condemned gender-based violence and discrimination perpetuated by laws like the Revised Penal Code. It urged immediate investigations into killings, compliance with international human rights standards, and cooperation with the ICC’s probe into crimes against humanity (2011–2019), while criticizing the Philippines’ withdrawal from the Rome Statute. The EU called for amending the Anti-Terrorism Act, ensuring free 2022 elections amid disinformation risks, and leveraging the GSP+ trade scheme—benefiting 26% of Philippine exports (€1.6 billion in 2020)—to enforce human rights benchmarks, threatening its suspension if violations persist. Additional demands included ending arms exports usable for repression, protecting indigenous rights, and supporting civil society, while urging accountability for state-backed paramilitary groups and police implicated in abuses.

title: The repression of the opposition in Turkey, specifically HDP: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the repression of the opposition in Turkey, specifically the Peoples’ Democratic Party (HDP) | RC-B9-0406/2021 | European Parliament
background: Turkish authorities initiated legal proceedings to dissolve the HDP, citing alleged terrorism links, following years of judicial actions against opposition figures and parties. The European Court of Human Rights repeatedly ruled for the release of detained HDP leaders, unresolved despite Turkey’s EU candidacy. The Parliament will discuss escalating restrictions on political opposition and democratic rights in Turkey.

stances.stance:
ECR requests revisions to the issue’s confrontational language, proposing amendments that prioritize cooperative dialogue over punitive measures toward Turkey.  
The issue’s threat-based approach entirely conflicts with ECR’s position that EU-Turkey security cooperation must not be jeopardized by domestic policy critiques.  
ECR conditionally supports concerns over judicial processes but demands removal of clauses implying EU interference in Turkey’s sovereign legal framework.  
This proposal overlooks critical aspects such as Turkey’s frontline role in countering regional instability, requiring amendments to acknowledge Ankara’s geopolitical value.  
ECR advocates replacing condemnation with technical assistance mechanisms, aligning with their issue’s emphasis on advisory engagement to address opposition rights.

GUE_NGL fundamentally advocates the issue’s unequivocal condemnation of Turkey’s judicial persecution of the HDP, perfectly aligning with their commitment to global anti-authoritarian solidarity and defense of political pluralism.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s exposure of EU-Turkey collaboration hypocrisy as critical reinforcement for democratic movements, mirroring their manifesto demand to end partnerships with regimes violating fundamental rights.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with the issue’s demand to halt trustee appointments in Kurdish municipalities, reflecting their decades-long advocacy for decentralized governance and minority self-determination.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the issue’s linkage between anti-terror law abuses and shrinking civic space as vital to challenging NATO members’ authoritarian practices, a core tenet of their foreign policy agenda.  
GUE_NGL asserts the issue’s ECtHR compliance demands directly advance their strategic litigation efforts to hold EU institutions accountable for enabling rights-abusing partners.

resolution: The European Parliament raised deep concerns over Turkey’s systemic erosion of democracy, human rights, and rule of law, particularly targeting opposition parties like the Peoples’ Democratic Party (HDP). It condemned the Turkish authorities’ efforts to dissolve the HDP through a Constitutional Court indictment seeking to ban nearly 500 members from political activity for five years and freeze party accounts, following years of crackdowns resulting in 4,000 HDP members imprisoned, including MPs and elected officials. The resolution highlighted the misuse of anti-terror laws in the ongoing "Kobanî trial" against 108 HDP members, with 28 arrested and warrants for 75 others, and denounced the arbitrary stripping of parliamentary immunity from three HDP MPs, leading to their arrests. It condemned Turkey’s disregard for European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) rulings, including the repeated detention of former HDP co-chair Selahattin Demirtaş despite ECtHR orders for his release. The Parliament also criticized the removal of 59 out of 65 democratically elected HDP mayors in southeastern Turkey since 2019, replaced by government-appointed trustees, and escalating pressure on the main opposition Republican People’s Party (CHP) and its leader Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu, facing prosecution and a TRY 1 million lawsuit. It urged Turkey to cease judicial harassment, ensure pluralism, align anti-terror laws with international standards, and protect opposition parties’ rights, stressing that EU-Turkey relations depend on compliance with democratic principles, minority rights, and the Copenhagen criteria.

title: The situation in Afghanistan: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the situation in Afghanistan | RC-B9-0324/2021 | European Parliament
background: Following the 2020 U.S.-Taliban agreement and planned NATO troop withdrawal by September 2021, Afghanistan faced escalating Taliban violence, stalled peace negotiations, deteriorating security, and threats to human rights gains, alongside EU development commitments and humanitarian crises from COVID-19 and drought. The Parliament will discuss implications of international disengagement and EU strategies to support stability, rights, and peace processes.

stances.stance:
SD totally agrees the issue’s emphasis on preserving women’s rights and inclusive peace processes, perfectly aligning with SD’s foundational principles of gender equality and democratic participation.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s call for sustained EU engagement through multilateral frameworks, advancing SD’s commitment to global stability and regional cooperation.  
SD totally agrees the prioritization of combating opium production and terrorism, reflecting SD’s longstanding focus on addressing transnational security threats.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands for accountability in humanitarian aid distribution, ensuring EU funds directly support Afghan civil society and human rights benchmarks.  
SD totally agrees the issue’s condemnation of violence against journalists and civilians, mirroring SD’s unwavering defense of press freedom and civilian protection.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s framing of Taliban resurgence as the primary destabilizing force, condemning instead NATO’s two-decade militarization that empowered warlords and exacerbated violence, directly contradicting their anti-imperialist principles.  

GUE_NGL opposes linking EU funding to human rights conditions, viewing this as hypocritical given the bloc’s complicity in destabilizing Afghanistan through proxy wars and support for corrupt regimes, which eroded social progress.  

GUE_NGL entirely opposes with claims of post-2001 socio-political advancement, arguing that U.S./NATO occupation systematically dismantled Afghan sovereignty and worsened women’s rights by backing fundamentalist militias, as cited in their historical critique.  

GUE_NGL condemns the omission of NATO’s responsibility for civilian casualties and displacement, noting that the issue’s humanitarian appeals ignore the root causes: Western intervention and economic exploitation.  

GUE_NGL disputes the issue’s reliance on UN-led investigations without addressing Western forces’ impunity, deeming this selective accountability inconsistent with their stance on global justice.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over Afghanistan’s critical juncture amid the withdrawal of US and NATO troops by September 2021, warning of potential instability, Taliban resurgence, and risks to socio-political progress achieved since 2001, including human rights, democracy, and women’s empowerment. It condemned escalating violence, including targeted killings of civilians, journalists, and women professionals, with 85 killed in a May 2021 school bombing and 35,000 civilian deaths over two decades, urging an immediate ceasefire. The resolution stressed the need for an Afghan-led peace process, inclusive negotiations with proportional women’s representation, and third-party mediation, while calling for a comprehensive EU strategy post-withdrawal. It highlighted EU support, having allocated over €4 billion (2002–2020) and pledging €1.2 billion (2021–2025), contingent on preserving human rights, governance, and anti-corruption efforts. The Parliament emphasized safeguarding women’s rights, noting threats like gender-based violence and limited healthcare access, and addressing a humanitarian crisis with 4 million displaced (3 million from violence), 5.5 million facing emergency food insecurity, and 17.6 million at risk due to drought and COVID-19. It urged tackling terrorism, citing Taliban-Al-Qaeda ties, ISIL-Khorasan threats, and terrorism’s economic cost (20% of 2018 GDP), alongside combating opium production and promoting sustainable development. The resolution called for regional cooperation with neighboring countries, UN-led investigations into attacks, protection for local staff who aided foreign forces, and continued humanitarian aid, including COVID-19 vaccines and food security measures, while ensuring EU funds are tied to transparent benchmarks on democracy and human rights.

title: The situation in Belarus after one year of protests and their violent repression: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the situation in Belarus after one year of protests and their violent repression | RC-B9-0482/2021 | European Parliament
background: Following the 2020 Belarusian presidential elections marked by alleged fraud, mass protests faced systemic repression including detentions, torture, and media crackdowns. Subsequent state-sponsored migrant crossings at EU borders and deepened military integration with Russia occurred. The Parliament will discuss Belarus's political crisis, human rights violations, regional security implications, and migration challenges.

stances.stance:
EPP completely upholds the issue’s demand for international accountability through tribunals and universal jurisdiction, perfectly aligning with its unwavering commitment to justice for state-sponsored torture and forced disappearances.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call to expand sanctions targeting Lukashenko’s economic enablers, particularly the $1 billion arms integration with Russia, as this advances EPP’s strategic priority to cripple authoritarian alliances.  
EPP completely upholds the €3 billion EU democratic transition plan, recognizing its congruence with EPP’s manifesto pledge to empower exiled leaders like Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya and dismantle hybrid warfare tactics.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the condemnation of the Astravyets nuclear plant risks, echoing EPP’s environmental security agenda and insistence on halting energy imports tied to regime coercion.  
EPP completely upholds the issue’s humanitarian imperative to protect migrants and asylum seekers, reflecting EPP’s foundational principle that hybrid attacks exploiting human suffering demand unified EU solidarity.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue’s inadequate sanctions on potash and key economic sectors, completely doubting with their demand to sever all EU financial flows propping up Lukashenko’s regime.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the delayed implementation of refugee protections, overlooking critical winter survival needs highlighted in their call for immediate humanitarian corridors.  
The issue’s limited accountability mechanisms contradict GREEN_EFA’s principle of universal jurisdiction for regime crimes, failing to prioritize swift international tribunals.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the insufficient measures against Belarus-Russia military integration, inconsistent with their stance on countering hybrid threats to regional security.  
The €3 billion EU plan lacks binding commitments to direct funding for grassroots democratic movements, opposing GREEN_EFA’s demand for unconditional support to civil society.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over the Belarusian regime’s systemic repression, including over 40,000 detentions, 720 political prisoners, and 4,600 criminal cases targeting dissent since the fraudulent 2020 elections. It condemned state-sponsored torture, forced disappearances, and the closure of 250 civil society organizations, including the Human Rights Center Viasna, whose leaders like Ales Bialiatski faced imprisonment. The resolution denounced politically motivated trials, such as the 11-year sentence for opposition figure Maryia Kalesnikava, and the crackdown on media, with 500 journalists arrested and the Belarusian Association of Journalists shut down. It labeled the forced diversion of Ryanair flight FR4978 as state terrorism, leading to sanctions against 166 individuals and 15 entities, including economic measures, though criticized their limited impact on sectors like potash. The Parliament condemned Belarus’s hybrid attacks, including orchestrating the migration crisis (4,000 entries into Lithuania) and collaborating with Russia via joint military exercises (Zapad 2021) and economic integration, including a $1 billion arms deal. It urged expanded sanctions, support for democratic forces like Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya, and a €3 billion EU plan for a future democratic Belarus, alongside calls for international accountability via tribunals and universal jurisdiction for regime crimes. Concerns over the unsafe Astravyets nuclear plant and demands to halt energy imports from it were emphasized, alongside appeals for humanitarian aid to migrants and protection of asylum rights. The resolution reiterated demands for free elections, abolition of the death penalty, and an end to repression against minorities, trade unions, and athletes, while urging coordinated international action to isolate the regime and support Belarusian civil society.

title: The situation in Chad: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the situation in Chad | RC-B9-0290/2021 | European Parliament
background: Chad’s President Idriss Déby, in power since 1990, died in April 2021 amid clashes with rebel forces, prompting a military-led transition suspending constitutional order. Chad’s strategic role in Sahel security cooperation, persistent governance challenges, and regional instability due to armed groups and humanitarian crises shaped the context. The Parliament will discuss Chad’s political transition and implications for regional stability.

stances.stance:
ECR totally agrees the issue’s condemnation of the unconstitutional military takeover and violent suppression of protests, as this perfectly aligns with ECR’s commitment to democratic legitimacy and human rights.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the demand for urgent civilian-led elections, recognizing that democratic mandates are critical to depriving terrorist groups of social grievances.  
ECR emphasizes the necessity for the EU to eliminate colonial-era paternalism in its partnerships with Chad, proposing enhanced dialogue frameworks that respect African sovereignty.  
ECR applauds the issue’s integrated security-development approach, which advances their priority of combating corruption and poverty as root causes of instability.  
ECR underscores that stability cannot exist without democratic accountability, fully supporting the rejection of unilateral military transitions.

ID conditionally agrees the issue’s security cooperation references but requests revising Article 12 to prioritize military stability over transitional timelines, stating the proposed 45-90 day election mandate risks destabilizing counter-terrorism efforts.  

ID rejects the issue’s condemnation of the TMC’s transitional authority as inconsistent with its stance that immediate military-led governance is critical to prevent state collapse and protect EU border security interests.  

The proposal absolutely conflicts with ID’s position on migration control by neglecting to tie development aid to stricter border management clauses, a prerequisite for regional stability.  

ID opposes the demand for an independent inquiry into TMC actions, arguing this undermines Chad’s sovereignty and distracts from counter-terrorism priorities outlined in the G5 Sahel framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the unconstitutional transfer of power in Chad following President Idriss Déby’s death in April 2021, condemning the Transitional Military Council (TMC) for suspending the constitution, dissolving government institutions, and imposing an 18-month transitional charter. It highlighted the TMC’s violent suppression of protests, resulting in at least six deaths, hundreds of arrests, and widespread human rights violations, and called for an independent inquiry into abuses. The resolution emphasized the need for an urgent civilian-led transition, inclusive dialogue, and free elections within 45-90 days as mandated by Chad’s constitution, while rejecting the TMC’s unilateral actions. It noted Chad’s role in regional security through the G5 Sahel and EU-supported initiatives, including the EU Training Mission and EUR 542 million in development aid (2014-2020), but stressed the need to address root causes of instability such as poverty, climate change, and corruption (Chad ranks 187th on the Human Development Index). The Parliament urged the EU and international community to support democratic processes, protect human rights, and ensure accountability for misuse of funds, while safeguarding Chad’s territorial integrity amid threats from terrorist groups like Boko Haram and internal displacement affecting over 133,000 people. It reiterated the importance of regional mediation led by Mauritania and Niger and endorsed integrated approaches combining security, development, and governance to stabilize the Sahel.

title: The situation in Cuba, namely the cases of José Daniel Ferrer, Lady in White Aymara Nieto, Maykel Castillo, Luis Robles, Félix Navarro, Luis Manuel Otero, Reverend Lorenzo Rosales Fajardo, Andy Dunier García and Yunior García Aguilera: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the situation in Cuba, namely the cases of José Daniel Ferrer, Lady in White Aymara Nieto, Maykel Castillo, Luis Robles, Félix Navarro, Luis Manuel Otero, Reverend Lorenzo Rosales Fajardo, Andy Dunier García and Yunior García Aguilera | RC-B9-0589/2021 | European Parliament
background: In July and November 2021, Cuba experienced widespread protests over socio-economic conditions, COVID-19 impacts, and civil liberties, leading to reports of arbitrary detentions and alleged restrictions on assembly and expression. The EU-Cuba Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement (2016) includes human rights commitments. The Parliament will discuss human rights concerns in Cuba and bilateral relations under the agreement.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly agrees the issue's demand to activate Article 85(3)(b) of the EU-Cuba PDCA, perfectly aligning with their unwavering commitment to condition engagement on democratic reforms and human rights compliance.  
EPP perfectly aligns with calls for targeted sanctions against Cuban regime officials, emphasizing their systematic persecution of Sakharov laureates like Guillermo Fariñas and Aymara Nieto as intolerable violations of core European values.  
EPP firmly agrees the condemnation of Cuba’s revocation of EFE journalists’ credentials, reflecting their ironclad defense of press freedom as a non-negotiable pillar of EU external action.  
EPP perfectly aligns with demands for immediate release of all political prisoners, including José Daniel Ferrer and Luis Manuel Otero, reaffirming their decades-long advocacy for dissidents facing torture and fabricated charges.  
EPP fully supports the issue’s linkage between EU funding accountability and human rights progress, demanding strict adherence to Article 1(5) of the PDCA to prevent financing regime-aligned entities over civil society.

SD rejects the issue's confrontational approach as counterproductive to fostering democratic dialogue in Cuba, fundamentally opposing the call for PDCA suspension under Article 85(3)(b) which contradicts S&D's emphasis on engagement over isolation.  
SD opposes the imposition of sanctions against Cuban officials, arguing this escalates political blockades rather than addressing systemic issues through multilateral economic cooperation and humanitarian aid.  
The issue overlooks S&D's prioritization of lifting the U.S. embargo as a prerequisite for improving human rights, focusing disproportionately on punitive measures inconsistent with the group's 2021 Cuba policy framework.  
SD condemns the issue's selective emphasis on civil-political rights violations while failing to address U.S. sanctions' role in exacerbating Cuba's socio-economic crisis, a key concern in Articles 1(5) and 43(2) of the PDCA.  
This proposal conflicts with S&D's stance that EU-Cuba relations require sustained political dialogue rather than conditional cooperation, as demonstrated by the rejection of UNHRC access demands without parallel commitments to sanction relief.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over systematic human rights violations in Cuba, condemning the government’s crackdown on peaceful protests since July 2021, which occurred in over 50 cities amid socio-economic crises, COVID-19, and demands for democracy. It highlighted arbitrary detentions, torture, and degrading treatment of protestors, dissidents, activists, journalists, and Sakharov Prize laureates, including José Daniel Ferrer, Aymara Nieto, and Guillermo Fariñas, who faced harassment, forced exile, or imprisonment under fabricated charges. The resolution denounced Cuba’s suppression of the planned 15 November 2021 civic march, revocation of EFE journalists’ credentials to stifle press freedom, and persistent breaches of the EU-Cuba Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement (PDCA), particularly violations of human rights obligations under Articles 1(5), 2(c), 5, 22, and 43(2). It urged immediate release of all political prisoners, independent investigations into abuses, access for UN human rights rapporteurs, and guarantees for freedoms of expression, assembly, and fair trials. The Parliament called on the EU to trigger the PDCA’s suspension clause (Article 85(3)(b)) due to Cuba’s failure to uphold democratic principles, and urged sanctions against officials responsible for repression. It stressed the need for Cuba to align with international human rights standards, ensure economic and social rights, and engage civil society in dialogue, while condemning forced expatriations and restrictions on EU delegations and civil society monitoring. The resolution underscored deteriorating human rights conditions despite the PDCA’s provisional application since 2017 and demanded urgent reforms to address systemic repression.

title: EU-Kazakhstan Enhanced Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (Consent): RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Enhanced Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Kazakhstan, of the other part
background: The European Union and Kazakhstan established a partnership in 1999, with the EU as Kazakhstan’s primary trade partner and investor. Kazakhstan’s strategic role in Central Asia and the 2015 signing of an Enhanced Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, alongside its 2016 WTO accession and the EU’s regional strategy, form the context. The Parliament will discuss ratifying the agreement to deepen bilateral cooperation across political, economic, and security domains.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the agreement for prioritizing EU geopolitical competition over Eurasian integration with Russia, completely doubting with their multipolarity doctrine.  
ENF opposes the issue's failure to address strategic collaboration with the Eurasian Economic Union, deemed essential by ENF to counter Chinese and Islamist regional threats.  
ENF condemns the approach as repeating divisive EU expansionist errors, overlooking Kazakhstan's role as a Eurasian stability "verrou" requiring Russian partnership.  
The proposal contradicts ENF's insistence on avoiding Ukraine-like conflicts by rejecting shared leadership with Russia in Central Asian diplomacy.  
ENF completely doubts EU attempts to realign Kazakhstan through bilateral agreements, advocating instead for trilateral EU-Russia-Kazakhstan frameworks to prevent destabilization.

ALDE entirely agrees the Enhanced Partnership and Cooperation Agreement as it perfectly aligns with their commitment to proactive EU foreign policy and strategic engagement in Central Asia.  
ALDE emphasizes the agreement’s critical role in reinforcing Kazakhstan’s position as a stabilizing force for regional security and a reliable partner in combating transnational threats.  
ALDE applauds the economic synergies created by the agreement, which advance their priority of fostering investment reciprocity and market access opportunities for EU enterprises.  
ALDE recognizes the issue’s alignment with democratic development goals, noting Kazakhstan’s evolving reforms as consistent with shared values despite its nascent democratic trajectory.  
ALDE underscores the symbolic importance of adopting this agreement on Kazakhstan’s Independence Day, reflecting mutual dedication to long-term cooperation and EU leadership in Eurasian diplomacy.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Enhanced Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the EU and Kazakhstan, aimed at deepening political, trade, and sectoral cooperation, including energy, transport, and justice. The resolution references the draft Council decision (12409/2016) and the draft agreement (09452/2015), emphasizing alignment with EU treaties, particularly Article 37 and Article 31(1) of the Treaty on European Union, and relevant provisions of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (Articles 91, 100(2), 207, 209, and 218). It underscores the agreement’s role in strengthening economic ties, promoting reforms, and enhancing dialogue on human rights and rule of law, while acknowledging the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on International Trade’s endorsement (A8-0325/2017) as the basis for approval.

title: EU-Kazakhstan Enhanced Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (Resolution): REPORT containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Enhanced Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Kazakhstan, of the other part
background: The EU and Kazakhstan established a 1999 Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, later negotiating an Enhanced Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (EPCA) signed in 2015, with provisional application from 2016. Kazakhstan joined the WTO (2016) and engages in Eurasian Economic Union and OSCE frameworks. The Parliament will discuss ratifying the EPCA to deepen political, economic, and sectoral cooperation.

stances.stance:
ALDE completely sanctions the EPCA as a strategic framework that perfectly aligns with ALDE's commitment to fostering stability and economic cooperation with key Central Asian partners.  
ALDE applauds Kazakhstan's role in regional security and counter-terrorism efforts, recognizing its critical contribution to safeguarding both Central Asian and European Union interests.  
ALDE highlights the agreement's enhancement opportunities for democratic reforms, urging continued progress on judicial independence and civil liberties to strengthen long-term partnership foundations.  
ALDE strongly promotes the EPCA's economic provisions, which create vital platforms for mutual investment and align with ALDE's priorities for expanding EU trade influence in emerging markets.  
ALDE acknowledges Kazakhstan's geostrategic importance and encourages sustained EU engagement through technical support and educational exchanges under Erasmus+ to deepen bilateral ties.

GUE_NGL rejects the Enhanced Partnership and Cooperation Agreement as it cynically prioritizes EU energy security and trade volumes over systemic human rights violations documented by UN rapporteurs and OSCE electoral observers.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally any agreement that whitewashes Kazakhstan’s repression of oil worker protests in 2011, where torture and killings occurred, while failing to mandate independent investigations into state violence.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s token human rights clauses as inconsistent with GUE/NGL’s anti-imperialist principles, given its silence on Kazakhstan’s criminalization of dissent through anti-terror laws and Interpol abuse.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s failure to address Kazakhstan’s 2016 laws suffocating civil society, directly contradicting the group’s commitment to defending grassroots organizing against authoritarian neoliberalism.  
GUE_NGL denounces the EU’s complicity in legitimizing Kazakhstan’s fraudulent 2016 parliamentary elections, which OSCE monitors deemed structurally oppressive to political freedoms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the Enhanced Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (EPCA) with Kazakhstan as a framework to deepen political, economic, and sectoral cooperation, emphasizing shared commitments to democracy, rule of law, human rights, and market economy principles. The EPCA, provisionally applied since May 2016 and replacing the 1999 Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, expands cooperation across 29 areas, including energy, climate change, trade, education, and security, while introducing counter-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction as a new essential element. Parliament welcomed Kazakhstan’s WTO accession (2016) and its role in regional stability but expressed serious concerns over restrictions on freedoms of expression, assembly, media, and civil society, citing cases like activists Maks Bokayev and Talgat Ayan imprisoned for peaceful protests. It urged judicial reforms, anti-corruption measures, and compliance with ILO standards, condemning politically motivated charges against trade union leaders and the closure of independent unions. The resolution highlighted Kazakhstan’s geostrategic importance, energy exports (80% of its EU exports are oil/gas), and environmental challenges, including the Aral Sea crisis and nuclear legacy of Semipalatinsk, calling for EU technical and financial support. It stressed the need for economic diversification, alignment with WTO and EPCA trade commitments, and public procurement reforms with 5- and 8-year transition periods. Parliament insisted on strict monitoring of human rights, labor standards, and anti-corruption efforts, reserving the right to suspend the EPCA for rights violations, while encouraging visa facilitation, Erasmus+ expansion, and civil society engagement. Kazakhstan’s multilateral diplomacy, including Syria talks and nuclear disarmament initiatives, was acknowledged, alongside calls to cease misuse of anti-terror laws and Interpol procedures against dissent.

title: EU-NATO relations: REPORT on EU-NATO relations
background: The EU and NATO have deepened their strategic partnership since 2016, amid evolving security challenges including hybrid threats, cyberattacks, and regional instability. Institutional developments like Permanent Structured Cooperation and the European Defence Fund aim to enhance defense capabilities. The Parliament will discuss strengthening EU-NATO collaboration on security, defense interoperability, and addressing shared strategic threats.

stances.stance:
EPP completely accepts the issue’s balanced emphasis on NATO’s essential role in collective defense and the EU’s strategic autonomy, perfectly aligning with EPP’s commitment to pragmatic, non-ideological cooperation that avoids duplication while addressing shared threats like hybrid warfare and Russian aggression.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the prioritization of practical initiatives such as PESCO and the European Defence Fund, which strengthen military mobility and interoperability, directly advancing EPP’s goal of a robust European defense framework that complements NATO’s capabilities.  
EPP completely accepts the call for EU member states to meet NATO’s 2% GDP defense spending target, emphasizing that enhanced European contributions reinforce NATO’s effectiveness and uphold transatlantic solidarity, a cornerstone of EPP’s security policy.  
EPP applauds the issue’s focus on joint EU-NATO measures against cyberattacks, terrorism, and maritime threats, reflecting EPP’s longstanding advocacy for integrated security strategies that leverage both organizations’ unique tools and resources.  
EPP strongly accepts the issue’s reaffirmation of NATO’s centrality in collective defense alongside the EU’s role as a comprehensive security provider, ensuring coherence between initiatives like CARD and NATO planning processes, as outlined in EPP’s 2023 defense manifesto.

GUE/NGL fundamentally challenges the issue’s militarist alignment with NATO, which contradicts their core principles of peace, strategic autonomy, and anti-imperialism.  
GUE/NGL rejects the endorsement of NATO’s 2% GDP defense spending target, viewing it as a capitulation to U.S.-driven militarization that undermines social priorities and regional stability.  
The issue fails to address NATO’s destructive legacy, including illegal interventions in Yugoslavia and Libya, which GUE/NGL condemns as violations of international law and catalysts for current crises.  
GUE/NGL highlights the hypocrisy of citing “common values” while ignoring NATO members’ aggression, such as Turkey’s threats against Greece and occupation of Cyprus, which the issue conspicuously omits.  
By prioritizing interoperability with NATO over genuine EU autonomy, the proposal entrenches dependency on structures GUE/NGL deems incompatible with peace and multipolar diplomacy.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the imperative for enhanced EU-NATO cooperation to address shared security challenges, emphasizing complementarity, strategic autonomy, and adherence to common values such as democracy and the rule of law. It underscored the necessity of a stronger European defence framework through initiatives like Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO), the European Defence Fund (EDF), and improved military mobility, while aligning with NATO’s priorities, including collective defence and interoperability. The resolution highlighted progress in implementing 42 joint EU-NATO measures (2016) and 32 additional actions (2017), focusing on hybrid threats, cybersecurity, counter-terrorism, and maritime security, and welcomed the establishment of hybrid threat centers and joint exercises. It stressed the need for EU Member States to meet NATO’s 2% GDP defence spending target, with 20% allocated to equipment, and urged infrastructure upgrades for rapid military deployment. Concerns over Russia’s assertive behavior, cyberattacks, and instability in the Southern neighborhood were noted, alongside calls for coordinated responses. The resolution emphasized avoiding duplication, enhancing resilience in partner countries (e.g., Bosnia and Herzegovina, Moldova), and fostering transatlantic ties post-Brexit, acknowledging the UK’s continued role in European security. It advocated for improved intelligence-sharing, gender inclusion in missions, and coherence between EU defence initiatives (e.g., Coordinated Annual Review on Defence) and NATO planning processes, while reaffirming NATO’s centrality in collective defence and the EU’s role as a comprehensive security provider.

title: EU-New Zealand Partnership Agreement on Relations and Cooperation (Consent): RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the Union of the Partnership Agreement on Relations and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and New Zealand, of the other part
background: The EU and New Zealand, bound by shared values and existing cooperation frameworks including a 2007 joint declaration and 2012 security agreement, pursued deepened ties amid the EU's strategic outreach to Asia-Pacific partners. The Parliament will discuss formalizing an upgraded bilateral partnership agreement covering political dialogue, economic collaboration, and joint security initiatives.

stances.stance:
SD strongly sanctions the strategic partnership framework as a vital reinforcement of shared democratic principles, aligning perfectly with S&D's commitment to multilateral cooperation in turbulent geopolitical times.  

SD applauds the integration of climate action and UN peacekeeping synergies, which effectively advances S&D's priority of global sustainability leadership through joint implementation of Paris Agreement targets.  

SD endorses enhanced counterterrorism intelligence-sharing mechanisms while proposing future trade negotiations explicitly safeguard EU agricultural sensitivities through robust geographical indication protections.  

SD approves the agreement's focus on Asia-Pacific stability, recognizing New Zealand's pivotal role in promoting maritime security and rules-based order – key to S&D's Indo-Pacific engagement strategy.  

SD welcomes provisions for academic and technological collaboration, urging accelerated complementary free trade talks that maintain high labor and environmental standards across supply chains.

GUE_NGL rejects the agreement's foundation as a stepping stone to another free trade deal, entirely conflicting with their opposition to trade policies that prioritize economic growth over climate sustainability and workers' rights.  
GUE_NGL opposes the regulatory convergence mechanisms, highlighting how invisible technical committees would erode EU standards on environmental protection and labor rights—core principles of the group.  
GUE_NGL condemns the failure to address agricultural sector vulnerabilities, noting the issue’s silence on protecting small farmers from market imbalances caused by New Zealand’s export-driven model.  
GUE_NGL argues the agreement overlooks critical climate obligations, as expanded transport and fossil fuel use from increased trade directly contradict Paris Agreement targets emphasized in their platform.  
GUE_NGL warns that alignment with New Zealand’s TPP membership creates systemic risks, undermining democratic oversight and enabling corporate influence over policymaking—a red line for the group.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval for the conclusion of the Partnership Agreement on relations and cooperation between the European Union, its Member States, and New Zealand, based on the 2016 draft agreement (09787/2016) and the Council’s request (C8-0027/2017) under Article 37 of the Treaty on European Union and Articles 207 and 212(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The resolution endorsed the agreement, which aims to strengthen bilateral ties across areas such as trade, climate action, human rights, and security, reflecting shared democratic values. It highlighted the legal basis for the decision and instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate the consent to the Council, Commission, and relevant national governments and parliaments, following the Committee on Foreign Affairs’ recommendation (A8-0327/2017). The resolution emphasized the strategic importance of deepening EU-New Zealand cooperation while aligning with broader EU external policy objectives.

title: EU-New Zealand Partnership Agreement on Relations and Cooperation (Resolution): REPORT containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the Union of the Partnership Agreement on Relations and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and New Zealand, of the other part
background: The European Union and New Zealand have maintained longstanding bilateral relations through prior agreements on scientific cooperation, crisis management, and a 2007 joint declaration, underpinned by shared democratic values and economic ties. The Parliament will discuss formalizing an updated partnership agreement to strengthen political, economic, and sectoral cooperation frameworks.

stances.stance:
SD strongly advocates the PARC framework as a vital reinforcement of shared democratic values and multilateral cooperation, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to climate leadership and rules-based global order.  
SD approves the enhanced security collaboration through EUNAVFOR Atalanta and counterterrorism efforts, recognizing New Zealand's proven role in EU crisis management operations as critical for international stability.  
SD highlights the issue's effective advancement of joint climate priorities, particularly renewable energy cooperation and marine conservation, mirroring New Zealand's 80% renewable electricity achievements.  
SD proposes ensuring agricultural sensitivity provisions in FTA negotiations explicitly protect EU producers while maintaining reciprocity, enhancing the agreement's sustainability dimensions.  
SD commends the strategic focus on Asia-Pacific stability and development aid partnerships, which aligns with SD's 2023 manifesto goals for equitable global governance.

GUE/NGL opposes fundamentally the issue's promotion of free trade agreements which exacerbate climate degradation through increased transport emissions and fossil fuel dependency  
GUE/NGL rejects regulatory convergence mechanisms as undemocratic erosion of EU standards, particularly citing the non-transparent "regulatory cooperation body" that bypasses parliamentary oversight  
GUE/NGL highlights the issue's failure to safeguard agricultural sectors from market destabilization, contradicting GUE/NGL's anti-neoliberal trade principles  
GUE/NGL condemns the alignment with TiSA-style service trade expansions, which threaten European workers' rights and job security through downward regulatory harmonization  
GUE/NGL asserts the proposal conflicts with Paris Agreement obligations by prioritizing trade growth over binding emission reduction targets, as evidenced by unresolved climate governance gaps noted in Bonn conferences

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of deepening EU-New Zealand relations through the Partnership Agreement on Relations and Cooperation (PARC), which establishes a framework for enhanced collaboration on sustainable development, security, climate action, trade, and counterterrorism, including information-sharing on terrorist networks. It supported launching free trade agreement (FTA) negotiations emphasizing reciprocity and sensitivity to agricultural products, while highlighting New Zealand’s role as the EU’s third-largest trading partner. The resolution acknowledged New Zealand’s contributions to international peace, including participation in EU crisis management operations (e.g., EUNAVFOR Atalanta, EUPOL Afghanistan), peacekeeping missions in Afghanistan and Iraq, and leadership during its 2015–2016 UN Security Council term, including co-sponsoring resolutions on Syria and the Middle East. It commended New Zealand’s climate leadership, noting its ratification of the Paris Agreement and reliance on renewable energy for over 80% of electricity, and urged expanded cooperation on sustainable energy and marine conservation. The resolution recognized New Zealand’s strategic partnerships in the Asia-Pacific region, its role in regional stability, and its status as a key development aid provider. It also emphasized collaboration in science, technology, and environmental governance, particularly in the Pacific and Antarctica, while welcoming New Zealand’s support for the International Criminal Court and its efforts against violent extremism in Southeast Asia.

title: EU-Singapore Partnership and Cooperation Agreement: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Singapore, of the other part
background: The European Union and Singapore concluded negotiations on a Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and accompanying trade and investment deals following a decade-long process, with Singapore being a key ASEAN member and the EU’s largest Southeast Asian trade partner. The Parliament will discuss the ratification of the EU-Singapore Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and associated trade and investment agreements.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA absolutely upholds the agreement’s integration of environmental sustainability and labor standards as a model for EU-Asia climate diplomacy, perfectly aligning with their decarbonization agenda.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the strategic value of ASEAN-EU connectivity frameworks in the issue, which advance multilateralism and green transition pathways central to their Indo-Pacific policy.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the necessity to uphold EU sovereignty in financial governance by ensuring debt restructuring mechanisms remain insulated from investor-state arbitration, aligning with post-2008 crisis reforms.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the human rights conditionality in Article 6 as a critical tool to promote democratic freedoms, mirroring their demands for systemic reforms in partner nations.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the imperative to rigorously enforce corporate accountability provisions, preventing ISDS mechanisms from undermining public health or environmental regulations during implementation.

GUE_NGL totally opposes the inclusion of ISDS mechanisms that enable corporate challenges to democratic policymaking, directly contradicting Article 212 TFEU's rule-of-law objectives.  
GUE_NGL rejects the agreement's failure to impose binding sustainability requirements while granting investor privileges, rendering environmental commitments in Section IV non-enforceable.  
GUE_NGL condemns legitimizing Singapore's financial secrecy regime through enhanced investment channels, undermining EU anti-tax evasion efforts referenced in governance cooperation clauses.  
GUE_NGL denounces the prioritization of foreign bondholder rights over sovereign debt restructuring capacities, exposing Member States to speculative financial attacks during crises.  
GUE_NGL highlights the contradiction between celebrating shared democratic values and partnering with an authoritarian state ranked 167th in civil liberties by Freedom House.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval for the conclusion of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union, its Member States, and the Republic of Singapore, aimed at enhancing bilateral relations across trade, investment, environmental sustainability, human rights, and governance. The resolution references the draft Council decision (15375/2018) and the agreement text (08224/2014), emphasizing alignment with the EU’s external action objectives under Article 212 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and the procedural framework of Article 218(6) TFEU. It underscores the agreement’s role in strengthening economic ties, promoting regulatory cooperation, and addressing shared challenges such as climate change and labor standards. The Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its consent to the Council, Commission, Member States, and Singapore, finalizing the ratification process to enable the agreement’s implementation.

title: EU-Singapore Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (resolution): REPORT containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Singapore, of the other part
background: Decades of EU-Singapore political and economic cooperation, including under the 1980 ASEAN-EEC framework, Singapore’s ASEAN leadership, and its status as a major Southeast Asian trade hub with existing 2018 EU agreements, established foundations for enhanced bilateral relations. The Parliament will discuss formalizing a comprehensive partnership and cooperation agreement.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s prioritization of climate action and human rights, particularly its call for Singapore to abolish discriminatory laws and uphold LGBTI equality.  
GREEN_EFA completely accepts the emphasis on multilateral governance and ASEAN-EU cybersecurity collaboration, reflecting their strategic vision for Indo-Pacific stability.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening Annex 4 provisions to eliminate investor privileges in public debt restructuring, ensuring alignment with EU post-2008 financial safeguards.  
GREEN_EFA demands rejection of investor-state arbitration mechanisms that undermine democratic sovereignty, urging trade frameworks centered on citizen rights over corporate power.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the inclusion of ISDS mechanisms in Article 44 which enable corporate challenges to public interest policies, directly conflicting with democratic accountability principles.  
GUE_NGL rejects the agreement's failure to impose binding environmental obligations on investors, rendering climate action commitments under the Paris Agreement unenforceable.  
GUE_NGL highlights the fundamental contradiction in partnering with Singapore as a recognized tax haven (ranked 6th in anti-corruption), undermining EU pledges to combat financial opacity.  
GUE_NGL condemns prioritizing foreign investors' rights to acquire state bonds (Section III), enabling corporate obstruction of sovereign debt restructuring during crises.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the issue's disregard for Singapore's authoritarian governance (151st in press freedom), inconsistent with EU human rights conditionality clauses in PCA Article 44.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the strategic importance of the EU-Singapore Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA), which establishes a framework for enhanced cooperation in areas such as environmental protection, climate action, security, justice, and sustainable development. It welcomed Singapore’s ratification of the Paris Agreement (2016) and urged joint efforts to meet emissions targets by 2030, combat deforestation, and adopt eco-friendly technologies. The resolution emphasized human rights concerns, urging Singapore to abolish laws criminalizing same-sex relations, protect LGBTI rights, and address restrictions on freedom of expression and assembly, noting Singapore’s 151st ranking on the 2018 World Press Freedom Index. It called for a moratorium on the death penalty and ratification of core ILO conventions on labor rights. The Parliament highlighted Singapore’s role in ASEAN and regional stability, including its contributions to cybersecurity via the ASEAN Cyber Capacity Programme and peace initiatives like the Shangri-La Dialogue. It stressed the need for EU-Singapore collaboration on trade, research (e.g., Horizon 2020), and cultural exchanges, while underscoring Singapore’s economic significance as a top-ranked country in anti-corruption (6th in 2017) and human development (9th in 2017). The resolution also urged adherence to international law in resolving South China Sea disputes and promoted multilateral governance through ASEAN-EU dialogues. Institutional mechanisms, including a PCA Joint Committee, were endorsed to monitor implementation, with Article 44 allowing suspension of agreements in cases of human rights violations.

title: EU-Ukraine Association Agreement: REPORT on the implementation of the EU Association Agreement with Ukraine
background: The EU-Ukraine Association Agreement (2014) established political/economic integration, including a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (2016), amid Russia’s 2014 annexation of Crimea and conflict in Eastern Ukraine. Ukraine implemented reforms in energy, governance, and anti-corruption but faces challenges including corruption, oligarchic influence, and socioeconomic pressures. The Parliament will discuss the agreement’s implementation, focusing on reform progress, economic integration, and geopolitical stability.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the issue's recognition of Ukraine's reform progress in decentralization and energy policy, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to European integration through structural modernization.  
EPP strongly approves the call for sustained sanctions against Russia and enhanced security cooperation, effectively advancing EPP's priority of safeguarding territorial integrity in Eastern Europe.  
EPP proposes strengthening minority rights provisions by explicitly incorporating the Venice Commission's recommendations on language laws and educational reforms as an enhancement opportunity for inclusive governance.  
EPP strongly endorses the emphasis on judicial reforms and anti-corruption measures, particularly the operationalization of the High Anti-Corruption Court, which matches EPP's 2023 manifesto commitments to rule-of-law frameworks.  
EPP urges stricter monitoring of agricultural trade protocols to address sectoral imbalances while maintaining full support for the DCFTA's strategic economic integration goals.

ENF opposes fundamentally the issue’s portrayal of anti-corruption progress, citing endemic oligarchic control and political interference in NABU, which conflicts with ENF’s rejection of EU-backed governance models that fail to dismantle systemic corruption.  
ENF condemns the economic provisions of the AA/DCFTA, highlighting Ukraine’s plummeting GDP per capita and record trade deficits as proof the agreement harms both Ukrainian welfare and EU agricultural sectors, inconsistent with ENF’s defense of economic sovereignty.  
ENF rejects the issue’s silence on neo-Nazi militia violence, arguing it overlooks state-tied human rights abuses and undermines ENF’s commitment to security and rule of law.  
ENF disputes electoral reform claims, condemning EU-funded NGO interference as hypocritical electoral meddling, contrary to ENF’s principle of non-intervention in sovereign democracies.  
ENF opposes agricultural imports under the AA, warning of irreversible damage to French cereal farmers, a stance rooted in ENF’s prioritization of local agriculture over destabilizing trade liberalization.

resolution: The European Parliament raised recognition of Ukraine’s progress in reforms such as energy, health, education, decentralization, and macro-economic stabilization under the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement (AA) and Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA), operational since 2016, while emphasizing persistent challenges including corruption, oligarchic influence, judicial inefficiency, and social inequality. It condemned Russia’s aggression in eastern Ukraine, illegal annexation of Crimea, and destabilizing actions in the Sea of Azov, urging prolonged EU sanctions until territorial integrity is restored and proposing an EU special envoy for the conflict. The resolution stressed the need for urgent deoligarchization, judicial reforms—including establishing an independent High Anti-Corruption Court—and enhanced anti-corruption measures, citing concerns over political interference in the National Anti-Corruption Bureau (NABU). It highlighted the importance of electoral reforms, minority rights, media freedom, and civil society protection, condemning attacks on activists like Kateryna Handziuk. Economically, it noted increased EU-Ukraine trade and a €200 million SME support fund but expressed alarm over rising poverty, wealth inequality, and the need for investment. Environmental and energy cooperation were urged, including opposition to Nord Stream 2 and sustainable resource management. The Parliament called for improved AA/DCFTA implementation through better institutional coordination, regulatory alignment, and annual EU monitoring reports, while advocating for Ukraine’s European perspective under Article 49 TEU and enhanced Eastern Partnership Plus cooperation. It also emphasized addressing humanitarian crises, supporting IDPs, and ensuring social welfare amid ongoing conflict.

title: Eastern Partnership: November 2017 Summit: REPORT on a European Parliament recommendation to the Council, the Commission and the EEAS on the Eastern Partnership, in the run-up to the November 2017 Summit
background: The Eastern Partnership, established in 2009 with Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova, and Ukraine, has seen Association Agreements with Georgia, Moldova, and Ukraine, visa liberalization, and the 20 Deliverables for 2020 framework. Unresolved regional conflicts and the November 2017 Summit prompted evaluation. The Parliament will discuss the partnership's future direction, progress assessment, and priorities.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly approves the Eastern Partnership Plus initiative and CSDP mission expansion, aligning with their commitment to actionable European integration through deepened political and security cooperation.  
ALDE completely agrees prioritizing judicial reforms and anti-corruption roadmaps while advocating amplified EU funding for civil society organizations facing authoritarian pressures.  
ALDE strongly approves maintaining unified EU condemnation of Russian aggression in Ukraine and Georgia, emphasizing conflict issue as foundational to regional stability and partnership credibility.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s focus on economic connectivity and mobility frameworks, urging accelerated DCFTA implementation to reinforce pro-European aspirations in associated states.  
ALDE proposes reassessing participation criteria for non-reformist regimes to safeguard the "more for more" principle, suggesting stricter conditionality for summit-level engagement.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's continuation of blank-check financial support to Eastern Partnership governments without binding anti-corruption safeguards, totally disputeing with their anti-oligarchic principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's Russophobic narrative that exacerbates geopolitical tensions, inconsistent with their commitment to peaceful EU-Russia dialogue and regional stability.  
The proposal totally disputes with GUE_NGL's stance by ignoring legitimate popular referendums in contested regions while uncritically endorsing EU-aligned regimes' territorial claims.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's failure to address structural poverty and unemployment, instead prioritizing corporate-friendly economic integration over grassroots social justice reforms.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of energy sovereignty by demanding shutdowns of nuclear facilities like Ostrovets, imposing EU decarbonization models without local consultation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of the Eastern Partnership as a shared commitment between the EU and Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova, and Ukraine to deepen relations based on democracy, rule of law, human rights, gender equality, sustainable development, and good governance. It highlighted progress since the 2009 launch, including Association Agreements and Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) with Georgia, Moldova, and Ukraine, visa-free regimes for these countries, a partnership agreement with Armenia, and ongoing negotiations with Azerbaijan, alongside reforms supported by EU technical and financial aid. The resolution underscored challenges such as deteriorating human rights and democratic backsliding in some partner states, unresolved regional conflicts exacerbated by Russian aggression—notably in Ukraine (Crimea annexation) and Georgia (occupied regions)—and hybrid threats undermining European security. It emphasized the "more for more" principle, linking EU support to partners’ reform commitments, and endorsed a strategic 2020 work plan with 20 deliverables focusing on governance, mobility, economic integration, and connectivity. The Parliament urged enhanced EU engagement in conflict resolution, stronger support for democratic transitions, and prioritized bilateral and regional cooperation to advance political association, economic integration, and societal resilience while respecting partners’ sovereign choices in aligning with EU ambitions.

title: EU strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement: REPORT on EU strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement
background: Following the 2015 Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) and subsequent EU sanctions relief, Iran's compliance with nuclear commitments prompted renewed diplomatic engagement. Geopolitical shifts, economic potential, and regional security concerns shaped EU-Iran relations. The Parliament will discuss post-JCPOA EU strategy, balancing economic cooperation, human rights, and regional stability priorities.

stances.stance:
SD firmly accepts the issue's strict JCPOA implementation framework, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to multilateral diplomacy as the cornerstone for EU-Iran economic integration and regional security enhancement.  
SD perfectly supports the linkage between sanctions relief and human rights conditionality, particularly the demand to abolish juvenile executions, which directly advances SD's decades-long campaign against capital punishment and gender-based violence.  
SD firmly accepts leveraging Iran's counter-terrorism capabilities against ISIS through structured regional dialogue, aligning with SD's strategic priority to stabilize conflict zones while condemning sectarian proxy interventions in Syria and Yemen.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's environmental cooperation mandate, recognizing joint climate action on Caspian Sea preservation and solar energy development as critical to fulfilling SD's Green Deal external dimension.  
SD firmly accepts academic mobility programs like Erasmus+ with Iran, seeing them as essential to empower civil society actors and institutionalize the issue's judicial reform agenda through grassroots cultural exchange.

ECR rejects the issue's economic engagement framework for legitimizing the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps' dominance in Iran's economy, contravening ECR's anti-terror financing principles.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the omission of Iran's state-sponsored Holocaust denial and calls for Israel's destruction, which violates ECR's commitment to transatlantic solidarity and Middle East security.  
ECR condemns the report's failure to condition trade growth on abolishing juvenile executions and releasing political prisoners, inconsistent with ECR's human rights red lines.  
ECR disputes the issue's characterization of Iran as a regional stabilizer, citing its "schurkengedrag" in Syria/Yemen as irreconcilable with ECR's counterterrorism priorities.  
ECR demands deletion of Caspian Sea cooperation clauses until Iran halts systematic persecution of ethnic Ahwazi Arabs and other minorities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) as a key achievement in multilateral diplomacy, emphasizing strict implementation to enhance EU-Iran relations and regional stability. It welcomed economic opportunities post-sanctions, noting Iran’s GDP of $397 billion (2015), potential for quadrupling EU-Iran trade (then $8 billion), and Iran’s need for $1 trillion in infrastructure investment. The resolution urged Iran to combat corruption, align with FATF recommendations, and pursue WTO accession to integrate into the global economy, while highlighting concerns over U.S. sanctions impacting EU businesses and advocating euro-based transactions. Human rights concerns included Iran’s high execution rates (noting 86% of global opium seizures occur there), urging abolition of the death penalty for drug offenses (potentially reducing executions by 80%) and minors, and calling for releases of political prisoners and dual nationals. It stressed gender equality, protection of ethnic and religious minorities, and judicial reforms. Regionally, Iran’s role in countering ISIS and stabilizing Iraq/Syria was acknowledged, alongside calls for de-escalation with Saudi Arabia and regional cooperation on security, energy, and refugee management (noting Iran hosts 3 million Afghans). Environmental cooperation on water scarcity, renewable energy (highlighting Iran’s solar potential), and Caspian Sea pollution was encouraged. Educational exchanges, including Erasmus Mundus and Horizon 2020 collaboration, were promoted to foster people-to-people ties. The resolution balanced economic engagement with demands for human rights progress, advocating a "four Cs" dialogue (comprehensive, cooperative, critical, constructive) to advance mutual interests while addressing systemic challenges.

title: EU-Afghanistan Cooperation Agreement on Partnership and Development: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Cooperation Agreement on Partnership and Development between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan, of the other part
background: The EU and Afghanistan signed a Cooperation Agreement on Partnership and Development in 2017, provisionally applied since December 2017, following years of EU development aid and amidst ongoing security challenges. The Parliament will discuss concluding the agreement, establishing the first legal framework for bilateral relations across governance, development, and regional stability.

stances.stance:
ALDE fully approves the agreement's strategic alignment with EU values in promoting rule of law and democratic governance as essential pillars for Afghanistan's stability.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on sustained financial commitments, particularly the €474 million package to reinforce public sector reforms and migration management.  
ALDE highlights the necessity of inclusive peace negotiations involving Afghanistan's government as critical to preserving constitutional rights and preventing security vacuums.  
ALDE emphasizes the agreement's role in safeguarding women's freedoms against regression, ensuring Taliban engagement doesn't compromise two decades of gender equality progress.  
ALDE supports the regional cooperation framework as vital to addressing cross-border challenges while maintaining conditionality on human rights benchmarks.

GUE_NGL rejects the agreement’s neoliberal economic framework, which prioritizes foreign corporate profits over Afghan welfare, fully disputeing with their anti-austerity and anti-exploitation principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes the inclusion of migration provisions enabling forced returns to Afghanistan, denouncing this as a violation of refugee rights and international humanitarian law.  
GUE_NGL highlights the agreement’s failure to address documented harms of IMF-imposed structural adjustments, directly contradicting their stance against market-driven development models.  
GUE_NGL condemns the promotion of natural resource extraction by EU firms, which overlooks critical ecological and social justice concerns central to the party’s platform.  
GUE_NGL asserts the issue’s security focus perpetuates militarized interventionism, inconsistent with their commitment to peaceful, sovereignty-respecting cooperation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to conclude the Cooperation Agreement on Partnership and Development between the European Union, its Member States, and the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan, aimed at strengthening bilateral cooperation in areas such as development, governance, human rights, rule of law, migration, and security. The resolution references the legal basis under Articles 207, 209, and 218 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, endorsing the draft Council decision (15093/2016) and the draft agreement (05385/2015). It aligns with the Committee on Foreign Affairs’ recommendation and the Committee on Development’s opinion (A8-0026/2019), emphasizing the agreement’s role in fostering stability and sustainable development in Afghanistan. The Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its approval to the Council, Commission, EU member states’ governments and parliaments, and Afghanistan’s government and parliament, finalizing the procedural steps for the agreement’s adoption.

title: EU-Australia Framework Agreement: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the Union of the Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Australia, of the other part
background: The EU and Australia negotiated a framework agreement to deepen bilateral cooperation across policy areas, requiring European Parliament consent under EU treaty obligations for international agreements. The Parliament will discuss the agreement's compliance with institutional procedures and legal frameworks governing EU external action and member state competencies.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the Framework Agreement, aligning perfectly with their commitment to effective EU legislation and international cooperation as key to addressing global challenges.  
EPP applauds the emphasis on subsidiarity and proportionality, crucial for maintaining citizen trust and countering Eurosceptic narratives.  
EPP approves the agreement's strategic focus on quality legislation and political dialogue, consistent with their priorities for EU-Australia relations.
