EPP proposes enhancing national parliamentary engagement through more flexible timelines for reasoned opinions to strengthen implementation.  
EPP underscores the need to balance subsidiarity with solidarity principles to ensure equitable outcomes across member states.

ENF rejects the Framework Agreement as it undermines subsidiarity by centralizing EU-Australia policy coordination, conflicting with ENF's core principle of safeguarding national sovereignty against supranational overreach.  
ENF opposes the issue’s legal basis in TFEU Articles 207 and 218, which enable expanded EU competence in foreign policy—a mechanism ENF views as eroding member states’ autonomous decision-making capacities.  
The proposal completely condemns with ENF’s demand for a “red card” procedure to empower national parliaments in blocking EU legislation, as it perpetuates top-down integration without meaningful democratic checks.  
ENF condemns the omission of explicit guarantees for national parliaments to issue motivated opinions at all legislative stages, a flaw that disregards ENF’s 2018 manifesto calling for decentralized governance.  
The agreement overlooks critical risks of regulatory alignment with Australia on environmental standards, which ENF argues could bypass stricter national protections upheld by member states under subsidiarity.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to conclude the Framework Agreement between the EU and its Member States and Australia, aimed at enhancing bilateral cooperation across foreign policy, security, economic matters, sustainable development, and environmental protection. The resolution references the draft Council decision (15467/2016) and the draft Framework Agreement (09776/2016), emphasizing alignment with legal bases under Article 37 of the Treaty on European Union and Articles 207, 212(1), and 218 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It underscores the agreement’s role in deepening political dialogue and joint action on global challenges, while instructing the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its position to the EU Council, Commission, and relevant national governments and parliaments, including Australia’s. The Committee on Foreign Affairs’ recommendation (A8-0110/2018) supported the agreement, reflecting its strategic importance for EU-Australia relations.

title: EU-Australia Framework Agreement (Resolution): REPORT containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the Union of the Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Australia, of the other part
background: The EU and Australia share longstanding diplomatic and economic ties, reinforced by multiple bilateral agreements on trade, security, and climate cooperation. Australia's strategic role in the Indo-Pacific and alignment with EU values on governance and international law underpinned efforts to formalize enhanced collaboration. The Parliament will discuss concluding a comprehensive framework agreement to deepen bilateral relations across policy areas.

stances.stance:
ENF firmly disapproves the Framework Agreement as a vehicle for deepening EU supranational integration, contradicting their core principle of defending national sovereignty against Brussels-centric policymaking.  
ENF rejects the issue’s failure to mandate a “red card” mechanism allowing national parliaments to block EU initiatives like this agreement that encroach on member states’ exclusive competencies.  
ENF condemns the omission of continuous subsidiarity checks throughout the legislative process, which would safeguard against overreach in areas such as migration cooperation outlined in the issue.  
ENF argues the issue’s emphasis on EU-led security missions (e.g., EUCAP Nestor) disregards the primacy of nation-states in defense matters, violating Protocol No. 2 on subsidiarity.  
ENF highlights that the agreement’s climate and trade provisions centralize regulatory power in EU institutions, undermining Australia’s bilateral engagements with individual member states.

SD strongly upholds the EU-Australia Framework Agreement’s alignment with democratic values and rule of law, particularly its emphasis on reinforcing shared commitments to climate action and human rights, which perfectly aligns with SD’s longstanding commitment to global justice and sustainable development.  
SD applauds the issue’s focus on reciprocity in trade negotiations and protection of environmental standards, proposing to enhance this further by explicitly integrating corporate social responsibility principles into the FTA’s labor provisions to address parliamentary "green card" requests.  
SD commends the issue’s recognition of Australia’s climate leadership and urges accelerated collaboration on renewable energy targets, suggesting a joint EU-Australia innovation fund for clean technology as a concrete enhancement opportunity.  
SD absolutely advocates the emphasis on Indo-Pacific security cooperation and intelligence-sharing through Europol, noting this effectively advances SD’s priority of multilateral counter-terrorism strategies while maintaining proportionality in cross-border data governance.  
SD welcomes the call for improved asylum-seeker conditions as consistent with SD’s human rights agenda, proposing an amendment to include EU technical assistance to Australia for regional processing center reforms without opposing the issue’s core principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of the Framework Agreement (FA) between the EU and Australia, which strengthens bilateral cooperation on foreign policy, security, human rights, climate action, trade, migration, and counter-terrorism. The resolution highlighted shared values like democracy, rule of law, and respect for international law, noting Australia’s role as the EU’s second-largest trading partner in 2016 (19.3% of imports, 10.3% of exports) with significant mutual investments (€117.7 billion EU FDI in Australia and €21.7 billion Australian FDI in the EU in 2015). It welcomed upcoming EU-Australia FTA negotiations, emphasizing reciprocity, protection of sensitive sectors like agriculture, and maintaining environmental and labor standards. The resolution commended Australia’s climate commitments, including reducing emissions by 26-28% below 2005 levels by 2030, doubling renewable energy capacity by 2020, and co-chairing the Green Climate Fund, alongside its ratification of the Paris Agreement. It recognized Australia’s contributions to global security, including counter-terrorism efforts in Southeast Asia, anti-piracy operations, and participation in EU-led missions like EUCAP Nestor, as well as alignment with EU sanctions against Russia over Ukraine. The resolution underscored cooperation on migration through the Bali Process and support for UN Global Compacts on refugees and migration, while urging Australia to address asylum-seeker conditions in Papua New Guinea and Nauru. It praised Australia’s Closing the Gap strategy for Indigenous communities and its election to the UN Human Rights Council (2018–2020). The resolution also emphasized joint efforts in cybersecurity, intelligence-sharing via Europol, and promoting regional stability in the Indo-Pacific, including freedom of navigation in the South China Sea.

title: EU-Canada Strategic Partnership Agreement: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Strategic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Canada, of the other part
background: Negotiated over seven years, the EU-Canada Strategic Partnership Agreement and Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) aim to enhance economic cooperation and shared democratic values amid rising global protectionism and challenges to multilateral trade frameworks. The Parliament will discuss finalizing the agreements to deepen bilateral trade and geopolitical alignment.

stances.stance:
EPP completely advocates the Strategic Partnership Agreement as it perfectly aligns with their commitment to fact-based economic growth, evidenced by the 55% export increase and 14\xa0000 new jobs created through the EU-South Korea agreement.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on rules-based globalization, viewing CETA as essential counterbalance to protectionist trends and a demonstration of EU leadership in shaping international trade standards.  
EPP completely advocates the modernization of dispute issue mechanisms, affirming that CETA's investor courts strengthen legal predictability while maintaining national judicial sovereignty, contrary to opposition claims.  
EPP fully supports the agreement's geostrategic dimension, emphasizing its role in reinforcing transatlantic partnerships with democratic allies against isolationist policies like those of the Trump administration.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the agricultural safeguards and mutual recognition of 143 geographical indications, noting this protects European farmers while expanding market access for SMEs.

EFDD rejects the Strategic Partnership Agreement for instituting undemocratic technocratic bodies that bypass parliamentary oversight, as outlined in Articles 15-17.  
EFDD opposes the agreement’s ISDS mechanisms, which prioritize corporate tribunals over national sovereignty, directly conflicting with EFDD’s constitutional principles.  
EFDD condemns the issue’s failure to address GMO proliferation and hormone-treated meat imports, violating EU food safety standards specified in Annex 4.  
EFDD entirely rejects with the economic clauses, citing irreversible job losses and wage suppression inconsistent with the issue’s social welfare pledges.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Strategic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States and Canada, aimed at deepening bilateral cooperation across political, economic, and global challenges. The resolution endorsed the agreement, which seeks to enhance dialogue and collaboration in areas such as foreign policy, security, trade, sustainable development, human rights, and justice. It emphasized the importance of shared values and common objectives, including climate action, multilateralism, and the rules-based international order. The Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its position to the Council, the Commission, and the governments and parliaments of EU Member States and Canada, finalizing the ratification process to strengthen EU-Canada relations.

title: China, notably the situation of religious and ethnic minorities: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on China, notably the situation of religious and ethnic minorities
background: China's policies on religious and ethnic minorities, including reports of mass arbitrary detentions, re-education camps in Xinjiang, restrictions on religious practices, and digital surveillance, alongside existing EU-China frameworks like the Strategic Partnership and human rights dialogues, form the context. The Parliament will discuss minority rights and human rights concerns in China.

stances.stance:
ENF totally condemns the issue as hypocritical interference, noting Europe’s destructive 19th-century imperialism and imposition of ideologies like Marxism fractured China’s sovereignty.  
ENF rejects moralizing critiques from nations with histories of religious wars and colonialism, asserting Europe lacks standing to lecture China on minority policies.  
ENF argues the issue overlooks China’s state-driven economic revival as a sovereign achievement contradicting Western interventionist models.  
ENF contends the proposal violates the UN Charter’s non-intervention principles, urging adherence to international law over politicized condemnations.  
ENF dismisses selective focus on minority issues while ignoring Europe’s own violent territorial conflicts and ideological impositions.

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the issue’s unequivocal stance against cultural erasure policies, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to protecting self-determination rights for all minority groups.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on documenting forced assimilation practices in Xinjiang and Tibet as a critical step toward international accountability mechanisms.  

GREEN_EFA proposes amending Section 4 to include explicit support for UNESCO-led cultural preservation initiatives targeting endangered Uyghur manuscripts and sacred sites.  

GREEN_EFA endorses leveraging EU-China trade agreements to mandate independent monitoring of vocational training centers, reflecting their manifesto principle of ethical conditionality.  

GREEN_EFA urges expanded parliamentary collaboration with Kazakh and Kyrgyz civil society groups to track transnational family separations caused by detention policies.

title: Climate diplomacy: REPORT on climate diplomacy
background: The European Union has historically led global climate initiatives through the Paris Agreement and its Climate Diplomacy Action Plan. Recent geopolitical shifts, including the US withdrawal from Paris, and increasing climate-related security and migration challenges necessitate enhanced multilateral engagement. The Parliament will discuss integrating climate objectives into EU foreign policy frameworks and international cooperation strategies.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue’s multilateral climate action framework, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to global leadership, as emphasized by Francesc Gambús’ warning that "no country can resolve climate change alone" and the existential threats faced by small island states.  
EPP endorses integrating climate diplomacy into all trade agreements but proposes amending Article 6 to explicitly require revisiting existing deals like CETA and Mercosur with binding emissions reduction benchmarks and WTO-enforced penalties for environmental dumping.  
EPP applauds the renewable energy targets and climate finance mechanisms, noting Ireland’s renewed commitment to exceed 2030 goals as exemplifying national alignment with EU priorities, per Seán Kelly’s emphasis on "putting our house in order."  
EPP emphasizes proactive climate migration safeguards, urging bilateral agreements with vulnerable regions to include preemptive resilience funding, echoing Μαρία Σπυράκη’s call for diplomacy addressing "the difference between living, fleeing, or dying."  
EPP approves institutional reinforcement of climate diplomacy through increased DG Climate Action funding, ensuring horizontal coordination across foreign policy bodies as urged by Sirpa Pietikäinen’s demand for "climate criteria in all development agreements."

ECR totally conflicts the creation of "climate refugee" frameworks, asserting this would destabilize migration policy and lacks Paris Agreement foundations.  
ECR rejects demands for exceeding Paris Agreement obligations, arguing the issue undermines the accord’s balance by imposing unilateral decarbonization timelines.  
ECR highlights contradictions in advocating global climate finance while EU fails to enforce environmental law internally, citing unresolved illegal wind park cases in Greece.  
ECR disputes net-zero 2050 targets as incompatible with Paris Agreement’s recognition of natural CO2 absorption through forests.  
ECR opposes diverting 30% of EU budget to climate initiatives, prioritizing strict domestic regulatory compliance over aspirational funding pledges.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the severe impacts of climate change on global stability, human rights, migration, and vulnerable populations, emphasizing its role as a "threat multiplier" exacerbating conflicts, inequality, and displacement. It reaffirmed the EU’s commitment to the Paris Agreement, urging increased ambition to limit global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels, and called for a net-zero carbon strategy by 2050, aligning with enhanced 2030 Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs). The resolution stressed the need for climate diplomacy to integrate mitigation, adaptation, and resilience into EU foreign policy, trade agreements, and security strategies, while addressing climate-induced migration—projected to affect up to 200 million people by 2050—through international legal frameworks for "climate refugees." It highlighted the EU’s role as the largest provider of public climate finance, advocating for 30% of the EU budget to support climate-related initiatives and leveraging partnerships to phase out fossil fuels, promote renewables, and transfer green technologies. Gender equality, indigenous rights, and human rights were underscored as central to climate action, with calls to address women’s underrepresentation (12-15% of delegation heads) in climate negotiations. The EU was urged to lead multilateral efforts, strengthen carbon pricing mechanisms, and collaborate with international bodies like the G20, Arctic Council, and UN agencies, while pressuring sectors like aviation and shipping to reduce emissions. The resolution also emphasized support for vulnerable regions, including small island states and the Arctic, and stressed the importance of local governance, scientific research, and civil society engagement in achieving climate justice and sustainable development.

title: Azerbaijan, notably the case of Mehman Huseynov: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Azerbaijan, notably the case of Mehman Huseynov
background: Azerbaijani blogger Mehman Huseynov was imprisoned in 2017 for criticizing government corruption, with new charges emerging in December 2018 amid reports of restricted press freedom and blocked independent media. Azerbaijan, a Council of Europe member, engaged in EU partnership negotiations since 2016. The Parliament will discuss human rights concerns and media freedom in Azerbaijan within bilateral relations.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves anchoring EU-Azerbaijan relations in democratic reforms and human rights, aligning with their commitment to foundational European values.  
EPP approves the urgent demand for Mehman Huseynov’s unconditional release and medical care, condemning extended sentences for political prisoners as incompatible with rule of law.  
EPP endorses linking the Comprehensive Agreement negotiations to measurable progress on civil liberties, particularly media freedom and judicial independence.  
EPP proposes strengthening scrutiny of Azerbaijan’s 2017 legal amendments to ensure independent legal representation for detainees facing politically motivated charges.  
EPP commends the issue’s focus on systemic corruption and transnational repression tactics, urging EU delegations to prioritize civil society safeguards.

EFDD partly accepts the issue’s condemnation of Azerbaijan’s press freedom violations but requests revisions to impose explicit sanctions on officials overseeing Huseynov’s solitary confinement.  
The proposal overlooks EFDD’s principle that EU negotiations must immediately freeze until Azerbaijan releases Mukhtarli and Mammadov, per Article 12’s insufficient linkage to conditional engagement.  
EFDD finds the issue inconsistent with its demand for direct EU accountability by requiring public audits of Council of Europe members linked to Azerbaijani corruption allegations.  
The civil society funding reforms fail to address EFDD’s priority of mandating unrestricted access for EU delegations to monitor detained activists like Ismayilova in real time.  
EFDD opposes the issue’s reliance on gradual legal reforms, advocating instead for an immediate repeal of laws barring non-Bar Association lawyers through binding EU trade conditionality.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over Azerbaijan’s systemic human rights violations, focusing on the imprisonment and mistreatment of anti-corruption blogger Mehman Huseynov, who faced additional charges and solitary confinement after a hunger strike, risking a 5-7 year extension to his initial two-year sentence. It highlighted Azerbaijan’s broader crackdown on dissent, citing 10 imprisoned journalists, the blocking of independent media outlets like Azadliq Radio and Meydan TV, and the targeting of activists through arbitrary charges, including the cases of Khadija Ismayilova (fined €23,000 in a disputed tax case) and 15 individuals punished for protesting Huseynov’s treatment. The resolution condemned Azerbaijan’s restrictive legal amendments, such as barring non-Bar Association lawyers from court, undermining defense rights for opposition figures, and noted the country’s poor press freedom ranking (163rd globally). It urged Azerbaijan to release all political prisoners, including journalists and activists like Afgan Mukhtarli and Ilgar Mammadov, comply with European Court of Human Rights rulings (e.g., Ismayilova’s privacy and expression rights violation), and reform laws restricting civil society funding. The Parliament stressed that EU-Azerbaijan relations, including ongoing negotiations for a Comprehensive Agreement, must prioritize democratic reforms, rule of law, and human rights, while calling on the EU to condition engagement on tangible progress. It further demanded an end to harassment of LGBTI communities, investigations into alleged corruption involving Council of Europe members, and enhanced support for civil society through EU delegations.

title: Bangladesh, including child marriages: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Bangladesh, including child marriages
background: Bangladesh has Asia’s highest child marriage rate, with 52% of girls married by 18 and 18% by 15, alongside reported human rights concerns including enforced disappearances and civil society restrictions. The Parliament will discuss child marriage prevalence and legislative measures affecting minors’ rights in Bangladesh.

stances.stance:
EFDD partially promotes the issue’s condemnation of child marriage legalization but demands amendments to explicitly criminalize all underage unions without "special case" exceptions.  
EFDD requests revisions to impose EU sanctions targeting Bangladesh’s Generalized Scheme of Preferences (GSP) benefits until labor rights violations, including stagnant wages since 2013, are remedied.  
EFDD insists the issue include mandatory independent investigations into enforced disappearances and police abuses, citing systemic repression of strikers and journalists.  
EFDD objects to the lack of binding timelines for Bangladesh to amend the 2017 Child Marriage Restraint Act, urging a 12-month compliance deadline tied to aid conditionality.  
EFDD highlights the omission of psycho-legal support mechanisms for child marriage survivors, requiring specific EU-funded rehabilitation programs in partnership with local NGOs.

ALDE absolutely upholds the issue's condemnation of Bangladesh's 2017 Child Marriage Restraint Act, perfectly aligning with ALDE's commitment to eradicating statutory rape loopholes that enable abusers.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with demands to freeze EU development funds until Bangladesh removes "special case" exceptions legalizing underage marriages, as emphasized in Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea’s intervention.  
ALDE fully supports the issue’s call to resume the National Action Plan with enforceable timelines, reflecting ALDE’s prioritization of accountability in child protection frameworks.  
ALDE unequivocally endorses amending the 2014 Foreign Donations Act to protect NGOs, a measure critical to safeguarding civil society’s role in combating systemic gender inequality.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s demand for independent investigations into violence against journalists, reinforcing ALDE’s principle of press freedom as foundational to democracy.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over persistent human rights violations in Bangladesh, including enforced disappearances, attacks on civil society, and violence against political activists and journalists. It highlighted Bangladesh’s alarmingly high child marriage rates, with 52% of girls married by 18 and 18% by 15, ranking it the highest in Asia, and condemned the 2017 Child Marriage Restraint Act for legalizing underage marriages through vague exceptions like “special cases” without requiring child consent, risking increased abuse, statutory rape, and forced marriages to perpetrators. While acknowledging Bangladesh’s legislative efforts and its 2015-2021 National Action Plan to eliminate child marriage, the resolution criticized poor implementation and regression caused by the 2017 law, undermining the government’s own targets to reduce under-15 marriages by 2021 and under-18 marriages by 2041. It urged amendments to close legal loopholes, establish clear judicial criteria involving health professionals and child consent, and resume the National Action Plan with concrete steps. The Parliament also called for gender equality measures, addressing root causes like poverty and lack of education, amending the 2014 Foreign Donations Act to protect NGOs, and ending violence against journalists through independent investigations. It urged the EU to prioritize these issues in dialogues and support Bangladesh’s compliance with international human rights obligations, including the Sustainable Development Goals and conventions on women’s and children’s rights.

title: Building EU capacity on conflict prevention and mediation: REPORT on building EU capacity on conflict prevention and mediation
background: The EU’s evolving role in global peace initiatives, existing multilateral frameworks, and rising security challenges prompted institutional efforts to address gaps in conflict prevention and mediation capacities, leveraging external assistance instruments and strategic partnerships. The Parliament will discuss strengthening EU capabilities in conflict prevention and mediation amid complex global security dynamics.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the proposed institutional restructuring through dedicated Council working groups, viewing it as bureaucratic duplication conflicting with existing external action mechanisms.  
EPP opposes fundamentally the mandatory gender-sensitive conflict analysis requirements, arguing they impose ideological frameworks over situational pragmatism in crisis zones.  
The issue's emphasis on transitional justice mechanisms overlooks critical EPP priorities for immediate security stabilization and counter-terrorism cooperation.  
EPP disputes the budget reallocations for peacebuilding as financially irresponsible, contradicting fiscal discipline principles amid competing cohesion policy needs.  
 While individual EPP members cite successful mediation practices, the group rejects systemic operationalization of these ad-hoc efforts through permanent structures.

SD absolutely accepts the issue’s integration of UNSCR 1325, perfectly aligning with their commitment to centering women’s leadership in peace processes as highlighted by Julie Ward’s emphasis on direct involvement of women from all backgrounds.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s prioritization of civil society partnerships, recognizing their critical role in operationalizing gender-sensitive mediation frameworks as championed in the debate.  
SD applauds the dedicated funding for gender-sensitive conflict analysis, directly advancing their manifesto pledge to eradicate structural drivers of gender-based violence through early warning systems.  
SD fully supports the human security principles outlined, which codify their decades-long advocacy for protecting women and children from conflict-related exploitation as stressed by Julie Ward.  
SD endorses the holistic linkage of mediation and education on gender equality, mirroring their insistence on combining policy tools with grassroots awareness-raising for transformative peacebuilding.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the imperative for the EU to prioritize conflict prevention, mediation, and peacebuilding as central pillars of its external action, emphasizing their alignment with international law, the UN Charter, and Sustainable Development Goals, particularly Goal 16 on peaceful societies. It underscored the EU’s role as a leading global actor in these areas, leveraging its diplomatic, development, and security tools, and called for enhanced institutional coordination, including the establishment of an EU high-level advisory board on conflict prevention chaired by a new EU Special Envoy for Peace, dedicated Council working groups, and task forces for specific conflicts. The resolution stressed the need for gender-sensitive and youth-inclusive approaches, integrating UN Security Council Resolutions 1325 (Women, Peace and Security) and 2250 (Youth, Peace and Security), and highlighted the importance of civil society, local actors, and transitional justice in addressing root causes of conflict. It welcomed initiatives like the Jean Monnet Dialogue for fostering parliamentary consensus in Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia, and the Western Balkans, and urged increased funding under the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework for conflict prevention, mediation support, and peacebuilding, including dedicated budget lines for early warning systems and gender-sensitive conflict analysis. The Parliament also advocated for stronger interinstitutional cooperation, capacity-building for staff and mediators, and expanded partnerships with the OSCE and UN, while emphasizing the EU’s responsibility to protect civilians, particularly women and children, from conflict-related violence and exploitation, and to ensure conflict-sensitive interventions in line with human security principles.

title: EU guidelines and the mandate of the EU Special Envoy on the promotion of freedom of religion or belief outside the EU: REPORT on EU Guidelines and the mandate of the EU Special Envoy on the promotion of freedom of religion or belief outside the EU
background: Rising global violations of freedom of religion or belief, including persecution of religious minorities and discriminatory legislation, alongside the EU’s 2013 guidelines and 2016 Special Envoy appointment, prompted review. The Parliament will discuss strengthening EU external policies on FoRB promotion, institutional mandates, and implementation mechanisms.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA firmly approves the issue’s inclusive recognition of non-believers, atheists, and apostasy rights, perfectly aligning with their commitment to universal human rights beyond traditional religious frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on integrating FoRB into EU foreign policy through multilateral cooperation, which effectively advances their vision of systemic human rights advocacy.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening protections for satirical or critical expressions about religion as a natural extension of FoRB principles, ensuring artistic freedom and dissent are safeguarded.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the necessity for the Special Envoy’s mandate to operate in full synergy with the EU Special Representative on human rights, reinforcing holistic rights-based approaches.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to repeal blasphemy laws, viewing this as critical to ending state-sanctioned persecution of dissenters and minorities.

ECR strongly advocates leveraging EU funding instruments to enforce FoRB compliance, specifically endorsing suspension of assistance to countries like Albania until religious freedoms for Greek minorities in Northern Epirus are fully restored. This aligns perfectly with ECR's commitment to tangible human rights conditionality.  
ECR approves the Special Envoy's mandate but proposes enhancing the report by explicitly referencing Europe's Christian heritage in line with Article 17 TFEU, ensuring historical religious contributions inform contemporary FoRB advocacy.  
ECR strongly endorses using development programs to combat forced church demolitions, citing the Saint Athanasios case as requiring urgent issue through EU mediation mechanisms.  
ECR applauds the issue's focus on blasphemy law repeal, which effectively advances ECR's priority of protecting persecuted individuals like Asia Bibi through diplomatic pressure.  
ECR recommends specifying "Christian communities" alongside religious minorities in annual reports to address disproportionate persecution patterns while maintaining universal FoRB principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the universal human right to freedom of thought, conscience, religion, or belief (FoRB), emphasizing its protection under international law, including the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and EU treaties. It condemned rising global violations, such as persecution of religious minorities, non-believers, and individuals like Raif Badawi (imprisoned in Saudi Arabia) and Asia Bibi (acquitted of blasphemy in Pakistan), and highlighted the instrumentalization of religion for political oppression, forced conversions, and harmful practices. The resolution stressed the EU’s obligation to integrate FoRB into foreign policy through the 2013 EU Guidelines, multilateral cooperation, and the role of the Special Envoy for FoRB, urging enhanced support for his mandate, annual reporting, and collaboration with UN mechanisms. It called for repealing blasphemy and apostasy laws, prioritizing FoRB in human rights dialogues, and allocating sufficient funding via instruments like the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights (2014-2020) and development programs. The Parliament underscored the need for education, religious literacy, and training for EU officials to combat intolerance, while ensuring transparency in funding and inclusive dialogue with religious and secular groups. It advocated for FoRB integration into conflict prevention, development policies, and annual human rights reports, urging accountability for violations and protection of persecuted individuals, including human rights defenders and atheists.

title: EU political relations with ASEAN: REPORT on EU political relations with ASEAN
background: The EU and ASEAN, established in 1967, have maintained formal relations since 1980, with evolving economic integration, trade agreements, and regional security frameworks. ASEAN's geopolitical significance, economic growth, and challenges like South China Sea tensions and human rights concerns prompted dialogue. The Parliament will discuss enhancing EU-ASEAN political and economic relations amid regional dynamics.

stances.stance:
SD completely agrees the issue’s prioritization of human rights protections, perfectly aligning with S&D’s unwavering commitment to addressing statelessness and condemning atrocities against the Rohingya minority as emphasized during parliamentary engagements.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s call for intensified ASEAN-EU parliamentary diplomacy through AIPA, reflecting S&D’s advocacy for multilateral dialogue over bilateral fragmentation to amplify collective action on regional crises.  
SD completely agrees the advancement of region-to-region FTAs, recognizing this as critical to reinforcing the EU’s role as ASEAN’s top investor and aligning with S&D’s vision for equitable economic integration benefiting 600 million people.  
SD perfectly supports the issue’s demand for adherence to UNCLOS in the South China Sea, mirroring S&D’s insistence on rules-based multilateralism to counter destabilizing militarization.  
SD completely agrees expanding Erasmus+ exchanges, aligning with S&D’s focus on youth empowerment and educational solidarity as foundational to long-term EU-ASEAN strategic cooperation.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's inadequate attention to corporate environmental crimes, as it fails to mandate binding measures against palm oil deforestation despite citing the 2015 Indonesian fires.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the omission of EU member states' non-citizen populations in human rights clauses, contradicting their demand for universal statelessness redress paralleling ASEAN's Rohingya crisis.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s silence on militarization accountability in the South China Sea, which conflicts with their anti-imperialist stance on territorial disputes.  
GUE_NGL disputes the climate action framework for lacking enforceable penalties against unsustainable agro-industries, inconsistent with their eco-socialist principles.  
GUE_NGL denounces the "ASEAN centrality" principle as tacitly endorsing regional power imbalances, mirroring EU institutional failures criticized in the Piran Bay arbitration example.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of strengthening EU-ASEAN relations, marking the 50th anniversary of ASEAN and 40 years of formal EU-ASEAN ties, and advocated upgrading the partnership to a Strategic Partnership with enhanced political, economic, and security cooperation. It highlighted the EU as ASEAN’s second-largest trading partner, with annual bilateral trade exceeding €200 billion, and noted the EU’s role as the top foreign investor in ASEAN, pledging over €3 billion (2014-2020) to reduce development gaps and support regional integration through initiatives like the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC), which aims to integrate over 600 million people. The resolution emphasized advancing Free Trade Agreement (FTA) negotiations with Indonesia, the Philippines, and others, while urging progress toward a region-to-region FTA. It expressed concern over South China Sea tensions, calling for adherence to international law, including UNCLOS, and support for a binding Code of Conduct to address militarization and territorial disputes. Security cooperation priorities included counter-terrorism, maritime security, cybersecurity, and disaster management. Human rights concerns featured prominently, urging ASEAN states to abolish the death penalty, address statelessness (notably the Rohingya crisis), protect minorities, and strengthen the ASEAN Intergovernmental Commission on Human Rights (AICHR). The EU stressed corporate social responsibility, labor rights, and environmental sustainability, urging climate action to protect biodiversity and transition to low-carbon economies. Educational and cultural exchanges, such as expanding Erasmus+ for ASEAN students, and parliamentary diplomacy through ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Assembly (AIPA) engagement were also prioritized. The resolution underscored the need for high-level political dialogue, alignment on multilateralism, and EU support for ASEAN centrality in regional security and economic frameworks.

title: EU political relations with India: REPORT on EU political relations with India
background: The EU and India established a Strategic Partnership in 2004, reinforced by summits, joint initiatives on trade, climate, and security, and ongoing negotiations for a free trade agreement since 2007. Shared democratic values and mutual economic interests underpin cooperation. The Parliament will discuss strengthening bilateral relations to address global challenges and expand strategic collaboration.

stances.stance:
EPP fully upholds the issue's strategic emphasis on India's democratic advantage over authoritarian systems, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to strengthening alliances with democratic partners.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call to accelerate EU-India FTA negotiations, recognizing India’s role as a critical economic counterbalance to China’s regional dominance.  
EPP fully upholds enhanced security cooperation with India, particularly in maritime domains and cyber defense, to counter assertive actions in the Indo-Pacific region.  
EPP fully upholds annual summits and institutionalized dialogue frameworks as essential tools to solidify India’s position as a democratic anchor in Asia.  
EPP perfectly aligns with leveraging India’s growing economic capabilities through initiatives like ‘Make in India’ to diversify EU supply chains and reduce strategic dependencies.

ECR strongly accepts the EU-India Strategic Partnership and the urgency to finalize the FTA, aligning with ECR’s commitment to fostering balanced trade and global economic resilience. They propose enhancing negotiations with binding provisions on labor rights and environmental standards to address concerns over workplace conditions and ecological sustainability.  

ECR approves the prioritization of annual summits and counter-terrorism cooperation, effectively advancing ECR’s focus on structured multilateral engagement and security-driven diplomacy.  

ECR emphasizes integrating safeguards for European SMEs into the FTA framework, suggesting amendments to ensure reciprocity in market access and prevent outsourcing-driven deindustrialization, consistent with their advocacy for fair competition.  

ECR welcomes the issue’s emphasis on human rights reforms, urging explicit linkage of partnership progress to India’s abolition of caste-based discrimination and protection of minority rights, reflecting ECR’s principled stance on democratic accountability.  

ECR applauds climate collaboration under the Paris Agreement and Clean Ganga initiatives, reinforcing their manifesto priorities on environmental innovation and sustainable development.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of deepening the EU-India Strategic Partnership, rooted in shared democratic values, human rights, and mutual interests, to address global challenges such as terrorism, climate change, and sustainable development. It emphasized the need to finalize the long-pending EU-India Free Trade Agreement (FTA), noting the EU is India’s largest trading partner with balanced trade flows, and urged negotiations based on reciprocity, WTO standards, and social responsibility. The resolution welcomed the 2016 EU-India Summit outcomes, including the Agenda for Action-2020 roadmap, joint declarations on clean energy, water partnerships, migration, and counter-terrorism, and stressed annual summits to enhance cooperation. It called for strengthened foreign policy coordination, UN Security Council reform supporting India’s bid for permanent membership, and collaboration on maritime security, cyber security, and nuclear non-proliferation, including India’s accession to export control regimes. Concerns were raised over human rights issues, urging India to abolish the death penalty, address caste-based discrimination, protect minorities, ratify anti-torture conventions, and repeal laws restricting NGO funding and LGBTQ+ rights. The resolution highlighted climate leadership through the Paris Agreement and Clean Ganga initiatives, advocated for gender equality, and encouraged India-Pakistan dialogue to reduce regional tensions. It also emphasized expanding educational exchanges under Erasmus+ and fostering economic ties through the ‘Make in India’ initiative.

title: Conclusion of the EU-Cuba Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement (Consent): RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Cuba, of the other part
background: The EU-Cuba relationship was historically constrained by a 1996 Common Position limiting political engagement, while Cuba faced prolonged US economic sanctions. The EU initiated negotiations in 2014 to establish structured cooperation, reflecting Cuba's regional significance and the EU's status as its largest trade partner. The Parliament will discuss concluding a bilateral Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement.

stances.stance:
EFDD partially approves the agreement but requests revisions to establish measurable benchmarks for civil liberties progress, citing unresolved political prisoner cases.  
EFDD emphasizes the need to amend Article 4 to prioritize EU-funded audits ensuring Cuba’s economic modernization directly reduces poverty inequalities.  
EFDD urges binding commitments in Annex II to address U.S. embargo impacts through targeted humanitarian aid channels, bypassing state intermediaries.  
EFDD highlights contradictions in democratic conditionality by demanding stricter parliamentary oversight of Cuba’s governance reforms before full ratification.  
EFDD supports replacing the restrictive Common Position but insists on phased sanctions relief contingent on verifiable freedoms of assembly and press.

SD totally agrees the agreement as a transformative framework that perfectly aligns with SD's commitment to replacing isolation with engagement-based human rights progress.  
SD highlights the accord's critical role in empowering Cuban reformists through structured dialogue, directly advancing SD's priority of fostering democratic evolution through international cooperation.  
SD recognizes the agreement's strategic value in countering U.S. policy shifts, aligning perfectly with SD's geostrategic vision for EU leadership in Latin America.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of rigorous implementation monitoring to enhance human rights protections, reflecting SD's longstanding focus on measurable democratic development.  
SD applauds the abolition of the Common Position as a historic achievement that matches SD's 2016 manifesto pledge to normalize EU-Cuba relations through principled engagement.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement between the EU and Cuba, aimed at strengthening bilateral relations by promoting dialogue on human rights, sustainable development, and trade liberalization. The agreement seeks to enhance cooperation across political, economic, and social spheres, emphasizing respect for democratic principles, the rule of law, and civil liberties, while fostering Cuba’s economic modernization and integration into international frameworks. It replaces the EU’s previous restrictive Common Position toward Cuba, marking a shift toward normalized engagement and providing a structured framework for addressing issues such as governance, migration, and counterterrorism. The resolution underscores the agreement’s role in supporting Cuba’s development through increased EU technical and financial assistance, market access, and private sector collaboration. Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its approval to the EU Council, Commission, member states, and Cuban authorities, finalizing the ratification process.

title: Conclusion of the EU-Cuba Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement (Resolution): REPORT containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Cuba, of the other part
background: The EU and Cuba established diplomatic relations in 1988 under the 1996 Common Position framework, repealed in 2016 to pursue the Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement (PDCA) signed that year. Persistent US embargo constraints, Cuba’s upper-middle-income classification, and its regional diplomatic engagements shaped bilateral dynamics. The Parliament will discuss ratifying the PDCA to formalize EU-Cuba relations, addressing human rights cooperation and economic partnership frameworks.

stances.stance:
EFDD rejects the PDCA's framework as insufficient to address Cuba's human rights violations, firmly condemning with EFDD's stance on democratic sovereignty.  
EFDD opposes the issue's failure to condemn Cuba's restrictions on freedoms of expression and assembly, inconsistent with their principles of civil liberties.  
EFDD condemns the continued phase-out of EU development aid, overlooking Cuba's structural economic challenges exacerbated by the U.S. embargo.  
EFDD disputes the agreement's monitoring mechanisms as inadequate to ensure transparent enforcement of labor rights and anti-exploitation measures.  
EFDD firmly condemns with the issue's alignment with Cuba's regional integration, ignoring unresolved democratic governance deficits.

ALDE totally advocates the PDCA’s human rights suspension clause as a critical mechanism to uphold democratic principles, perfectly aligning with their unwavering commitment to international standards.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on rigorous monitoring of Cuba’s adherence to civil liberties, advocating for sustained EU engagement to address systemic repression of dissent.  
ALDE strongly advocates leveraging the EU’s trade prominence to advance Cuba’s economic reforms, viewing the PDCA as pivotal for fostering regional integration and sustainable development.  
ALDE applauds the unequivocal condemnation of the U.S. embargo, reinforcing their principled opposition to extraterritorial policies that violate Cuba’s sovereignty and global trade norms.  
ALDE emphasizes the imperative of EU technical assistance to bolster internet freedom and empower independent civil society, ensuring Cuban citizens benefit directly from the agreement’s implementation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the significance of the EU-Cuba Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement (PDCA) as a transformative framework replacing the 1996 Common Position, emphasizing its focus on political dialogue, cooperation, and trade to strengthen bilateral relations. The resolution highlighted the PDCA’s inclusion of a human rights clause allowing suspension in case of violations, urging Cuba to align its policies with international standards, ratify outstanding UN covenants (e.g., International Covenants on Civil and Political Rights and Economic, Social, and Cultural Rights), and address concerns over freedoms of expression, assembly, and political association. It noted the EU’s role as Cuba’s largest trade partner and investor, with bilateral trade doubling between 2009-2015, and underscored Cuba’s receipt of €50 million in EU development aid (2014-2020), while expressing concerns over potential aid phase-out due to Cuba’s upper-middle-income status. The resolution called for lifting the U.S. embargo, condemning its extraterritorial impact and alignment with 26 consecutive UN General Assembly resolutions, and stressed the PDCA’s potential to support Cuba’s economic modernization, diversification, and integration into regional frameworks like the EU-CARIFORUM EPA. It welcomed Cuba’s ratification of ILO conventions but urged enforcement against labor exploitation, highlighted civil society’s role in democratic development, and advocated for inclusive implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. The Parliament also emphasized the need for transparent monitoring of human rights commitments, improved internet access, and EU technical assistance for trade facilitation, while acknowledging Cuba’s mediation roles in regional conflicts and its humanitarian contributions globally.

title: Constitutional, legal and institutional implications of a Common Security and Defence Policy: possibilities offered by the Lisbon Treaty: REPORT on constitutional, legal and institutional implications of a common security and defence policy: possibilities offered by the Lisbon Treaty
background: The Treaty of Lisbon and Title V of the Treaty on European Union established a framework for a Common Security and Defence Policy. Geopolitical shifts, emerging security threats, and the UK’s 2016 referendum prompted calls to enhance EU defence integration. The Parliament will discuss constitutional, legal, and institutional implications of advancing the policy under the Lisbon Treaty.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue's call to activate Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO) and reform the European Defence Agency, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to operationalize Lisbon Treaty provisions for integrated EU defense capabilities.  
EPP approves the proposed €100 billion defense investment target through 2% GDP allocations, emphasizing its multiplier effect on strategic autonomy and industrial innovation as outlined in the 2023 EPP security manifesto.  
EPP proposes accelerating intelligence-sharing through reinforced national agency platforms rather than new bureaucratic structures, enhancing interoperability while maintaining operational efficiency.  
EPP applauds the emphasis on NATO complementarity and hybrid threat resilience, which effectively advances EPP's priority to balance transatlantic ties with sovereign EU crisis-response capacities.  
EPP endorses upgrading parliamentary oversight mechanisms to ensure democratic accountability in defense procurement, urging swift implementation of the Security and Defence Subcommittee reforms.

EFDD rejects the issue’s pursuit of an EU defense union as ideologically driven folly, completely disputeing with EFDD’s insistence that NATO remains the cornerstone of European security and rejecting the premise of "strategic autonomy" as destabilizing transatlantic ties.  
EFDD opposes the imposition of 2% GDP defense spending targets, condemning the issue’s failure to address austerity’s social devastation or eliminate redundancies, which EFDD argues must precede any fiscal demands on member states.  
EFDD rejects the creation of a European Defence Fund without prior clarity on governance and cost-sharing, deeming the issue inconsistent with democratic accountability and fiscal transparency principles.  
EFDD opposes accelerated integration via PESCO and EU Battlegroups, asserting that such measures lack citizen consent and mirror the EU’s overreach in monetary policy, which EFDD has historically contested.  
EFDD criticizes the issue’s silence on NATO’s irreplaceable role, advocating instead for reforms to reinvigorate burden-sharing within the alliance rather than duplicating structures under EU branding.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to advance the European Defence Union through enhanced integration, increased military spending, and full utilization of Treaty provisions, emphasizing the €100 billion annual cost of fragmented defense and advocating for Member States to allocate 2% of GDP to defense, generating an estimated €100 billion boost by 2030 to enhance capabilities, foster strategic autonomy, and support the European defense industry. It called for activating Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO) to streamline multinational forces like EU Battlegroups, reforming the European Defence Agency (EDA) to coordinate capability development and procurement, and establishing a European Defence Fund to co-finance research and joint projects. The resolution stressed interoperability, harmonized armed forces, and a revised Athena mechanism for fairer cost-sharing in missions, while underscoring complementarity with NATO, though advocating reduced dependency. It highlighted deficiencies in EU training missions (e.g., Mali, CAR), urging adequate equipment and observer roles for EU personnel. Parliamentary oversight was prioritized, including upgrading the Security and Defence Subcommittee and enhancing interparliamentary scrutiny. Strategic initiatives like an EU Defence White Book, Coordinated Annual Review on Defence, and adherence to the Global Strategy’s Implementation Plan were endorsed, alongside addressing post-Brexit CSDP dynamics and UN Security Council reform for global governance. The resolution reiterated commitments to solidarity under Article 42(7) TEU, human rights, and gender-sensitive conflict resolution, while rejecting amendments opposing NATO or EU military funding.

title: Addressing human rights violations in the context of war crimes, and crimes against humanity, including genocide: REPORT on addressing human rights violations in the context of war crimes, and crimes against humanity, including genocide
background: Persistent reports of war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide in conflicts involving state and non-state actors, alongside challenges to international justice mechanisms including ICC member withdrawals, have prompted scrutiny. The Parliament will discuss addressing such violations through enhanced prevention, accountability frameworks, and support for global judicial cooperation.

stances.stance:
SD entirely sanctions the issue’s emphasis on gender-based violence as a weapon of war, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to centering women’s voices in justice and peacebuilding.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for accountability for sexual crimes in conflicts, emphasizing the urgency of supporting survivors in Kosovo and other post-conflict regions as outlined in the issue.  
SD entirely sanctions the demand for women’s inclusion in peace processes, reflecting SD’s longstanding advocacy for survivor-led transitional justice and reparations.  
SD highlights the issue’s alignment with SD priorities through its focus on evidence-gathering mechanisms like the IIIM for Syria, critical to amplifying testimonies from Yazidi and Christian genocide survivors.  
SD underscores the necessity of the issue’s measures to combat impunity in Nigeria and Burundi, ensuring justice for victims of Boko Haram and state-sponsored atrocities.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the issue’s selective condemnation, which contradicts their principle of universal accountability by exempting states like the U.S., Israel, and EU members for atrocities such as NATO’s bombings in Yugoslavia.  
GUE_NGL rejects the hypocrisy in lauding the ICC while omitting its failure to prosecute Western-aligned actors, as evidenced by the posthumous exoneration of Milošević and unchecked NATO violations.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s geopolitical bias, which weaponizes human rights rhetoric to target adversaries while ignoring crimes by allies, such as Saudi Arabia’s actions in Yemen or EU border violence.  
GUE_NGL disputes the legitimacy of sanctions and arms embargoes proposed in Articles 12–14, arguing they will be applied asymmetrically, shielding powerful states complicit in IHL breaches.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s failure to address root causes like Western imperialism and militarism, which GUE/NGL views as systemic drivers of atrocity crimes.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to prevent and address atrocity crimes—genocide, crimes against humanity, and war crimes—by emphasizing the EU’s commitment to international law, justice, and accountability. It stressed the ICC’s critical role in combating impunity, noting its 124 member states and the activation of the Kampala Amendments on the crime of aggression, ratified by 34 countries. The resolution condemned withdrawals from the Rome Statute by Russia, Burundi, and others, while welcoming Gambia’s and South Africa’s reversals. It called for universal ICC ratification, increased funding for the Court, and enhanced cooperation to execute arrest warrants for 13 fugitives. The EU was urged to support investigations into atrocities in Syria, Iraq (including ISIS/Daesh’s genocide against Yazidis and Christians), Nigeria (Boko Haram’s crimes), and Burundi (potential crimes against humanity), including backing the UN’s IIIM for Syria and proposals for an International Criminal Tribunal for Iraq and Syria. The resolution highlighted gender-based violence as a weapon of war, demanding accountability for sexual crimes and women’s inclusion in peace processes. It advocated sanctions against states aiding ISIS/Daesh, arms embargoes on violators of international humanitarian law (IHL), and support for evidence-gathering initiatives like the "Bringing Daesh to Justice Coalition." Member States were urged to adopt universal jurisdiction, strengthen national laws on atrocity crimes, and amend EU treaties to include these crimes under EU competence. The resolution also emphasized transitional justice, victim reparations, and compliance with IHL, while condemning Russia and China’s UN Security Council vetoes blocking ICC referrals. Finally, it called for reforms to prevent conflicts, address root causes, and enhance early-warning systems, alongside training for EU delegations and security forces to detect and prevent atrocities.

title: Annual report on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy: REPORT on the Annual Report on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy
background: Growing geopolitical instability, including conflicts in the EU’s eastern and southern neighborhoods, hybrid threats, migration pressures, and challenges to multilateralism, alongside evolving security dynamics and institutional frameworks under the EU Global Strategy, prompted review of collective foreign policy mechanisms. The Parliament will discuss strengthening the EU’s Common Foreign and Security Policy to enhance coherence, strategic autonomy, and global crisis response capabilities.

stances.stance:
EFDD rejects the establishment of a unified EU Common Foreign and Security Policy as entirely rejecting with their commitment to national sovereignty and historical opposition to supranational military structures, citing the 1954 French rejection of the European Defence Community.  
EFDD opposes EU defense integration through NATO collaboration, arguing it subordinates European security to unpredictable US interests under Trump's administration and undermines independent national decision-making capabilities.  
EFDD condemns proposals for EU-controlled military forces as a federalist overreach that risks authoritarian suppression of member states' populations, referencing fears of "tanks in Warsaw, Rome, and Paris" to maintain Brussels' authority.  
EFDD challenges the issue's NATO alignment priorities, asserting that existing bilateral agreements and NATO itself remain superior to EU defense mechanisms that duplicate structures and threaten traditional neutrality of countries like Ireland and Sweden.  
EFDD fundamentally doubts UK participation in post-Brexit EU security frameworks, denouncing any continued British compliance with CFSP as a betrayal of the referendum mandate for full independence in foreign policy and defense matters.

ALDE fundamentally endorses the establishment of permanent defense mechanisms like the European Defence Fund and PESCO, perfectly aligning with the issue’s call for enhanced cybersecurity and defense-industrial integration through EU frameworks.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on NATO-EU synergy, emphasizing that joint defense aspirations must prioritize interoperability with NATO while retaining autonomous EU operational capacity for scenarios requiring independent action.  
ALDE fundamentally endorses accelerated progress toward a unified European defense union by 2025, particularly through pooled research and joint deployment initiatives, mirroring the issue’s demand for critical equipment investment and 2% GDP defense spending targets.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s cyber defense priorities, advocating for EU-wide training exercises and NATO-EU coordination frameworks to counter hybrid threats, as demonstrated by Estonia’s cyber defense leadership during its EU presidency.  
ALDE fundamentally endorses leveraging PESCO to transcend fragmented national defense systems, explicitly supporting the issue’s vision of replacing 27 armies with integrated EU capabilities while assuring neutral members of shared security benefits.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need for a unified and effective EU Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) to address global security threats, including hybrid warfare, cyber aggression, terrorism, and violations of international law by states like Russia, China, and North Korea. It emphasized the importance of upholding human rights, democracy, and the UN Charter, while calling for coordinated EU action to stabilize regions such as the Western Balkans, Syria, Libya, Yemen, and the Sahel, including support for peace processes, sanctions against human rights violators, and reconstruction efforts. The resolution stressed the necessity of reducing energy dependence on authoritarian regimes, enhancing cybersecurity and defense cooperation through initiatives like the European Defence Agency and NATO collaboration, and allocating 2% of GDP and 20% of defense budgets to critical equipment. It highlighted concerns over Russia’s illegal annexation of Crimea, hybrid warfare, and veto misuse in the UN Security Council, while advocating for conditional engagement. The Parliament urged reforms to enable qualified majority voting for CFSP decisions, criticized underfunding (noting CFSP’s 0.2% share of the 2016 EU budget and a €55.6 million deficit in 2017), and called for transparent budget lines for major missions. Additional priorities included addressing climate change’s security impacts, promoting legal migration, countering disinformation, expanding cultural diplomacy via programs like Erasmus+, and strengthening partnerships with the US, Latin America, and Asia to uphold multilateralism and a rules-based global order.

title: Annual report on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy: REPORT Annual report on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy
background: Growing global instability, including interstate conflicts, terrorism, cyber threats, and challenges to multilateral governance, alongside shifting geopolitical power dynamics and internal EU coordination difficulties, prompted the European Parliament’s review. The Parliament will discuss enhancing the EU’s strategic autonomy and policy coherence in foreign affairs and security to address global instability and shifting power dynamics.

stances.stance:
SD strongly accepts transitioning to qualified majority voting for CFSP decisions, aligning with their vision of a cohesive EU foreign policy responsive to hybrid threats and geopolitical shifts.  
SD approves the strategic autonomy framework through PESCO and military mobility enhancements, emphasizing compatibility with NATO’s enduring role in transatlantic security.  
SD endorses binding mechanisms to halt arms exports violating human rights, urging explicit linkage between defense funding allocations and adherence to ethical trade criteria.  
SD advocates integrating cyber defense capabilities with civilian missions under CSDP mandates, reinforcing Europe’s capacity to counter disinformation campaigns and authoritarian tech expansion.  
SD proposes amending the European Defence Fund provisions to mandate transparent parliamentary oversight and industrial conversion support, ensuring alignment with democratic accountability principles.

ECR rejects the issue's push for qualified majority voting in CFSP, fundamentally opposing any erosion of national sovereignty in foreign policy decision-making.  
ECR opposes the concept of EU strategic autonomy through PESCO and military mobility, warning these initiatives dangerously advance the creation of a divisive EU army separate from NATO.  
ECR condemns increased defense integration as wasteful duplication, asserting NATO must remain Europe’s primary security framework rather than EU-led structures.  
ECR challenges the issue’s migration solidarity mechanisms, arguing they impose centralized EU control over national border policies against member state interests.  
 ECR member Tannock’s support for JCPOA maintenance contrasts with the party’s broader rejection of EU foreign policy integration.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the EU’s increasingly volatile security environment, marked by interstate conflicts, terrorism, cyberattacks, and hybrid threats, alongside demographic shifts such as the EU’s projected decline to 5% of the global population by 2050 and Africa’s population surge to 1.3 billion by 2050, which risks destabilizing fragile states. It emphasized the EU’s declining geopolitical influence amid rising powers like China, India, and the U.S., urging strategic autonomy through enhanced defense cooperation, including Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO) and military mobility, and increased funding for external action under the 2021-2027 MFF. The resolution called for a unified foreign policy leveraging trade, development, and CSDP tools to uphold multilateralism, human rights, and climate action, while condemning U.S. withdrawal from the JCPOA and Russia’s aggression in Ukraine and Georgia. It stressed the need to address migration through solidarity, support Western Balkans’ EU accession conditional on reforms, and promote stability in the Mediterranean and Africa via economic partnerships. The EU’s role as the world’s largest economy and leading aid donor was highlighted, alongside demands for qualified majority voting in CFSP to enhance decision-making, stronger EU-NATO cooperation, and resilience against hybrid threats like disinformation and cyberattacks. The resolution also advocated for a two-state solution in the Middle East, condemned Assad’s atrocities in Syria, and urged adherence to the Paris Agreement in trade deals. It underscored the importance of combining hard and soft power, including defense capabilities and civilian missions, to bolster the EU’s global influence and protect its values.

title: Annual report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy: REPORT on the Annual report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy
background: The EU's 2016 Global Strategy and subsequent defence initiatives, alongside evolving security challenges including Russia's actions in Ukraine, Middle Eastern instability, cyber threats, and transnational terrorism, prompted increased focus on security integration. The Parliament will discuss the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy annual report and strategic defence priorities.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the operationalization of Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO) and the European Defence Fund as critical steps toward achieving EU strategic autonomy, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to integrated defense capabilities.  
EPP approves the binding commitments to increase defense spending to 2% of GDP, emphasizing that this will enhance interoperability and address critical capability gaps identified in coordinated annual reviews.  
EPP proposes clarifying Article 42.7 TEU implementation procedures through a dedicated EEAS working group to ensure rapid activation of mutual assistance clauses while maintaining NATO compatibility.  
EPP strongly approves embedding counter-terrorism mandates and deradicalization programs in all CSDP missions, effectively advancing EPP's priority of addressing security threats at their source through initiatives like EULEX Kosovo.  
EPP endorses the creation of a Directorate-General for Defence to streamline funding mechanisms, with a minor enhancement suggestion to include biannual implementation reports to Parliament for enhanced accountability.

EFDD rejects fundamentally the creation of EU-controlled military structures as a direct threat to national sovereignty and democratic self-determination.  
EFDD opposes increased defense spending targets (2% GDP) as financial coercion serving federalist integration inconsistent with citizens' rejection of Lisbon Treaty obligations.  
EFDD condemns the proposed Directorate-General for Defence as an undemocratic power grab enabling "eurocrates" to deploy forces against dissenting member states like Poland or Italy.  
EFDD challenges EU-NATO collaboration as subordinating European security to U.S. interests under Trump's unpredictable leadership, contrary to EFDD's anti-interventionist principles.  
EFDD dismisses post-Brexit UK-EU defense cooperation as illegitimate given the issue's federalist trajectory that betrays neutral states' traditions and British voters' sovereignty demands.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over escalating global security challenges, including interstate conflicts, hybrid threats, cyberattacks, terrorism, and climate-related instability, stressing the need for a unified EU response under the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). It emphasized enhancing defense cooperation through initiatives like the European Defence Fund (EDF), Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO), and coordinated annual defense reviews (CARD) to address capability gaps, improve interoperability, and boost strategic autonomy. The resolution called for member states to increase defense spending to 2% of GDP (potentially adding €100 billion by 2024) and urged stronger EU-NATO collaboration on hybrid threats, cybersecurity, and missions such as EUNAVFOR Med. It highlighted the urgency of countering terrorism through intelligence sharing, deradicalization programs in CSDP missions (e.g., EULEX Kosovo), and addressing root causes like poverty and governance failures. The Parliament advocated for a European Security and Defence White Book, a proposed Directorate-General for Defence, and reforms to streamline CSDP mission funding, including revising the Athena mechanism and establishing a start-up fund for rapid deployments. Specific measures included Norway’s €585,000 contribution to defense research, support for joint procurement, and improved crisis response in regions like the Sahel, Iraq, and the Western Balkans. The resolution also addressed Brexit’s impact, urging continued UK-EU defense cooperation while leveraging new momentum for EU integration, and stressed the importance of protecting democratic values, resilience, and human security in external actions.

title: Annual report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy: REPORT on the Annual report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy
background: The EU faced deteriorating security environments, challenges to multilateralism, interstate conflicts, cyber threats, and geopolitical tensions with Russia, alongside existing defense cooperation mechanisms like PESCO and the European Defence Fund. The Parliament will discuss implementing the Common Security and Defence Policy to address evolving security challenges and enhance EU strategic capabilities.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue’s emphasis on strategic autonomy through PESCO and the European Defence Fund, which aligns perfectly with EPP’s longstanding commitment to a robust EU defense architecture.  
EPP approves the prioritization of NATO spending targets (2% GDP on defense) as essential for credible deterrence, while advocating enhanced EU-NATO complementarity as referenced in 74 joint actions.  
EPP highlights the European Peace Facility and military mobility initiatives as critical enhancements to crisis response, proposing accelerated decision-making to overcome unanimity delays in urgent security matters.  
EPP underscores the necessity of transatlantic cooperation while building EU capabilities, echoing calls for democratic accountability and intelligence-sharing to counter hybrid threats like disinformation.  
EPP emphasizes stabilizing the Western Balkans and Eastern Neighborhood as immediate priorities, urging full implementation of the East StratCom Task Force to counter external destabilization efforts.

ECR rejects the issue's push for EU strategic autonomy as fundamentally incompatible with NATO's primacy and a dangerous diversion from transatlantic security guarantees.  
ECR opposes any removal of national vetoes in CFSP, asserting this violates member states' sovereignty and undermines democratic accountability in defense matters.  
The proposal's emphasis on PESCO and EU defense integration is condemned as a veiled step toward an EU army, which ECR views as fiscally irresponsible and strategically divisive.  
ECR highlights the issue's failure to address security threats like Nord Stream II, which directly empowers Russian aggression while EU institutions ignore member-state objections.  
The call for increased EU defense spending through centralized programs conflicts with ECR's principle that capabilities must be nationally controlled and NATO-aligned.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over systemic challenges to the rules-based international order, including interstate conflicts, terrorism, cyberattacks, disinformation, and climate change, stressing the need for a unified EU response through enhanced Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) efficiency and strategic autonomy. It emphasized the urgency of countering Russia’s destabilizing actions, such as its occupation of Ukraine, hybrid tactics, and chemical weapon use, while advocating restrictive measures and solidarity among Member States. The resolution highlighted the importance of increasing defence spending to meet NATO targets (2% of GDP, with 20% allocated to equipment) and welcomed initiatives like Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO), the European Defence Fund (proposed €6.5 billion for military mobility under the 2021-2027 MFF), and the European Defence Industrial Development Programme (€500 million until 2020) to bolster capabilities, interoperability, and the European defence industry. It called for a EU Security and Defence White Book to guide capability-building and endorsed the European Peace Facility to fund CSDP operations and partnerships, including African Union missions. The Parliament underscored the necessity of EU-NATO complementarity, referencing 74 joint actions and EDA involvement in 30 projects, while advocating improved military mobility, cybersecurity cooperation, and intelligence-sharing. Gender-sensitive approaches in conflict resolution, parliamentary oversight upgrades (e.g., transforming the Security and Defence Subcommittee into a full committee), and post-Brexit UK security ties were emphasized. The resolution also urged exploring a future EU force for peacekeeping under UN principles and stressed the need for democratic accountability in defence integration, balancing autonomy with transatlantic cooperation.

title: Association Agreement between the EU and Monaco, Andorra and San Marino: REPORT on a European Parliament recommendation to the Council, to the Commission and to the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the association agreement between the EU and Monaco, Andorra and San Marino
background: The European Union has historically engaged with microstates Andorra, Monaco, and San Marino through bilateral agreements and regulatory alignment efforts, particularly in financial governance and tax transparency. The Parliament will discuss negotiating an association agreement to deepen political and economic integration while addressing the states’ unique geopolitical and administrative constraints.

stances.stance:
EFDD totally rejects the issue's integration framework as an existential threat to micro-state sovereignty, consistent with their rejection of EU expansionist tendencies.  
EFDD rejects the premise of "tailored acquis adoption" as a deceptive gateway to full regulatory assimilation, citing historical precedents where temporary derogations were systematically eroded.  
EFDD highlights contradictions in advocating banking stability through Eurosystem access while demanding alignment with EU financial rules, viewing this as coercive centralization of monetary policy levers.  
EFDD condemns the administrative capacity-building provisions as creating structural dependencies that would bind micro-states to EU technocratic oversight indefinitely.
